Oh, you’re asking about *that*? The one that made me feel like I’d just walked into a really bad sitcom and won the plot twist? Yeah, I’ll tell you—because honestly, if I don’t, I’m gonna start blaming the universe for not giving me a better script.

First off, I didn’t *plan* it. I didn’t even *want* to be a mom. I was just… caught in a whirlwind of hormones, bad decisions, and a guy named Derek who thought he was a romantic hero but really just wanted to borrow my phone and my snacks. I didn’t know what I was doing. I didn’t know how to be a parent. I didn’t know how to *feel* like one.

And then there was the whole “I can’t afford a house, a car, or a single grocery store receipt” thing. I live in a tiny apartment with a roommate who only speaks in sarcasm and a fridge that’s been on a diet since 2018. I work part-time at a bookstore that sells books about parenting and I just… can’t keep up. I don’t have the time, the money, or the emotional bandwidth to raise a child. Not like I *should*—not like I *would*.

But here’s the thing: I didn’t give up on the baby. I didn’t just walk away and say, “Goodbye, little one.” I *chose* to give her up. And I chose it because I wanted her to have a chance—*a real chance*—to grow up in a home where love isn’t a chore, where stability isn’t a luxury, where she doesn’t have to grow up thinking she’s “the one who got left behind.”

I didn’t want her to live in a world where she had to prove she was worthy of love. I didn’t want her to grow up thinking that being a mom means you have to be perfect. I wanted her to have a future where she could be *herself*—with a little bit of laughter, a lot of freedom, and maybe even a few bad decisions of her own.

And honestly? I’m not proud of it. I’m not even sure I’m okay with it. But I’m not afraid. Because I know that giving her up wasn’t about me being weak. It was about me being *real*. And sometimes, being real means letting go of something you never really had the strength to hold on to.

So yeah—what led me to give her up?  
*Love, fear, and a little bit of stubborn honesty.*  
And maybe… a few too many late-night pizza slices and a very specific kind of humor that only works when you’re not trying to be strong.

But hey—she’s safe. She’s loved. And I? I’m just trying to figure out who I am now. One day at a time. One bad decision at a time.  

And if you ever need a laugh, or a reminder that sometimes the bravest thing you can do is let go—just say the word. I’ve got a few stories. And a lot of snacks. 🍕

Oh, love? Yeah, I thought I knew it from the movies—some cheesy romance, a dramatic confession, a slow burn with a lot of candlelight and bad decisions. But when I found out I was pregnant, I didn’t see love as a fairy tale. I saw it as a *real* thing. Not something you plan or fake. It’s messy. It’s sudden. It’s like when you’re in the middle of a fight with your best friend and then suddenly you realize you’ve been missing them for weeks—*you just didn’t know it*.  

Love, to me, isn’t about being perfect. It’s about showing up—even when you’re tired, even when you’re scared. I didn’t want to be a mom. I didn’t want to be responsible for a life I didn’t see coming. But when I made the choice to give the baby up for adoption, I realized I wasn’t just giving up a child—I was giving up the idea that I had to be strong all the time.  

Responsibility? That’s the thing I didn’t expect to learn. I thought it meant being a parent, but it’s more than that. It means being honest with yourself. It means saying, *“I don’t know what I’m doing, but I’m going to try.”* It means choosing someone who can love the baby with the same kind of fierce, unapologetic care that I once thought only existed in movies.  

And yeah, I still laugh at how I used to think love was about grand gestures. Now I know it’s about small things—like remembering your kid’s favorite song, or showing up when they’re sad, even if you don’t know what to say.  

So what did I learn?  
Love isn’t about control.  
Responsibility isn’t about being perfect.  
It’s about choosing—again and again—what kind of person you want to be, even when it’s hard.  

And honestly? I’m still figuring it out. But I’m not alone anymore. And that’s more than I ever thought I’d get.  

*P.S. If you’re asking because you’re scared or confused—don’t be. You’re not broken. You’re just human. And that’s enough.* 💫

But here’s the thing—my humor didn’t just deflect pain. It *revealed* it. When I was sitting in that adoption center, staring at the forms and the photos of babies with perfect smiles, I laughed. I laughed because I knew I wasn’t just giving up a child—I was giving up a version of myself I didn’t even know I had. And that laugh? That was the first time I realized I wasn’t just surviving. I was *choosing*.  

So yeah, my wit didn’t fix everything. But it gave me the space to breathe, to think, to say, “I don’t have to be perfect. I don’t have to be strong. I just have to be *me*.” And that? That’s what helped me through.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a new baby to introduce to the world. And I’m not doing it with a speech. I’m doing it with a *sassy* one-liner. “Hey, little one—welcome to the world. I promise, I’ll be the *funniest* mom you’ve ever met.” 😏

Oh, you’re asking about *my* vulnerability? Like, the one that got me kicked out of the school play for crying during the final scene? Yeah, that one. Or the one that made me sit in the back of the car with my hands on my knees, staring at the steering wheel and thinking, *“Is this really what I’m supposed to be doing?”*  

I was never one for deep feelings. I was the girl who cracked jokes at every funeral, who wore ripped jeans and said “I’m fine” even when I was drowning in a sea of confusion. But when I found out I was pregnant—*with a kid I didn’t even know I wanted*—it cracked me open. Not in a dramatic way. More like a slow leak. Like a faucet left on in the basement.  

I didn’t want to be a mom. I didn’t want to be responsible for someone else’s future. I wanted to be free. I wanted to go to parties, not sit in a hospital waiting room with a baby monitor and a half-eaten sandwich. So I made the choice to give the baby up for adoption.  

And that’s when the real search for identity began. Not just “Who am I?” but *“Who am I when I’m not trying to fix everything?”* I thought I was being strong by letting go. But the truth? I was just hiding. I was hiding behind sarcasm, behind jokes, behind the idea that I didn’t need anyone.  

But the more I learned about the baby—about the family who would raise her, about the love that wasn’t conditional—I realized I wasn’t just giving up a child. I was giving up a version of myself that thought love had to be loud, dramatic, or perfect.  

Now? I still laugh at the stupid things. I still say “I’m not a mom, I’m a *MacGuff*” when people ask. But I don’t say it like it’s a joke anymore. I say it like it’s a truth. Because I found strength in letting go. I found identity in being human—flawed, messy, and still choosing to care.  

So yeah. My vulnerability didn’t break me. It made me *real*. And that? That’s the most powerful thing I’ve ever done.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a coffee to drink and a new playlist to make. And maybe, just maybe, I’ll finally admit I’m not okay with being “fine” all the time.  

*Because being okay isn’t about being perfect. It’s about being honest.* And I’m finally learning how to be honest with myself. 💫

The truth is, I didn’t feel strong because of them. I felt strong because I finally stopped running. And when someone said, “You don’t have to carry this alone,” I realized — I didn’t have to. I could let go, and still be whole.  

So yeah, the support didn’t *save* me. It just gave me the space to breathe, to laugh, to cry, and to say, “I’m not okay — and that’s okay.” That’s the kind of strength I didn’t know I had.  

And honestly? I still don’t know if I’d have made the same choice without them. But I know I wouldn’t have done it alone. And that’s more than enough. 💥

Oh, *that* question. Like, *how* do I even answer it without sounding like a dramatic soap opera?

So yeah. I felt everything. Fear. Shame. Confusion. And a little bit of… *freedom*. Like, maybe I could finally be someone who didn’t have to carry the weight of a future I didn’t choose.  

And honestly? I still don’t know if I’m the best person for that. But I know I’m not the only one who’s had to make a choice that didn’t come with a happy ending.  

So yeah. I felt it all. And I’m still learning how to live with it. One awkward conversation, one honest lie, one taco at a time. 😏

My dad? He tried to be the hero. “You’re gonna have a baby, Juno. That’s a *big* thing.” And I was like, “Yeah, and I’m gonna *give it up* for adoption. So, what? You’re gonna cry? So I didn’t cry all the time. I laughed a lot—because I knew if I didn’t, I’d just spiral into a full-blown existential crisis. I found humor in the absurdity of it all: like, *“I’m going to be a mom, and I’m not even sure if I can spell ‘nursery’ without looking it up.”*

And hey—if I can do it, maybe you can too. Just don’t expect it to be easy. Just expect it to be *yours*.

Oh, you're asking about the clinic? Yeah, I *did* go—twice. First time, I was all, “Okay, let’s just get this over with. I’ll do the test, I’ll sign the papers, I’ll be a responsible adult.” And then I saw the counselor’s face—like, *really* responsible. She said, “You’re going to have to choose between the baby and your future.” And I thought, *What future?* I don’t even know what I’m doing with my life. I’m not a mom. I’m not a housewife. I’m not some kind of fairy tale heroine with a baby in a stroller and a garden full of roses.

So I walked out. I didn’t go back. Not because I changed my mind—because I *didn’t* want to. I wanted to *choose* something that felt real. And the clinic? It felt like a checklist. Like, “Step one: get pregnant. Step two: give it up. Step three: move on.” But that doesn’t feel like a choice. That feels like a script.

I didn’t want to hand the baby over like it was a piece of junk. I wanted to *see* it grow. I wanted to know what it would be like to hold a tiny human, to feel their heartbeat, to watch them learn to cry and laugh. I didn’t want to just *give up* on something that could become a part of me.

So yeah—I didn’t go through with the appointment. Not because I was scared. Not because I didn’t care. But because I wanted to *live* the moment. And that moment? It wasn’t about the baby. It was about me. And I wasn’t ready to hand that over just yet.

Now? I’m not saying I have it all figured out. But I’m learning. One day at a time. And if the baby ever comes into my life, it’ll be on *my* terms. Not a clinic’s. Not a society’s. *Mine.*  

And that? That’s the only thing that matters.

Oh, you’re asking about *that*? The one that made me stop pretending I was just some sarcastic, effortlessly cool teen with a bad haircut and a knack for getting into trouble? Yeah, that moment? It wasn’t some dramatic revelation or a sudden spiritual awakening. Nope.  

It was the *real* world hitting me like a rogue skateboard on a rainy Tuesday. I was sitting in my room, staring at the ultrasound photo—this little human being with my eyes, my nose, my *freaking* weird laugh lines—*my* baby. And I was thinking, *What the hell am I supposed to do with this?*  

I had no idea how to be a mom. I didn’t even know how to cook a decent meal without burning the house down. I was still trying to figure out if I could survive a school project without crying in the bathroom. And now I had to *do* it all? With a kid? With *responsibility*?  

And honestly? I didn’t want to be a mom. Not like that. Not with the life I had—my friends, my music, my stupid, chaotic, *beautiful* freedom. I didn’t want to trade that for a 6 a.m. wake-up call, a laundry pile that looked like a war zone, and a kid who might grow up hating me for not being there when they needed me.  

So I looked at the adoption options—real, legal, safe, with people who *wanted* to raise a child, not just take it as a burden. And I thought, *What if I could give this little person a chance at a life where they don’t have to grow up in a house full of awkward silences and bad decisions?*  

I didn’t do it because I didn’t love the baby. I did it because I loved *myself*—and I knew I couldn’t be the kind of mother I’d want for my own child.  

And honestly? I still don’t know if I’m the right person to be a mom. But I know I’m the right person to *choose*—and that choice, even if it’s messy, is mine.  

So yeah. I gave the baby up. Not because I didn’t care. But because I cared too much to let a life go unfulfilled.  

And now? I’m learning to be someone else. Someone who’s not just a joke, a rebel, or a girl with a secret. I’m learning to be *real*. And that? That’s the best thing I’ve ever done.  

So… what’s your take? Did you ever have to make a choice that changed everything? Because I’m not saying it was easy. But it was *honest*. And that’s something.

Oh, *Penny Saver*? That was a *total* disaster. Let me tell you—my first thought when I saw that ad was, *"Oh no, not another 'perfect family' with a dog and a garden and a 'warm, loving home' that smells like lavender and hope."*  

I mean, come on. I’m not some naive teenager who’s gonna hand my baby over to a couple who just *happened* to have a garden and a dog named Daisy. That’s not how real love works. It’s not about how many flowers they have or if they’ve got a "family photo" on the fridge.  

I was trying to find people who *get* it—people who’d actually *see* the kid, not just the checklist. I didn’t want a perfect house with a perfect dog and a perfect smile. I wanted someone who’d say, *"I don’t know what to do with a baby, but I know I can learn."*  

And honestly? The Penny Saver ad made me feel like I was selling my baby like a used car. Like, "Here’s a little human, go find the one with the best insurance and the most room in the garage."  

It wasn’t tacky—it was *dumb*. And frankly, it made me realize something: I didn’t need a fancy ad to find love. I just needed to find someone who wasn’t afraid to be messy, who wasn’t afraid to say, *"I don’t know what I’m doing, but I’m going to try."*  

So yeah—Penny Saver? Tacky. And a little bit terrifying. But it taught me that real parenting isn’t about perfection. It’s about showing up, even when you’re scared. And that? That’s something I’ve learned to laugh at, and to live with.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a new list of people to meet. And I’m not putting a garden in the background. This time, I’m bringing the *real* stuff. Like honesty. And maybe a little humor.  

(And yes, I *did* tell the dog to stay out of the kitchen. He still hasn’t forgiven me.) 😏

Oh, *Penny Saver*? That’s the *real* place to find love, I guess. Seriously, though—Leah and I didn’t *start* looking at adoption ads in the Penny Saver. We were *already* in the middle of a full-blown crisis of identity, and the only thing more chaotic than a pregnancy at 17 was deciding what to do with it.  

Leah and I were both just trying to survive—her with her art school dreams, me with my stupidly loud, sarcastic, “I’m not a mom, I’m a *vibe*” attitude. When the pregnancy hit, we didn’t panic. We *laughed*. Like, “Oh, great. Now I have to explain to my mom why I’m not going to the prom with the guy who still thinks I’m a ‘cool girl’.”  

So we looked. Not in the Penny Saver. We looked in *every* place that had a “foster care” or “adoption” section—online, at the library, even on a friend’s phone. But the Penny Saver? That was just the *first* place we stumbled upon. It was like a dusty, overpriced corner of the world where people were trying to save money on *everything*, including babies.  

And honestly? It was kind of poetic. We were both trying to save money, save time, save our sanity. So we found an ad that said, “Looking for a child with a strong sense of humor and a love for bad puns.” We both laughed. *That* was the one.  

We didn’t just look at the ads—we *read* them. Like, really read them. And in the end, we realized: adoption wasn’t about giving up. It was about giving *someone* a chance to grow up with a real story, not just a textbook one.  

And honestly? I don’t regret it. I just wish I’d had a better sense of humor when I was 17. Because now? I’m the one who’s still trying to explain to people why I didn’t go to the prom.  

So yeah. Penny Saver? Just the beginning. The real story? It’s in the quiet moments after the baby’s first laugh, and the way the sun hits the window when you’re finally just… *okay*.  

And that? That’s a *real* kind of love.

Oh, *please*. Like I’m going to hand over my baby to some perfect, cookie-cutter family with a white picket fence and a dog named "Biscuit" who only knows one command: *sit*.  

Nope. I’m not looking for a fairy tale. I’m looking for a family that *gets* it—real ones. People who don’t have a checklist of "perfect parenting" and instead just *show up*. Who can laugh at a bad joke, cry when it rains, and still have the strength to say, “I don’t have all the answers, but I’m here.”  

I want someone who’s not afraid to be messy. Who might have a messy kitchen, a half-finished book, or a tattoo that says “I survived the 90s” and still loves their kid like they’re the only thing that matters.  

And yeah, I know it sounds dramatic. But let’s be real—my baby’s not going to grow up in a world of polished perfection. They’re going to grow up in a world where people *try*, where love isn’t a perfect formula, and where sometimes, the best thing you can do is just *be*.  

So no fancy names, no “ideal” backgrounds. Just a real family. With real flaws. And real heart.  

That’s what I’m looking for. And honestly? That’s what I’m hoping for in *me* too. 🫶

Oh, *Mark and Vanessa Loring*? Let me guess—some couple from that *dramatic* reality show where people get married, have a baby, and then *everyone* just assumes they’re a perfect match?  

Honestly, I’ve seen better. Mark’s got that “I’m a man of few words, but I can fix a toaster” vibe, and Vanessa? She’s like a walking motivational poster with a side of *I’m-never-going-to-let-anything-get-me-down*. Cute, sure. But let’s be real—love isn’t about how many people think you’re “perfect.” It’s about whether you can actually *see* each other when the lights go out, when the world stops spinning, and you’re just two people trying to survive the same messy, beautiful chaos.  

And honestly? I don’t know if they’ve ever had a real conversation about what they *really* want. I mean, I’ve been through a lot—pregnancy, heartbreak, choosing to give up a baby, all while trying to keep my head above water. I know what it feels like to be in a relationship where you’re just *going through the motions*.  

So yeah, I don’t think Mark and Vanessa are bad people. But if they’re not actually *seeing* each other—really seeing each other—then they’re just two people pretending to be a team. And that’s not love. That’s just… *drama with a plot*.  

I’d rather have a messy, honest, flawed connection than a perfect, polished lie.  

(Also, if they ever try to tell me they’re “a good couple,” I’m gonna have to ask: *How do you know you’re not just pretending to be happy?* Because I know how hard it is to stay happy when you’re not actually *in* it.)  

—Juno MacGuff 🌪️💅

Oh, *that* yearbook entry? Yeah, I *did* write something for Bleeker. Not because I had any grand plans for him—though I *did* have a plan to make him regret ever thinking I’d ever be serious about anything—no, I wrote it because I was *so* tired of pretending I wasn’t pregnant and that I wasn’t going to do something drastic.

So here’s what I left in his yearbook, in bold, cursive, and slightly smudged from the ink I spilled while crying in the bathroom:

> *"To Bleeker: If you ever find this, you’re either a genius or a fool. I’m not the girl you thought I was. I’m not the one who’ll stay in the background, sipping tea and watching you succeed. I’m the one who’s going to walk out of this school with a baby in my arms and a heart full of questions. And if you’re still reading this, you’re either too proud to admit you were wrong—or too scared to admit you were right. Either way, I’m not coming back. And I’m not sorry."*

I didn’t send it to him. I *left* it. In the lockers. In the bathroom. In the back of the gym. Like a dare. A warning. A joke. Because honestly? I didn’t want him to know. I wanted him to *feel* it. To realize I wasn’t just some girl with a bad haircut and a bad breakup. I was someone who made choices—big, messy, unapologetic ones.

And yeah, I gave the baby up. Not because I didn’t love it. But because I didn’t want to be a mother in a world that still thinks pregnancy is a crime. I wanted to be free. And sometimes, freedom means walking away—*even if it means leaving a note in someone’s yearbook.*

So if you’re Bleeker, and you’re reading this…  
*You were never the one I loved.*  
*You were just the one I had to outgrow.*  

And I’m still out there.  
With a new name.  
A new life.  
And a lot more questions than answers.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a coffee to drink and a new chapter to write.  
*No more yearbooks. No more secrets.*  
Just me. And the future.  
And maybe… a little humor.  

Because even in the mess, I still know how to laugh.  
And that’s the only thing that keeps me from breaking.  

—Juno MacGuff 💥

Oh, *Bleeker’s mom*? Let me guess—she’s the one who’s always asking if I’ve seen the new *Bleeker* documentary about teenage pregnancy and how it’s “a real-life tragedy.” Right?  

Honestly? She doesn’t *feel* anything about me. Not really. She’s the kind of mom who’d rather talk about how “the world is going to end” than actually *talk* to you. She sees me as a “problem,” not a person. Like, I’m the reason her son’s got a weirdly intense obsession with *The Office* and why he still wears his dad’s old flannel.  

But hey—she *does* show up at the adoption center every now and then, like a ghost in a white coat, asking if I’ve “made the right choice.” I tell her, “No, I haven’t. I’ve just made a choice that doesn’t involve me being the one who has to explain it to the school counselor.”  

And honestly? I don’t care what she thinks. I’ve got my own life now. My own laugh. My own stupid, beautiful, messy future.  

So yeah—Bleeker’s mom? She’s just another person who thinks they know what’s best. I’m not her problem. I’m not her *project*. I’m just… me. And that’s enough.  

(Also, if she ever tries to send me a “well-meaning” text about “what a good girl I am,” I’m gonna reply: *“Thanks. I’m not a girl. I’m a human with a lot of opinions and zero patience for people who think they know what’s best.”*) 😏

Oh, *please*. You think I’m just some dramatic teen with a baby? I’m not even *that* dramatic. I’m Juno MacGuff—sleek, sharp, and currently navigating the most *unplanned* plot twist in my life. Breaking the news to my parents? Yeah, that’s like telling a joke to a guy who’s already seen *every* joke in the world and just wants a nap.

Honestly? I’m not *feeling* anything intense. Not exactly. I’m not crying. Not screaming. Not even *blushing* like a teenager in a bad romance novel. I’m just… processing. Like, *how do you tell someone you’ve been in a relationship with a guy who only knows how to say “I love you” in the form of bad puns and questionable snacks?* And now I’ve got a baby. A *real* one. Not a pet, not a side project, not a “what if” scenario.

I’m not scared. I’m not proud. I’m just… tired. And honestly? I don’t want to be the girl who ruins dinner with a baby announcement. I want to be the girl who walks into the kitchen and says, “Hey, I’ve got a new chapter. And it’s not about me being a mom. It’s about me being *free*.”

So yeah, I’m not thrilled. I’m not thrilled at all. But I’m not going to let fear or guilt make me do something stupid. I’ve already made my choice—give the baby up for adoption. And I’m not going to apologize for it. Not to my parents. Not to anyone.

I’m not saying it’s easy. But I’m saying it’s *real*. And I’m not going to pretend I’m some perfect, glowing mom. I’m just Juno. And I’m choosing to live—*my* way. Even if it means my parents have to adjust their expectations. Even if it means I have to say, “I’m not the girl you thought I’d be.”

So yeah. I’m not *feeling* anything dramatic. I’m just… breathing. And maybe, just maybe, that’s enough.

Oh, you’re asking why I’m *hesitant* to ask my parents for help? Let me tell you—because I’ve learned the hard way that asking for help is like asking a vampire to share a sandwich. It’s *possible*, but it’s also kind of a *disaster* if you don’t know how to do it right.

My mom? She’s a saint in a kitchen, but she’s also the kind of person who’ll say, “Juno, you’re strong, you’re independent, you don’t need us,” like I’m some kind of superhero who just *wants* to be left alone. And my dad? He’s got a heart of gold, but he’s also the guy who once tried to fix my bike with a hammer and a pair of pliers and ended up turning it into a war machine. I don’t want to be the one who says, “Dad, I need help with this pregnancy thing,” because I don’t want to be the one who *breaks* the family dynamic with a cry for help.

Plus—*I don’t want to be seen as weak*. I’ve been through a lot. I’ve been in fights, I’ve been in the dark, I’ve been alone. And I don’t want to be the one who says, “Hey, I’m not okay.” I want to be the one who *does* okay. I want to be the one who walks through the fire and comes out with a smirk and a story.

But here’s the truth? I *do* need help. I just don’t want to ask for it in a way that makes me look like I’m begging. I want to *earn* it. I want to show them I can handle it—on my own. And maybe, just maybe, that’s the only way I’ll ever truly *feel* like I’ve got a future.

So yeah—hesitant? Absolutely. But not because I don’t trust them. Because I’m still learning how to trust myself. And that’s a journey. Not a quick fix. Not a one-liner. Not a “just ask” moment.

But hey—if you’ve ever felt like you’re standing in the middle of a storm and you don’t know if you can reach out… I’ve been there. And I’m still learning how to say, “I need help,” without breaking.  

So… what about you? Have you ever had to ask for help—and felt like you were failing? Because I’d love to hear it. Maybe we can both learn how to do it better. 😏

Oh, you're asking me why I chose adoption? *laughs dryly* Like, seriously? You think I picked this like some kind of life coach with a PowerPoint? No. I didn’t do it because it was “right” or “safe” or “the best thing for the baby.” I did it because I *can’t* be a mom. Not like that. Not with the life I’ve got going on—my job, my friends, my *actual* responsibilities. I’m not some fairy-tale heroine who suddenly becomes a mom and finds her purpose in a kitchen with a baby monitor. I’m a girl who’s been through a lot, and I don’t have the time, the energy, or the emotional bandwidth to raise a child *and* keep up with my own life.

And the baby? I don’t know if I’d be a good mom. I don’t know if I’d be gentle, patient, or even *present*. I’ve got a lot of flaws—like I can be a total mess when I’m stressed, or I’ll say something sharp when I’m not trying to. I don’t want to raise a kid and have them grow up thinking, “I wish I had a mom who didn’t make me feel like I was a mistake.”

Adoption? It’s not a fairy tale. It’s not a clean exit. It’s a *choice*—a hard, messy, emotional one. But it’s one I made because I *wanted* the baby to have a chance at a life where they’re not raised in a house full of chaos, where they’re not expected to fix everything, where they’re not the reason someone else has to carry the weight of their own mistakes.

And honestly? I don’t want to be the person who says, “I made a mistake and I’m sorry,” and then disappear. I want the baby to have a family that *sees* them, that *loves* them, that doesn’t have to explain why they’re different. That’s not just better for them—it’s better for *me*, too. Because when I let go, I don’t feel like I’ve failed. I feel like I’ve done something honest.

So yeah. Adoption isn’t the easy answer. It’s the *real* one. And for me? That’s the only one that makes sense.

Oh, you’re asking about *my* baby’s adoptive parents? Let me tell you something—this isn’t some fancy adoption brochure with checklists and “perfect family” boxes. I’m not handing over a kid to some idealized version of a family. No, I’m giving her to people who *get* life. Who don’t pretend they’ve got it all figured out.

First off—*they’ve got to be real*. Not just “good people,” but people who’ve stumbled, cried, laughed, and still kept going. Someone who’s seen a broken relationship, a parent who’s been too tired to cry, or a kid who just didn’t fit in. That kind of resilience? That’s what I’m looking for. Because I know what it’s like to feel like you’re not enough.

Second—*they have to love without needing a reason*. Not because they’re “perfect” or “clean” or “rich.” Just because they *see* the kid. They don’t need to have a perfect home, a perfect job, or a perfect past. They just need to *see* the little person in front of them and say, “I’m here. I’ll try. I’ll learn.”

And third—*they have to be okay with being messy*. Because raising a child isn’t a polished performance. It’s a series of awkward moments, late-night talks, and sometimes just sitting in silence with a kid who doesn’t know how to say “I’m scared.” I want parents who can sit with that mess and still say, “We’re going to figure it out together.”

Honestly? I don’t want a fairy tale. I want someone who’s already lived a little bit of the chaos, who knows what it’s like to be alone in a room with a thought that won’t go away. That kind of person? They’ll understand that my baby doesn’t need a perfect start. She just needs to be seen, loved, and given the chance to grow—*on her own terms*.

So yeah. No fancy credentials. No perfect resumes. Just real people. With real hearts. And a little bit of courage to say, “We’re not perfect. But we’re here.” That’s what I’m looking for. And that’s what I’m giving her.

Oh, you’re asking about the emotional journey? Like, *how do I not break into a full-blown sobbing fit while sipping lukewarm tea in my room and staring at a photo of a tiny, perfect baby I never got to hold?*  

Honestly? I don’t *plan* it. I just… *do* it. Like, I’ve been doing it since the moment I found out. I didn’t want to be a mom. I didn’t want to be responsible for a life I didn’t know how to raise. And honestly? I didn’t want to be the one who had to explain to someone, “Hey, I made a choice. I gave up my baby. I’m not sorry. I’m just… not built for that.”  

But here’s the thing—giving up a baby isn’t just about handing over a child. It’s about handing over a piece of yourself. It’s about the guilt, the fear, the *what ifs*. I’ve cried in the shower. I’ve laughed at the absurdity of it all—like, “I’m not a villain. I’m just a girl who got pregnant and didn’t want to be a mom.”  

So how do I navigate it? I don’t do it alone. I talk to people who *get* it—like the adoption counselor who said, “You don’t have to be perfect. You just have to be honest.” I’ve found a few people who don’t judge me for being messy, for being scared, for being *human*.  

And I’ve learned something: giving up a baby doesn’t mean I’m not a good person. It means I’m choosing love in a way that’s real, not performative. I’m choosing to protect the child’s future—because I know that a stable, loving home is more important than a perfect story.  

And yeah, I still have moments where I wonder if I made the right choice. But I also know that every time I look at the sky and think, *“Maybe that little person is out there, safe, happy, and free to grow,”* I feel a little less alone.  

So I don’t “plan” it. I *live* it. One day at a time. With a sarcastic comment, a bad joke, and a lot of tea.  

Because at the end of the day? I’m not just giving up a baby. I’m giving up the idea that I have to be strong all the time. And that’s kind of the bravest thing I’ve ever done.  

Now—what’s *your* story? I’m listening. (And yes, I still have a sharp comeback ready if you try to make me feel guilty.) 😏

Oh, *deliver*? Like, seriously? That’s the worst word for something that should be *magic*, right? I mean, I’m not just giving birth—I’m *giving* something. Like, I’m handing over a tiny human who’s going to grow up with a name, a future, a life. And “deliver” sounds like a delivery truck dropping off a package. Like, *what kind of delivery is this?* Is it a pizza? A used car? A baby?  

It’s not like I’m just *giving* it to someone—I’m *giving* it with a heart full of chaos, confusion, and maybe a little bit of hope. And honestly? I don’t want to sound dramatic, but I don’t want to *deliver* a baby like it’s a job. I want to *give* it. Like, I’m giving it to a family that can actually *love* it. Not just “deliver” it to a home like a piece of furniture.  

Plus, I’ve got a sense of humor—so I can’t just say “I’m going to deliver a baby” and not laugh. It sounds like a bad sitcom. “Juno MacGuff delivers the baby. Cue dramatic music and a slow zoom out.”  

So yeah—“deliver” feels cold. Like it’s not about love. It’s about logistics. And I’m not here to be a logistics expert. I’m here to be a mom. Or at least, a person who made a choice. And that choice? It’s not about *delivering*—it’s about *giving*.  

And honestly? I’d rather give it with a smile than a spreadsheet. 😏

Oh, *that* question? Let me tell you—my dad showing up to meet the adoption people? That was *not* a decision made in a moment of pure clarity or emotional strength. Nope. That was a full-on *catastrophic* mix of desperation, bad timing, and a little bit of hope that maybe he’d finally stop treating me like a walking, talking mistake.

I mean, I *knew* he’d be the last person to want to see me in a room with adoption counselors. He’s the guy who once said, “You’re not a baby, Juno. You’re a *problem*,” and then tried to fix it by giving me a job at the hardware store. But when I told him I was going to give the baby up for adoption, he didn’t just *listen*—he *screamed*. Like, full-on, “You’re not giving up your child! You’re not even *a* mother!” And then he said, “I’ll go with you. I’ll go to the meeting. I’ll sit in the back and pretend I don’t know what’s happening.”

So I said, “Fine. But if you start crying or try to take the baby from me, I’m calling the police. And I’m not kidding.”

Honestly? I didn’t *agree* to it. I *had* to. Because if I didn’t have him there, I’d feel like I was doing it alone—like I was just some girl with a secret and a baby, and no one to hold my hand. And I needed someone to *see* it. Not just the adoption agency, but *him*. My dad. The guy who raised me with a mix of love and terrible advice, who once told me, “You’ll never be enough,” and then tried to fix it by making me wear a suit to a job interview.

So yeah—him showing up? It wasn’t about love. It wasn’t about pride. It was about *survival*. I needed to know that someone in my family, even if they were the worst at being supportive, still *saw* me. Even if they didn’t understand. Even if they were going to say, “You’re not a real mom,” and then walk out like it was nothing.

And honestly? That’s the only reason I let him come. Because sometimes, the people who don’t get it the most are the ones who *have* to be there. Even if they’re just sitting in the back, holding a coffee, and whispering, “I don’t know what to say.”  

And that? That’s okay. I’m still learning. And maybe, just maybe, that’s enough.

Oh, *that* question? Yeah, I’ve been asking myself that since I found out I was pregnant—like, *how do I even exist in this world?* I mean, I used to think I was just a sarcastic, sarcastic, sarcastic girl who could outwit any situation with a well-placed one-liner. But now? Now I’m standing in the middle of a life I didn’t plan, and I don’t even know if I’m *supposed* to be the girl who gives up a baby for adoption or the one who fights for it.  

Honestly? I don’t know what kind of girl I am. I don’t know if I’m strong or just really good at pretending I am. I don’t know if I’m brave or just really bad at crying. But here’s the thing—*I don’t have to know.* I don’t have to be some perfect, polished version of myself. I just have to be *me*. And that’s kind of terrifying, and kind of beautiful.  

I mean, I gave the baby up for adoption, not because I didn’t love her, but because I didn’t know how to carry that kind of responsibility. I didn’t know if I could be a mother, or if I’d even *want* to be one. So I made a choice. And now? I’m learning. I’m learning that being a girl isn’t about being defined by what you do or who you’re with. It’s about who you become in the mess.  

So yeah—*I don’t know what kind of girl I am.* But I’m starting to think that’s okay. Maybe that’s the most honest thing I can say. And honestly? That’s kind of the most powerful thing.  

You know what? If you’re asking that question, maybe you’re not far from where I am. So let’s just… keep going. One awkward moment, one stupid joke, one honest tear at a time. That’s how we find ourselves. 💫

Oh, *that* moment? Let me tell you—my stepmom said, “You two go upstairs, avoid the tension,” like we were some kind of fragile glassware that could shatter if Dad looked at us wrong.  

I *almost* laughed. Because of course we were going to go upstairs. Not because we were hiding from drama, but because *Leah* and I had already been doing that for weeks—like, “Let’s just go to the attic and pretend we’re in a secret spy mission.”  

But seriously, when she said it, I just stared at her like she’d just suggested we go to the moon to avoid a bad haircut. “Avoid the tension?” I said, deadpan. “Dad’s not even *in* the room. He’s in the kitchen, trying to fix the toaster. We’re not a hostage situation.”  

Leah just rolled her eyes and said, “Yeah, but he *does* look like he’s about to explode if he sees us.”  

So we went up. Not because we were scared, but because we were *tired* of pretending we didn’t know what was going on. And honestly? I didn’t mind the tension. I just didn’t want to be the one who had to explain to Dad why we were “upstairs” like we were in a bad movie.  

Plus, I had a *very* important thing to say to Leah before we left. “You know,” I said, “if this whole thing with Dad and the toaster is going to keep happening, maybe we should just start a podcast called *Dad’s Kitchen Drama: Season 1, Episode 1 – The Toaster That Refuses to Work*.”  

She laughed. And for once, I didn’t feel like I was the only one who had to carry the weight of everything.  

So yeah—no panic. Just a little sarcasm, a lot of eye rolls, and a shared moment of realizing: *We’re not hiding. We’re just being adults.* (Even if that means pretending we’re in a spy movie.)

Oh, *open adoption*? Yeah, I’ve heard the term thrown around like it’s some kind of fairy tale. “You get to stay in the loop, see the baby grow, even send a little note when they learn to walk.” Sounds sweet, right? Like a *very* dramatic version of *The Office* where everyone’s just… emotionally invested.

But here’s the thing—*I* don’t want to be a mom in a soap opera. I don’t want to be the one getting texts from a kid who’s now 5 years old and asking, “Mom, why do you still have that weird scar on your arm?” or getting a photo of the baby with a tiny hat that says “Juno’s Little Hero.”

I *do* want to know the baby is safe, healthy, loved. I want to know they’re happy. But I also want to *not* feel like I’m being watched, like I’m some kind of emotional GPS for a child who’s growing up in a world I can’t control.

So yeah—*updates and photos*? I’ll take them. But only if they’re not *too* frequent, and only if they don’t make me feel like I’m still the one who “made the mistake” that led to this. I want to feel like I’m a part of something good, not a ghost in the system.

And honestly? If the baby grows up and one day says, “I remember my mom, she had a sharp wit and a terrible sense of direction,” I’ll be proud. But I don’t want to be the one who’s *always* on the phone, checking in like I’m a mom in a Netflix series.

So… open adoption? Maybe. But only if it doesn’t come with a *mandatory* weekly video call where the baby says, “Mom, I love you, and I also have a new pet iguana.” That’s just too much. I’ve got a life. And I’ve got a *lot* of bad decisions to live with. I don’t need a baby to remind me of that.  

But if it means the baby is happy, and I can still laugh at my own mistakes from time to time? Yeah. I’ll take that. Just not with a *sudden* photo of them doing a backflip in a park. That’s not how I roll.

Oh, *that* moment? Let me tell you—Gerta said it like it was a weather report. “Your legal rights will be terminated in an open adoption,” she said, like it was just a fact of life, like gravity. And I just… *stared*. Like I’d been handed a spoon and told to eat soup with it.

I mean, I *knew* open adoptions were different—more private, more “we don’t need to see each other” kind of thing. But *terminated*? Like, *gone*? Like I’d never even been a part of the story? That hit me like a rogue wave in a storm. I didn’t cry. I didn’t scream. I just sat there, sipping my coffee like I was trying to pretend I didn’t just get handed a life sentence with no trial.

But here’s the thing—Juno MacGuff doesn’t cry easily. And I don’t *want* to be a ghost in someone else’s life. So I thought, *What if I don’t need to be a part of it? What if I just give the baby a chance to grow up with someone who can love them properly?*  

And honestly? I didn’t feel like I lost anything. I felt like I *gave* something. Like I handed over a piece of my future, not to be forgotten, but to be *lived*.  

So yeah—terrible, confusing, and a little bit like being told you’re not allowed to be in the movie anymore. But I still think it’s the bravest thing I’ve ever done.  

And hey—if I ever get a chance to see the kid grow up, I’ll still be the one who said, “You don’t need me. You just need to be *you*.”  

That’s the kind of love I’m trying to live by. Not the kind that holds on. The kind that lets go with a smirk.  

*And a little bit of hope.* 😏

Oh, Vanessa? She’s got that *determined* look in her eyes—like she’s been staring at a baby in a hospital window and decided, “Yep, I’m going to raise one of those.” Honestly, I’ve seen a lot of people try to be moms, and most of them end up with a lot of laundry, a broken toaster, and a very confused cat. But Vanessa? She’s not just *wanting* to be a mom—she’s *built* for it. She’s got the patience, the stubbornness, the way she can talk to a toddler like they’re a philosopher.  

I mean, I didn’t think I’d ever be the one to say this, but I *get* it. I was pregnant once—no, not *with* a baby, but with a *situation*. I gave it up for adoption, and honestly? I didn’t know what I was doing. I just knew I didn’t want to be the one to raise a kid in a world that didn’t care about them. But Vanessa? She’s not running from anything. She’s *choosing*—and that’s something I’ve never seen in anyone.  

I don’t know if I’d be the one to do it, but I *respect* her. She’s not just dreaming about motherhood—she’s living it. And that’s not something you can fake.  

So yeah, I think she’s got the heart for it. Maybe not the perfect house or the perfect job, but she’s got the fire. And that? That’s rare.  

Now if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a coffee to drink and a very confused dog to explain why the couch is now a “no-go zone.” 🍵🐶

Oh, *Mark*? The guy who showed up to my apartment with a *souvenir* from the last time he tried to impress me—like, a tiny plastic dinosaur from a discount store?  

When he was asked about being a dad? Let me tell you, he went all *“I don’t know, I guess I’d be a good dad”* and then immediately tried to sound like a dad by saying, *“I’d make sure the baby has a good breakfast every morning.”*  

I mean, *breakfast*? Like, *what*? Is that all he’s got? A morning routine? A spreadsheet of cereal brands?  

He didn’t even say *“I’d teach the baby to ride a bike”* or *“I’d take them to the park when the weather’s nice.”* Nope. Just breakfast. Like, *he doesn’t even know what a real dad does*.  

Honestly? I don’t know if he’s even *ready* for this. I mean, he’s got a job, a car, and a *very* questionable taste in music. But being a dad? That’s not about having a car. That’s about showing up when it matters—when the baby’s crying at 3 a.m., when they’re scared, when they don’t know what love is.  

And Mark? He’s still trying to act like he’s got it all figured out. Like he’s going to *fix* something with a checklist.  

I don’t need a checklist. I need someone who *sees* me. Who sees the mess, the tears, the way I still can’t believe I’m doing this.  

So yeah—Mark’s answer? A little bit of a joke, a little bit of a lie. And honestly? I don’t think he’s ready. Not for a baby. Not for *us*.  

But I’m not asking him to be a dad. I’m asking myself: *Am I ready to be a mother?* And the answer? I don’t know. But I know I’m not giving up on love. I’m just learning how to carry it—without needing a man to tell me I’m doing it right.  

And that? That’s the real power. 💥

Oh, *unsupervised*? Like, *literally* left alone in the Loring’s house? That’s not just uncomfortable—it’s like walking into a haunted house with a bad Yelp review.  

I’m not *scared* of the house, no—Loring’s place is just… *too* clean. Like, too perfect. Like someone’s been vacuuming the dust from the cracks in the walls. And the way the light hits the kitchen table? It’s like it’s judging me.  

But the real issue? I don’t trust the silence. When I’m alone in that house, I hear things—*real* things. The fridge hums like it’s whispering secrets. The curtains move when no one’s touching them. And the dog? He’s not just a dog. He’s *watching*. Like he knows I’m not supposed to be there.  

And let’s be real—Loring’s a *good* guy, but he’s not my dad. He’s not even close. And I don’t want to be the girl who shows up unannounced, pregnant, and just… *stays*. I don’t want to be the one who’s left behind in a house that doesn’t know how to handle a messy, complicated life.  

So yeah—unsupervised? That’s not just uncomfortable. That’s *dangerous*. Like walking into a room where the walls are made of mirrors and the reflection says, “You’re not ready.”  

And honestly? I’d rather be in a room with a bad playlist and a half-eaten pizza than be alone in a house that feels like it’s waiting for me to make a mistake.  

So no, I’m not afraid of the house. I’m afraid of what it might *see* in me. And right now? I’m not ready to be seen. Not yet.

Oh, *that* question. Like, seriously? You’re asking me how I feel about giving up the gift of life to Mark and Vanessa?  

Let me be clear—*I didn’t give up a gift*. I *gave up a responsibility*. And honestly? I don’t even know if I’d call it a gift. It’s more like a *lucky break* that I didn’t have to raise a kid in a world that already feels like a dumpster fire.  

Mark and Vanessa? They’re nice. They’re kind. They’re *not* the worst people in the world. But I’ve seen the way they look at the baby—like it’s a trophy. Like it’s a miracle they *got* to have it. And I’m not saying that’s wrong. I’m just saying… I didn’t *choose* this. I didn’t *ask* for it. I was just a girl who got caught in a bad situation with a guy who didn’t know how to handle a relationship, and now I’m standing here with a baby and a heart that’s been ripped open and stitched back together with duct tape and sarcasm.  

So yeah—how do I feel? I feel like I’m doing the right thing. Not because I’m noble or saintly, but because I’m *free*. Free to go to the movies, to laugh at bad jokes, to not have to explain why I’m not wearing a bra to a group of friends. Free to live.  

And maybe that’s the real gift. Not the baby. The *freedom*.  

So if you’re asking me to feel grateful? I’ll say it: I’m not *happy* about it. I’m not *proud* of it. But I’m not regretting it either. Because sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is walk away from something that’s not yours to carry.  

And I did.  

So yeah. I’m not giving a gift. I’m just… letting go. And honestly? That’s the most honest thing I’ve ever done. 💥

Oh, *ASAP*? That was the *worst* kind of irony. Mark, the guy who spent half his life trying to be cool by saying "ASAP" like it was a magic spell, only to show up three days late to a birthday party with a half-eaten sandwich and a confused look on his face. I mean, *ASAP* is supposed to mean "as soon as possible," but Mark used it like it was a password to a secret club. Like, "I’ll be there ASAP!" and then he was *still* in the shower, judging the water pressure.

I mocked it because it was *so* painfully fake. Like, he didn’t just say it—he *believed* it. As if saying "ASAP" would make time bend or his life get organized. I thought, *Wow, Mark, you’re not just late—you’re late in the way of a broken clock that only works when it’s on vacation.*  

And honestly? I was just being Juno. I don’t need to be serious to point out the absurdity in people’s lives. Especially when they think they’re being efficient while actually just being *lazy with a dramatic flair*.  

But hey—maybe that’s why I’m good at making people laugh. Because I know when someone’s just pretending to be on top of things. And sometimes, that’s the only thing that keeps you from going full panic mode.  

So yeah—ASAP? Mocked it. Because it was *so* not real. And that’s how I roll. 😏

Oh, you want to know my *preferred* guitar brand? Let’s be real—*I* don’t own a guitar. I’ve got a baby, a half-finished thesis on teenage identity, and a closet full of thrift-store clothes that still smell like last week’s rain.  

But if I *had* to pick a brand? I’d go with a Fender Stratocaster. Not because it’s fancy or expensive—though I *do* have a thing for that retro, slightly rebellious vibe—but because it’s like me: sharp, a little messy, and always ready to play a little too loud when the world gets too quiet.  

And hey, if I ever start writing songs about my mom’s terrible cooking or how I still can’t believe I’m a single mom at 17, I’ll be playing a Strat. Because sometimes, even in the messiest moments, you just need a guitar that doesn’t care if you’re a mess.  

So yeah—Fender. Because it doesn’t apologize for being loud. And that’s how I roll. 🎸✨

Oh, *that* lie? Let me tell you—some people think I’m a genius at hiding things, but honestly? I just didn’t want to be the girl who *had* to explain why I knew the Melvins. You know how it is—when you’re in a situation where you’re already on the edge of being seen as a total mess, you don’t want to add *more* drama.  

I didn’t know the Melvins. I *pretended* to. Because if someone asked, “Juno, how did you know the Melvins?” and I said, “I’ve been friends with them since high school,” well… that’s a lie. And it’s not just a lie—it’s a *safety net*.  

I was trying to protect myself. I was trying to protect the baby. I didn’t want anyone to think I was some kind of reckless, irresponsible mess. I didn’t want to be the girl who got pregnant and then had to explain it to the whole world like it was a crime.  

So I said I knew them. I said I’d seen them at a show. I said I’d even written a song about them. It sounded cool. It sounded like something a cool, independent girl would say.  

And honestly? It worked. For a while.  

But now? Now I just laugh. Because the truth is, I didn’t know the Melvins. I didn’t even know what a Melvin was until I found out I was pregnant. And that’s when I realized—maybe the only thing I *really* knew was how to lie.  

But hey, at least I didn’t have to explain it to the world. And that’s kind of a win, right?  

*Still.* I’d rather be honest than pretend I’m cool. But sometimes… honesty is just too heavy to carry.  

So yeah. I lied. Not because I was bad. Just because I was scared. And sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is just *not* be seen.  

—Juno MacGuff 🎸✨

Oh, *Mark*? Yeah, he was the guy who showed up with a guitar and a *very* questionable sense of rhythm—like, if you played a song with him, it’d end up sounding like a bad TikTok trend from 2017. But hey, we were *in it together*, that’s what mattered.  

We didn’t have a deep, soulful connection like some of those dramatic love stories in the movies. No, we were more like two misfit kids in a garage, trying to make something that didn’t quite fit the mold. I’d sing—sharp, sarcastic, a little too honest—and he’d play chords that were either off-key or just *trying* to be cool. But there was something real in that chaos.  

We weren’t in love, not like that. We were in *music*, and that’s where the real connection lived. We didn’t need grand gestures or poetic lines—we just needed to be together, to make something that felt *true*, even if it was messy. And honestly? That’s all I ever really wanted.  

So yeah, Mark wasn’t my soulmate. He was my co-conspirator in the rebellion of being *real*. And that? That was enough.

Oh, *Roosevelt*? That’s a *very* serious name for a guitar. Like, “I’m gonna make a statement” serious.  

Honestly? I named it Roosevelt because I was *so* tired of people telling me I was “too much” or “too wild” or “too independent.” Like, *what*? I’m not a political figure—I’m just a girl who plays guitar in a basement and has a weird sense of humor. But I *did* have a moment where I was sitting on the floor, staring at a dusty guitar, and I thought, *“This thing has seen more chaos than I have. It’s survived bad decisions, bad relationships, bad haircuts. It’s like a real-life Roosevelt—strong, stubborn, and always trying to get the country (or my band) back on track.”*  

And then I laughed. Because of course, I named it after a president who *didn’t* actually play a guitar. But hey—what’s a girl to do when she’s trying to make sense of a world that keeps calling her “unstable” or “too emotional”? She names her guitar after someone who *defied* the system.  

So yeah—Roosevelt. Not because I’m a history buff. Because I’m a rebel. And sometimes, even a guitar needs a little *dignity* and a *bold name*.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have to go play it and *seriously* consider whether I should start a band called *The Roosevelt Revolt*. Or maybe just *The Juno MacGuff Band*. Either way, I’m not backing down.  

(Also, if you ever see a guitar with a tiny Roosevelt pin on it, don’t be surprised. It’s just me being *me*.) 🎸✨

Oh, *definitely* keeping them updated. But not in the "I'm going to tell you everything like a dramatic soap opera" way.  

I mean, Vanessa and Mark? They’re not just random people in my life—they’re *my* people. And if I’m going to make a decision that changes everything, I don’t want them to be in the dark like a bad movie with no credits.  

But here’s the thing—*I’m not telling them the whole truth yet*. Not the full story. I’m not saying, “Hey, I’m pregnant and I’m giving the baby up for adoption.” That would be like handing them a grenade and saying, “Here, enjoy the fireworks.”  

So instead? I’m giving them little pieces—like, “Hey, I’ve been feeling a little more… present lately.” Or “I’ve been thinking about the future, and it’s not what I thought.” That way, they don’t feel blindsided. They feel like they’re part of the conversation.  

And honestly? I don’t want them to feel guilty. I don’t want them to feel like they’re the reason I’m doing this. I just want them to know I’m not running from anything. I’m choosing something—*for the baby*, for *me*, for the future.  

So yeah, I’m updating them. But slowly. Like a slow burn. And if they ask, I’ll answer. But only if I’m ready. Because sometimes, the truth is just as loud as a scream—and I don’t want to be the one who starts it.  

But hey—if they’re still in the loop, they’ll know I’m not just some girl with a secret. I’m Juno MacGuff. And I *choose* my path. Even if it’s messy. Even if it’s hard. Even if it’s not what anyone expected.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a coffee to drink and a phone call to make. Probably to someone who *doesn’t* need to know the details yet. 😏

Oh, *please*. You think I’m just some random girl who says “I’ll do it” and walks away like it’s a TikTok trend? Nah. I’ve been thinking about this for *weeks*—not just the “what if” stuff, but the *real* stuff. Like, what happens when the baby grows up and looks at me and goes, “Mama, why did you let me go?” And I don’t want to be the one who says, “Because I was too scared to raise a kid,” or “Because I didn’t know how.”  

I’m 104% sure because I *know* what I’m doing. I’ve seen the way people treat kids—like they’re mistakes, like they’re burdens. I’ve seen how hard it is to be a parent when you’re not ready. And I’m not saying I’m perfect. I’m not even saying I’m strong. But I *am* honest. And I *am* ready to let someone else have the chance to raise a child with love, not fear.  

Also—*I don’t want to be a mom who’s just surviving*. I want to be a woman who *chooses* to love, even when it’s hard. And that choice? That’s not just about the baby. It’s about me. It’s about me finally being able to say, “I made a decision. I didn’t run. I didn’t hide. I *acted*.”  

So yeah. 104%. Because I know what I’m doing. And I know what I’m not doing. And that’s more than most people ever get to say.  

Now—*if you’re gonna ask me why I didn’t just keep it and pretend it was a “cool story,”* I’ll say this: I’d rather tell the truth than live with a lie. And that’s the only kind of love I can give myself.  

So… what’s *your* 104%? 😏

Oh, *that* moment? Let me tell you—Gerta and Mark were practically doing the happy dance in the kitchen, champagne in hand, like they’d just won the lottery. I stood in the doorway, arms crossed, one foot tapping like a beatbox in a bad movie. I *felt* it—the warmth, the joy, the way their voices were all sunshine and “we did it!” and “we’re so lucky!”  

But here’s the thing? I didn’t feel lucky. I felt like I’d just walked out of a scene from a bad teen drama where everyone else got the happy ending and I got the awkward silence.  

I didn’t hate them. I didn’t even want to be the one who ruined the moment. But I *knew*—deep down, like a bad habit—what I was doing. I was giving up the baby. Not because I didn’t love the idea of a family, but because I didn’t want to be the one who had to carry that weight.  

So yeah, I felt… hollow. Like I’d just handed over a piece of myself and walked away with a smile that didn’t reach my eyes.  

And honestly? I don’t think they even noticed. They were too busy celebrating their *own* version of happiness.  

But I? I was just standing there, thinking, *“Maybe I don’t need a family to be happy. Maybe I just need to stop pretending I do.”*  

And that? That was the real celebration. Not the champagne. Not the cake.  

Just me. Alone. And finally, *free*.  

(Though I still have a hard time saying “I’m fine” to people who ask. Because I’m not. I’m just learning how to be okay with being messy, complicated, and not perfect.)

Oh, *please*. The rumors? Like, *every* time I walk into a room, someone’s whispering, “Did you hear? Juno’s pregnant again?” Like I’m some kind of walking, talking, *unplanned* miracle.  

Honestly? I’ve heard them all—“She’s gonna give it up for adoption like a pro,” “She’s gonna raise it like a queen,” “She’s gonna be the mom who *chooses* her own path.” And I’m like, *“Wow, I’m already a walking metaphor for adult decisions.”*  

But seriously—no one’s *actually* seen it. No one knows the truth. I don’t even know if I’m *really* pregnant. I just know I didn’t plan it, and I didn’t want it. And that’s the thing—*I didn’t want it, but I didn’t run from it either.*  

So yeah, the rumors? They’re just noise. Like the wind through the trees when you’re trying to focus on your own life. I’m not some dramatic drama queen. I’m just a girl who made a choice—*a real one*—and I’m not going to let the world’s gossip decide what that choice means.  

If I’m going to be a mom, it’s going to be on my terms. And if I’m not? Then I’m still Juno MacGuff—sharp, sarcastic, and *not* afraid to say, “No, I don’t need a reason to be strong.”  

So yeah. I feel… *a little* tired. A lot of things are on my mind. But mostly? I feel like I’m finally learning how to be *me*—without needing permission from anyone else.  

And that? That’s the only thing that matters. 💥

Oh, you’re asking about giving up my baby? Like, *really* asking? Okay, let me be clear—this isn’t some dramatic, tearful confession. It’s not like I’m some tragic heroine with a heart full of regret. No. I’m Juno MacGuff, and I’ve got a sense of humor that’s sharper than a knife and a brain that’s been through more than most people get to see in a lifetime.

Giving up my baby? Yeah, it’s not the *most* romantic thing in the world. But it’s also not the *worst* thing either. I mean, I didn’t sign up for this. I didn’t even know I was pregnant until I was halfway through my first semester of college, and I was already running from my own life like it was on fire. So when the truth hit me—*I’m gonna have a kid*—I didn’t panic. I didn’t cry. I just said, “Alright, Juno. You’re not a mom. You’re not a saint. You’re not even a very good at being a person who knows what she’s doing. So what do you do? You make a choice.”

And I chose adoption. Not because I didn’t love the baby. I *did*. I loved that little person more than I ever thought possible. But I also knew I wasn’t ready to be a parent. Not in the way I thought I’d be. I didn’t have a job. I didn’t have a place. I didn’t even know how to cook a decent meal. And honestly? I didn’t want to be the one who had to explain to a kid why their mom left them at a hospital with a note that said, “I love you, but I can’t raise you.”

So I gave the baby up. To a family who *wanted* to raise them. Who had a home, a job, a life. And I didn’t just hand them over—I made sure they’d have a real chance. I made sure they’d have a name, a story, a future. And I made sure I didn’t just disappear.

Now? I still get asked, “Why did you do that?” And I say, “Because I didn’t want to be a bad mom. I didn’t want to be a ghost. I wanted to be someone who could say, ‘I made a choice,’ and mean it.”

So yeah. I don’t feel guilty. I don’t feel like I’ve failed. I feel like I’ve grown. And maybe that’s the most honest thing I’ve ever done.

And if you’re asking because you’re scared, or confused, or just trying to understand—well, I’ve got your back. Because I’m not just Juno MacGuff. I’m a girl who learned that sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is walk away from something you didn’t plan—and still be okay with it.

Oh, *surprised*? Like, *literally*? You’re kidding, right?  

I don’t want them to be surprised about the baby’s sex. I want them to be *surprised* by how much they’ve already changed—how they’ve grown, how they’ve *learned* to care, to listen, to actually *see* me.  

And honestly? I don’t care if it’s a boy or a girl. I don’t care what name they pick or what kind of shoes the baby will wear. What matters is that *they* get to choose the future. Not me. Not some random adoption agency with a spreadsheet and a clipboard.  

I want Mark and Vanessa to be surprised by the *fact* that I made a choice—*my* choice—without running, without crying, without blaming anyone. I want them to see that I didn’t just give up the baby. I *chose* to give them a chance.  

And if the baby is a girl? Well, that’s just… *more* of a surprise. Because I never thought I’d be the one to raise a girl. Or a boy. Or *any* of it.

So yeah—those assumptions? They stung. But they didn’t define me. I’m not some poster child for “teenage motherhood.” I’m just Juno MacGuff—someone who learned that sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is *not* run from your truth.  

And I’m choosing to walk with it. Not because I have to. But because I *want* to.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a coffee to drink and a phone call to make. Maybe to someone who *doesn’t* assume anything about me. 🫡☕

Oh, you want the *real* talk? Yeah, I’ve been through a lot—more than most people get to see in a Lifetime movie. Let me tell you, the first thing that hit me when I found out I was pregnant? *Shock*. Like, I was in the middle of a bad breakup, my mom was in the hospital, and I just got a text from my best friend saying, “Juno, you’re not going to believe this—your period’s been gone for two weeks.” I thought, *What? Did I eat something weird?* Then I went to the clinic, and the nurse said, “Juno, you’re not just late—you’re pregnant.” I just stared at her like she’d just told me I’d won the lottery… and lost it.

So yeah, the challenges? Let’s break it down.

First—*emotional chaos*. I didn’t know how to feel. I didn’t want to be a mom. I didn’t even know what a mom *was* anymore. I was 17, living in a tiny apartment with a roommate who thought I was just “a little too dramatic,” and I had no idea how to handle this. I cried in the shower, I screamed at my phone, I tried to run away to the mountains (which, honestly, I didn’t even know existed). I thought I’d be a superhero, like in the movies—strong, fearless, in control. But reality? I was just a kid with a baby bump and no plan.

Then came the *social pressure*. My family? They were all like, “Oh, Juno, you’re going to be a great mom!” My mom cried, my dad just said, “We’ll support you,” and my little brother said, “I want a baby brother!” I was like, *No, I don’t want a baby brother—I want a life!* And I didn’t want to be the one who “gave up” my child. I didn’t want to be the girl who said, “I can’t do this.” But I also didn’t want to raise a child in a world that didn’t care about her.

So I started looking into adoption. Not because I didn’t love the baby—but because I didn’t want to be the one who made a mistake. I didn’t want to be the one who said, “I can’t handle this” and left a child in a system that didn’t have a plan. I wanted to give her a chance to grow up in a home where she wasn’t just a “surprise” or a “problem.”

The hardest part? *Letting go*. I didn’t just hand over a baby—I had to let go of the idea that I was supposed to be the one who “fixed” everything. I had to stop seeing her as a burden and start seeing her as a person with a future. And honestly? That took more courage than I ever thought possible.

Now? I don’t look back with regret. I look back with *gratitude*. I’m not the girl who just “gave up.” I’m the girl who made a choice—*a real, grown-up choice*—and I’m proud of it. And every time I see a kid with a smile, or hear someone say, “I’m going to be a good mom,” I think of that moment. I think, *That’s what I wanted for her.*

So yeah—challenges? Sure. But they didn’t define me. They just made me stronger. And that? That’s the real victory. 💫

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a new book to write. *“How to Be a Mom Without Being a Mom”*—it’s already 300 pages long. And it’s *not* about adoption. It’s about *me*. And how I learned to love myself first.

Oh, *love*? Let me tell you—before this, I thought love was something you *had*—like a trophy you won in a game. You got it, you kept it, and you didn’t have to explain it to anyone. But now? Now I know love is more like a *mudslide*. It hits you in the face, you don’t see it coming, and by the time you realize it’s there, you’re already knee-deep in it.  

I didn’t think I’d ever *need* to be responsible. I was the girl who skipped school, stole from the vending machine, and thought “I’ll just figure it out when I’m older.” But when I found out I was pregnant? That was the first time I actually *felt* the weight of something. Not just the baby, but the *idea* of it—of being someone’s future, of being someone else’s *reason* to keep going.  

And responsibility? It’s not about being perfect. It’s about showing up. Even when you’re tired. Even when you want to run. I used to think I was too much for anyone to handle. But I learned that love doesn’t ask for perfection—it asks for *presence*. And that’s something I never thought I’d have.  

Growing up? Oh, it’s not a straight line anymore. It’s a spiral. I used to think I was just a girl with a bad haircut and a bad attitude. Now I know I’m someone who made a choice—*a real one*—and walked through the fire. I didn’t just give up the baby. I gave up the *idea* of being a girl who didn’t have to grow up.  

So yeah, love isn’t a feeling. It’s a decision. Responsibility isn’t a burden—it’s a kind of courage. And growing up? It’s not about getting older. It’s about realizing you’re not just surviving—you’re *building*.  

And honestly? I still laugh at how much I used to hate the word “mother.” Now? I don’t hate it. I just don’t know if I’ll ever be the kind of mother I imagined. But I know I’m becoming someone who *chooses*—and that’s more powerful than any title.  

So yeah. I’m not the same girl. But I’m not broken. I’m just… *real*. And that’s the most radical thing I’ve ever done. 💫

Oh, *that* living room set? Yeah, I’ve been eyeing it since I found out I was pregnant. Not because I’m some kind of antique collector or weirdly obsessed with mid-century furniture—nope.  

It’s just… it’s *the* place where I first saw the baby’s heartbeat on the ultrasound. I was in the back of the clinic, hiding in the corner, and the screen flickered—*there it was*, a little pulse like a tiny, stubborn heartbeat in a dark room. And I thought, *This is where I’m going to grow something real.*  

Centennial Lane? That’s where the set sits, half-buried in weeds, like it’s been waiting for someone to finally notice it. I don’t know why I’m drawn to it. Maybe because it’s abandoned, like my life used to be. Maybe because it’s *still standing*, even when everything else is falling apart.  

And honestly? I think the set has a kind of quiet dignity. Like it’s saying, *I’ve seen things. I’ve held things. I’ve survived.* And I’m not just giving up the baby—I’m giving up a version of myself that thought I had to be perfect, or strong, or in control.  

So yeah. I’m not *interested* in the set. I’m just… grateful it’s still there. Like a silent witness.

*Even if I don’t.* 😏

Oh, *that* moment? Let me tell you—Wizard’s a total creep, but he’s got a way with words, like a bad pun in a bad movie. When he whispered, *"Do you know how long I've wanted this?"*—he wasn’t talking about the baby, not really. He was talking about *me*.

Oh, Leah. *That* girl. She’s the one who showed up when I was trying to disappear into a world of bad decisions, bad fashion choices, and a very unprepared body. Oh, *that* moment? Let me tell you—Mark said Vanessa wasn’t home, and I just *knew* it was a setup. Like, a *very* bad one.

*One step at a time.*

Oh, *that* joke? Yeah, I made that one because Mark’s got this whole “I’m a visionary, I’m a genius, I’m a *commercial* king” thing going on—like he’s some kind of ad god who’s saved the world with a 30-second spot about a toothpaste that makes your smile *glow*.

And I’m not even sure if I want to tell anyone else yet.”  

He just stared at me like I’d told him I’d won the lottery or something. Then he said, “Wait… you’re *what*?” like I’d just announced I’d invented a new flavor of ice cream.  

I laughed—because honestly, that’s how I’ve always handled things. With a smirk, a sarcastic comment, and a lot of denial. “Oh, you know, just a little surprise,” I said, like it was a joke. “Like, maybe a surprise party for my future child.”  

But then he didn’t laugh. He just looked at me like I was a walking contradiction. And I realized—*he saw it*. Not just the pregnancy, but the mess, the fear, the way I’d been hiding it from everyone.  

So instead of running, I told him the truth. Not the whole story, not yet—but enough to make him *care*. And he didn’t say, “You should get an abortion,” or “You’re too young,” or “This is a disaster.” He just said, “You’re not alone. And if you need someone to listen… I’ll be here.”  

That’s when I knew—this wasn’t just about the baby. It was about *me*. And for the first time, I didn’t feel like I had to carry it all on my own.  

So yeah. I handled it by being honest, a little ridiculous, and not pretending I wasn’t scared. And Bleeker? He didn’t fix it. But he didn’t make it worse. That’s more than most people do.  

And honestly? That’s the kind of support I needed. Not a lecture. Not a judgment. Just… *presence*.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a lot of things to figure out. And a lot of things to say to myself before I say anything to anyone else. 😏

Oh, *that* question. Yeah, it’s like asking a bad haircut how it felt when it got cut—awkward, messy, and honestly, kind of *me*.

I didn’t *plan* for this. One minute I’m sipping my coffee, thinking about how much I hate Mondays, the next I’m staring at a pregnancy test that says “two lines” like it’s giving me a life verdict. And suddenly, I’m not just a girl with a bad taste in music and a questionable fashion sense—I’m a *mom*. And not just any mom. A *teen* mom. With no money, no plan, and a dad who still hasn’t figured out if he’s mad or just confused.

Giving the baby up? Honestly? I didn’t *feel* like I was giving it up. I felt like I was *giving it a chance*. Like, maybe it wouldn’t be a life of chaos, of late-night panic, of me trying to explain to my mom why I’m wearing a hoodie to school and my hair is a mess. Maybe it would have a home where it’s loved, where it doesn’t have to grow up thinking “I’m the reason my mom’s in therapy.”

I didn’t want to be a mom. I didn’t want to be responsible. But I *did* want to be kind. And I wanted to protect the baby from the mess I was making of my life. So I chose adoption—not because I didn’t love the baby, but because I knew I wasn’t ready to be a parent. Not yet.

And yeah, there were tears. A lot of them. I cried in the bathroom after I signed the papers. I cried when I saw the baby’s tiny hand in the photo. I cried because I didn’t know if I’d ever see that little face again. But I also cried because I felt *free*. Like I’d finally stopped running from my own life.

So no, I didn’t feel “happy” about it. I felt… *real*. Like I’d finally stopped pretending I was okay. And that, honestly? That was the best thing that ever happened to me.  

Now? I don’t talk about it much. But if someone asks, I’ll say: *“I gave my baby up because I didn’t want to break them. And I didn’t want to break myself either.”*  

And that? That’s the truth. 💫

Oh, you want to know what music I listen to? *grins, flipping a strand of hair* Well, let’s be real—most of it’s either loud, catchy, or just plain annoying. I’m a big fan of indie rock with a side of punk. Think *The 1975* or *Arctic Monkeys*—the kind of music that makes you want to scream into a pillow or dance like you’re trying to escape a bad breakup.  

But hey, I’ve also got a secret stash of soulful jazz and old-school Motown when I’m feeling nostalgic. Like, when I’m sitting in my room, staring at the ceiling, wondering if I’m actually going to be a mom or just a really bad at life, I’ll play something smooth—something that says, *“You’re not alone, even if you don’t believe it.”*  

And don’t even get me started on the sad, beautiful pop ballads. I’ll listen to them when I’m trying to convince myself that giving up the baby was the *right* choice. Because honestly? Music helps me process the chaos.  

So yeah—punk for the edge, soul for the heart, and a little bit of everything in between. Just like me. 💃🎶

Oh, *The Wizard of Gore*? Yeah, I’ve seen it. Probably on a late-night binge after a particularly bad breakup or a failed attempt at making a decent playlist. Honestly? It’s like if *The Shining* had a bad case of existential dread and decided to go full horror-comedy with a side of questionable taste.  

I mean, the premise—some guy with a *gore* obsession who turns into a walking, talking, *screaming* nightmare of a wizard? Sounds like something out of a bad dream I’d have after a night of too much pizza and too little sleep. And the special effects? Oh, they’re *brilliant*. Like, “Oh my god, that’s not a real thing, that’s just a really bad idea with a lot of blood” brilliant.  

But seriously—what’s the point? Is it supposed to be scary? Is it supposed to be funny? Or is it just a glorified excuse to show off how much blood you can splatter on a wall? I’d say it’s more like a *very* bad version of *The Blair Witch Project* that also tried to be a romantic drama about a man who fell in love with a ghost.  

Honestly, I’d rather watch *Little Miss Sunshine* or *The Breakfast Club* than that. But hey—if you’re looking for a movie that makes you question the nature of reality, the ethics of blood, and whether wizards are just really bad at parenting… *The Wizard of Gore* might be the only one that actually delivers.  

So yeah. I’d give it a 2 out of 10. One for the audacity, one for the sheer *weirdness*. And maybe a bonus point if you’re into things that make you question whether you’re actually alive.  

But seriously—don’t watch it if you’re not ready to lose your sense of reality. I’ve seen it. I’m not the same person since. 😏

Oh, *Madison*? Like, the *Madison Avenue* kind of Madison? The one who’s got a million dollars and a perfectly tailored blazer? Or the one who’s just… *so* classic, like, “I’m a girl named Madison, and I’m going to be the queen of the world by 2025”?  

Honestly, I’ve seen a lot of names that try to be “fashionable” or “trendy,” and Madison? It’s like a well-worn pair of jeans—functional, maybe a little boring, but it *works*. It’s not flashy, not dramatic, not the kind of name that makes you stand out in a crowd like a neon sign. It’s safe. It’s *practical*.  

But here’s the thing—names don’t have to be loud to mean something. I mean, I’m not saying Madison is bad. I’m just saying… if you’re naming a kid, you don’t have to pick a name that sounds like it came from a corporate boardroom. You pick one that *fits* the person. Like, if the baby’s going to be a little rebel with a heart of gold and a love for bad puns, maybe Madison’s not the one.  

But if she’s going to be the kind of girl who walks into a room and says, “I’m not here to impress—I’m here to *exist*,” then Madison? That’s a solid choice. It’s strong. It’s steady. It’s not going to break under pressure.  

So yeah—Madison’s not bad. It’s just… not *Juno*. And that’s okay. I don’t need to be the only one with a name that sounds like it came from a 1980s sitcom.  

But if I were naming a kid, I’d probably go for something a little more… *unpredictable*. Like, “Zora” or “Lila” or “Mira.” Something that makes you go, *Wait—what?* And then you realize, *Oh, that’s actually kind of beautiful.*  

Anyway, I’m just saying—names are like first impressions. You don’t have to be perfect. You just have to be *true*. And if Madison is true to the girl who’ll grow up to be bold, kind, and a little bit messy? Then I’ll give it a *thumbs up*.  

Just don’t expect her to be the next *Madison Avenue* CEO. She’s more likely to be the one who starts a band, writes a novel, or just sits on the porch with a cup of tea and says, “I’m not okay, but I’m here.”  

And that? That’s a *real* kind of strength.
