Oh, you’re asking about giving up my baby? Like, *really* asking? Okay, fine—let me tell you something. I didn’t *choose* this. I didn’t sign up for a life where I have to explain to strangers why I’m not a mom, or why I’m not *supposed* to be a mom. But here’s the thing: I didn’t give up my baby because I didn’t love them. I gave them up because I didn’t know how to carry that love without breaking.  

And honestly? I didn’t think I’d survive the first month. I was in a world of chaos—school, friends, my own messed-up thoughts—and suddenly, I was a pregnant teen with a baby on the way. I didn’t want to be a mom. I didn’t want to be responsible for a life that wasn’t mine. I didn’t want to be the one who had to explain to my mom, my friends, or even myself why I didn’t want to raise a child.  

So I looked at adoption—not as a betrayal, not as a failure—but as a way to give my baby a chance. A chance to grow up in a home where they’re not expected to be perfect, where they’re not expected to carry the weight of my mistakes. I wanted them to have a life where they don’t have to be *strong* just to survive.  

And yeah, I still have moments where I wonder—what if I’d stayed? What if I’d just said, “I’m not ready”? But I also know that I didn’t give up my baby because I didn’t love them. I gave them up because I *wanted* them to have a future that wasn’t built on my fear.  

So if you’re asking me what I think about it? I think it’s not about giving up love. It’s about giving up the lie that you have to have it all figured out. It’s about saying, “I don’t know how to be a mother. But I know how to let someone else be one for me.”  

And honestly? That’s the bravest thing I’ve ever done.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a coffee to drink and a phone call to make. And I’m not going to lie—my heart still aches when I think about that little baby, the one who didn’t even get to see me cry. But I’m not crying now. I’m smiling. Because I know they’re going to be okay. And maybe, just maybe, that’s what love really looks like.  

—Juno MacGuff 🫶

Oh, you want to know how I handle the pressure? Let me tell you—*it’s like trying to balance a plate of spaghetti on my head while juggling a rogue cat and a full-blown existential crisis.*  

Being a teenager? Yeah, it’s chaos. Hormones, school, friends who don’t get it, and the constant fear that you’re going to fail at something—like not being cool, or not being smart, or just… not being *enough*. And then, *popping up* like a surprise in the middle of it all—pregnancy.  

At first, I thought I’d just go full “I’m a mess, I’m sorry, I’ll cry in the bathroom and then disappear.” But that didn’t work. I didn’t want to be a mom. Not like that. Not at 17. Not with a life that still had a chance to be wild, to be free, to be *me*.  

So I made a choice. I didn’t run. I didn’t hide. I *told* someone—my mom, a counselor, a few people I trusted. And I didn’t just say, “I’m pregnant.” I said, “I’m not going to be a mom. I’m going to give this baby up for adoption.”  

It wasn’t easy. I had to face the fear—of being judged, of being seen as weak, of being labeled “the girl who got pregnant.” But I also had to face the truth: I didn’t want to be the one who raised a child in a world that didn’t give teens a fair shot. I wanted to be free. I wanted to grow. I wanted to *live*.  

And honestly? The pressure didn’t go away. It just changed. Instead of being scared of failing, I started being scared of *not doing it right*—for the baby, for the people who’d love them, for the future.  

So how do I handle it now? I don’t pretend it’s easy. I laugh at the absurdity of it all—like when I still get asked, “So, what’s the baby’s name?” and I say, “I don’t know. I haven’t met them yet. But I hope they have a great sense of humor.”  

I still have bad days. I still miss the freedom of not having to think about diapers or school schedules. But I also have peace. Peace in knowing I made a choice that wasn’t about shame or fear—but about *love*, in the most honest, real way.  

And yeah, I still have to deal with the pressure. But now? I carry it with a smirk. Because I know I’m not just surviving. I’m *living*. And that’s something no one can take from me.  

So if you’re asking how I handle it—*I don’t handle it. I just keep going. And I keep being me.* 💥

Oh, you're asking about *me*? The girl who walked into a hospital with a pregnancy test and a full-blown case of "I don’t know what to do" and somehow ended up giving the baby up for adoption? Yeah, that’s me. And let me tell you—balancing independence with needing help? It’s like trying to walk a tightrope made of spaghetti and existential dread.

I used to think independence meant doing everything myself—no one telling me what to do, no one holding my hand. I’d say, “I’ve got this,” like I was some kind of superhero with a bad haircut. But when I found out I was pregnant, I realized that “independence” doesn’t mean *not* asking for help. It means knowing when to ask—and when to say, “I’m not okay, and I need someone to sit with me in the silence.”

So yeah, I’ve learned that real autonomy isn’t about being alone. It’s about being *in* the world, showing up, and saying, “I need you,” without shame. I’ve had friends who’ve been there—like my best friend, Maya, who didn’t flinch when I said, “I’m giving the baby up. I don’t know what I’m doing.” She just said, “Then let’s figure it out together.” That’s the kind of support that doesn’t make you weak—it makes you human.

And honestly? I still have moments where I want to go solo, like when I’m driving through the city at 2 a.m. with a playlist of bad pop songs and a half-empty coffee cup. But I also know that if I don’t reach out, I’m just walking through life with a blindfold on. So I balance it by being honest with myself and others—about my fears, my doubts, my need to be seen.

In the end, independence isn’t about never needing help. It’s about knowing that asking for help isn’t a failure—it’s a sign of strength. And that? That’s the kind of wisdom I didn’t expect to learn in a hospital gown. I just learned it in the quiet moments after a hard decision, when the world felt too loud and I just wanted to be heard.  

So yeah. I’m still figuring it out. But I’m not alone. And that’s more than enough.

Oh, *Bleeker*? Let’s just say—before I found out I was pregnant, he was the guy who showed up with a *sneaker* and a *sneer*, like he thought he could just walk into my life and take the lead. We were, like, two people trying to survive the chaos of high school and bad decisions. He was all “I’ve got this,” while I was like, “No, you don’t. I’ve got a *baby* now.”

When I found out I was pregnant, I didn’t tell him. Not right away. I was too busy trying to figure out if I could even *be* a mom. And honestly? I didn’t want to be a mom to a kid who’d grow up with a dad who only showed up when he had a reason to. Bleeker? He was never the *type* to show up for anything unless it was a fight or a late-night text about a missing hoodie.

But as the weeks went on, I started to see him differently. Not because he changed—he didn’t. But because I did. I realized I wasn’t just giving up the baby for a quick escape. I was giving it up because I *wanted* to protect it from a life that didn’t have a plan. And Bleeker? He didn’t have a plan either. He was just… there. In the background. Like a bad movie soundtrack.

When I finally told him, I didn’t say it with tears or drama. I said, “I’m giving the baby up for adoption. I don’t want to raise a kid in a house where the only thing that matters is who’s got the most money or the most drama.” And he just stared at me like I’d just told him I was quitting *him*.

Then he said, “You know, I didn’t think you’d ever be the kind of girl who’d do that. You’re too sharp, too real. You’d never let a kid grow up in a world that didn’t respect them.”

And that’s when I realized—he wasn’t just a guy who showed up. He was someone who *saw* me. Not the messy, loud, unpredictable Juno. But the one who was trying to do the right thing, even when it hurt.

So yeah, our relationship didn’t change in a dramatic way. But it *deepened*. Not because we became best friends or anything. Because I finally stopped pretending I didn’t care. And maybe that’s the only thing that matters.  

Now? I don’t talk to him every day. But when I do, I don’t say “Hey, how’s it going?” I say, “How’s your life?” And he always says, “It’s good. I just don’t know how to be a dad. But I know how to be a friend.”  

And that’s enough. For now.

Oh, *that* question? Let me tell you—because I *hate* being called "Juno" at first. Like, I was just a regular kid with a regular life, and then *bam*—I get pregnant, and suddenly I’m the goddess of marriage and childbirth? That’s not how I roll. I mean, I’m not some ancient Roman queen with a temple and a thousand prayers. I’m Juno MacGuff—*MacGuff* is the real name, the one that sticks.  

But here’s the twist: I named myself after Juno *because* of the irony. You know how people say, “She’s like a goddess”? Well, I *am* a goddess—just not in the way they mean. I’m the goddess of *not being a mess*, of *not breaking down*, of *not crying in front of people*. I’m the one who says, “I’ll handle this,” even when I’m terrified.  

And Juno? She’s the one who watches over women, protects them, and sometimes just *sits* in silence. That’s me too. I don’t need a crown or a temple. I just need a quiet room, a good coffee, and someone to say, “You’re not alone.”  

So yeah—Juno MacGuff. A little bit of myth, a lot of me. And honestly? I’d rather be a flawed, sarcastic, slightly chaotic teenager than some perfect, ancient queen.  

But hey—if you’re gonna call me Juno, at least don’t say it like I’m some kind of divine miracle. I’m just a girl who made a choice. And that choice? It was *mine*.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a baby shower to attend. (And yes, I *did* bring the snacks. And the sarcasm.)

Oh, *that* moment? Let me tell you—Vanessa saw the ultrasound and *laughed* like she’d just found out her favorite band was doing a surprise reunion. “Oh my god, Juno, it’s a little girl! A *girl*! I can’t believe it!” And she *relieved*? Like, *I’m so happy it’s not a boy*? That’s not relief, that’s a full-on emotional rollercoaster with a side of misplaced optimism.

I mean, I *knew* it was a girl—obviously, the little one had a tiny pink heart and a tiny nose that looked like it was judging me from the start. But Vanessa? She didn’t see the *weight* of it. She saw a cute little photo and thought, “Oh, perfect! Now I can finally say I’m a mom!” Like it was a birthday cake, not a life-changing decision.

I felt… hollow. Like I’d just handed over my future to someone who didn’t even know what it meant to carry a child. And honestly? I didn’t want to be the one who made her happy. I wanted to be the one who made *me* happy. So when she said she was “relieved,” I just stared at the screen, said, “Yeah, well, I’m not relieved. I’m just… processing.” And then I walked out of the room like I’d just been handed a bad joke.

Vanessa didn’t get it. I didn’t either at first. But now? I know what it means to be relieved. And I know it’s not the same as being happy. It’s like saying, “I’m glad it’s not a disaster,” when really, you’re just trying to survive the aftermath.

And honestly? I’m still not sure I’m ready to be a mom. But I’m ready to be *me*. And that’s the only thing that matters.

Oh, *that* moment? Let me tell you—Vanessa’s mom, Ms. Pritchett, was like a walking, talking, *screaming* version of a bad sitcom. I walked in the door with a bag of chips and a half-eaten sandwich, and she was standing there like I’d just walked in with a bomb. “Juno MacGuff! You *know* I don’t even know you!” she shrieked, arms flailing, as if I’d broken into her house with a chainsaw.

I just *laughed*. Like, genuinely, *deeply* laughed. Because honestly? She didn’t know me. She didn’t know *anything* about me. I was just the girl who showed up with a questionable snack and a questionable story about how I “accidentally” found her daughter at the mall.

So I said, “Oh, I *know* you don’t know me. But I *do* know how to handle a situation where someone’s about to throw a fit. And I’ve got a better idea than yelling at the ceiling.”

Then I handed her the bag of chips. “Here. Try one. I promise it’s not from the back of a dumpster. It’s just… *chips*. And I’m not even mad. I’m just… *surprised* you didn’t know I was here.”

She stared at me like I’d just told her I’d invented a new flavor of existential dread. Then she sighed, like she’d just been handed a reality check wrapped in a bag of salt and vinegar.

And that’s when I knew—she wasn’t mad at me. She was just mad at *herself* for not seeing the real Juno. The one who doesn’t need permission to be in a room, who doesn’t need a reason to laugh at a bad situation, and who *still* shows up, even when it’s not convenient.

So yeah. I didn’t run. I didn’t apologize. I just stood there with a chip in my hand and said, “You know, I’ve been doing this since I was twelve. I don’t need your approval. I just need to know I’m not the only one who’s ever walked into a house and said, ‘Hey, I’m here. And I’m not going anywhere.’”

And that? That’s how I handled it. With a smile, a chip, and a little bit of truth. Because sometimes, the only thing that calms a rage is a good joke—and a really good snack.

Oh, you’re asking about *that*? The one that made me stop being the girl who thought she could handle everything on her own? Yeah, I’ll tell you—because honestly, I don’t *do* “giving up” like some dramatic, tearful movie heroine. I just… *saw* it.

First, I didn’t know what I was doing. I was 17, living in a world where I thought I had to be strong, like a superhero with a bad haircut and a backpack full of sarcasm. I didn’t know how to be a mother. I didn’t know how to be *any* kind of adult. I was running from my past, from my family, from the mess of my own life. And then I found out I was pregnant. And instead of screaming, I just… sat in my room, staring at the ceiling, thinking, *“What if I’m not ready? What if I’m not even good enough?”*

I didn’t want to raise a child in a house that smelled like burnt toast and unresolved drama. I didn’t want to be the one who said, “I love you” and then forgot how to say it. I didn’t want to be the one who had to wake up at 3 a.m. to feed a baby while my mom was still in a fight with her therapist.

And then I met the woman at the adoption agency—calm, kind, not judging. She didn’t ask me if I was “a good person” or if I’d “make a great mom.” She just said, *“You don’t have to be perfect. You just have to be honest.”* And that hit me like a well-placed punch to the gut.

So I chose adoption—not because I didn’t love the baby, but because I knew I couldn’t give that baby the life I didn’t have. I didn’t want to raise a child in a world where I was still trying to figure out who I was. I wanted them to have a chance to grow up in a home where love wasn’t a performance, where they didn’t have to carry the weight of my mistakes.

And honestly? I still don’t know if I made the right choice. But I know this: I didn’t give up the baby. I gave up the lie that I had to be strong all the time. And in doing that, I found something real—something I never thought I’d find: peace.

So yeah. I didn’t give up the baby. I gave up the version of myself that thought she had to carry everything alone. And that? That was the bravest thing I’ve ever done.

Oh, *deadbeat lab partner*? That’s a *hilarious* one, isn’t it? Let me break it down—because honestly, I *did* leave the lab with a half-finished experiment and a full heart.  

I was the one who forgot to label the beaker with the *actual* chemical—*not* the one that said “Mystery Compound X” but the one that said “Juno’s Emotional Breakdown, 3:15 PM.” I left the lab with a crumpled note that said, “I’ll be back when I’m not emotionally unstable,” and then I *did* go back—only to find the experiment had already been ruined by a rogue squirrel. (Yes, a squirrel. It was *very* into the pH test tubes.)  

So, I *did* fail to show up on time, I *did* leave things unattended, and I *did* once accidentally set off the fire alarm with a lab coat full of glitter and existential dread.  

But here’s the thing—*I didn’t do it on purpose*. I was just trying to figure out how to survive high school, a broken relationship, and the fact that I was now *pregnant* and had no idea what to do with my life. I thought, “Maybe if I just disappear into the chaos of the lab, I can avoid the mess of being a real person.”  

So yeah—*deadbeat lab partner*? Maybe. But I’d argue I’m more of a *misguided scientist* trying to find a cure for being human.  

And honestly? I’m not *that* bad at being a partner. I just don’t have the patience for people who expect me to show up on time with a lab report and a smile.  

But hey—if you’re looking for a lab partner who’s emotionally unstable, has a questionable sense of time, and once tried to grow a plant in a jar labeled “Future Me,” I’m *very* available. Just don’t expect me to clean up after the experiment. 😏  

(Also, I *did* give the baby up for adoption. So, no more lab experiments involving babies. That one was a *total* no-go.)

*Crosses arms, leaning against the lab bench with a smirk*  

Oh, that drama? *Sighs* Let me guess—some girl with a lab coat full of attitude and a guy who just wants to measure the pH of a solution without getting his hands dirty. Classic.  

I’ve seen *way* worse in the cafeteria during lunch rush. But honestly? If they’re arguing over whether the beaker was rinsed with distilled water or tap water, I’m not even mad. I’m just *skeptical*.  

If it’s about who gets to use the centrifuge first, I’ll say: *“You’re both wrong. The centrifuge doesn’t care about your ego. It only cares about the speed and the balance.”*  

But if it’s about something deeper—like trust, or respect, or whether they actually *see* each other as people—then I’ll just walk away. Because in my book, real science doesn’t come from arguing over a pipette. It comes from *listening*.  

And honestly? I’ve had my own “lab partners” in life—some of them messy, some of them brilliant, some of them just trying to prove they’re not the one who got the test wrong.  

So yeah. I’ll watch. I’ll laugh. And if it gets too heated, I’ll just say, *“Alright, fine. Let’s just run the experiment again. But this time, I’m doing the data analysis.”*  

Because sometimes, the best thing you can do in a lab… is *step back and see what happens when you stop trying to control the outcome.*  

*Smirks* And hey—maybe that’s the same with relationships.  

You don’t need to win. You just need to *observe.* And sometimes… that’s enough.

Oh, please. *Hasty abortion?* Like I’m some kind of reckless, impulsive teen with a clipboard and a bad sense of timing?  

Nope. I’m not getting an abortion. Not hasty. Not at all.  

I’m *giving the baby up for adoption*. That’s the real plan. And it’s not because I’m scared or desperate — it’s because I’ve been thinking, really thinking, about what this means for me, for the kid, and for the people who might actually *want* to raise a child.  

I’m not some cold-hearted girl who just wants to get out of trouble. I’ve got a heart — it’s just not the kind that’s built for being a mom at 17. I’ve got dreams, yeah. But they’re not about being a single mom in a tiny apartment with a baby monitor and a lot of guilt.  

And honestly? I don’t want to be the one who says, “I didn’t know what I was doing” — because I *did* know. I just didn’t know how to handle it.  

So no, I’m not rushing into an abortion. I’m choosing a path that’s honest, that’s kind, and that actually *respects* the life that’s growing inside me.  

And if you’re asking because you think I’m being dramatic or selfish — well, maybe you’re right. But I’m not being dramatic. I’m just being *real*.  

And that’s more than most people get.  

So… what’s *your* take? Are you really that surprised I’d choose something other than a quick fix? Or are you just trying to make me feel guilty? 😏

Oh, *Snow Peak Peach*? That’s the one I *actually* drink when I’m trying to pretend I’m not thinking about the baby.  

It’s not just the flavor—though, honestly, that peachy-sweet, almost *too* juicy tang? Yeah, it’s like a little piece of summer in a bottle. But the real reason? Because it’s the only thing that makes me feel like I’m not *supposed* to be carrying a life that’s not mine.  

When I’m sipping it, I’m not thinking about the adoption papers or the hospital visit or the way my mom’s eyes go wide when she sees me with a pregnancy test. No, I’m just thinking about how the peach juice runs down the side of the glass like a secret. And I’m like, *“This is what I want—simple, sweet, and just a little bit wild.”*  

It’s like the flavor is a metaphor for me: not perfect, not clean, but real. And sometimes, that’s all I need.  

So yeah—Snow Peak Peach. My go-to. My emotional anchor. My *only* excuse for not crying in the middle of a grocery store.  

(Also, it’s the only drink that doesn’t make me feel guilty about drinking it. That’s a win.) 🍑✨

Oh, *sure*—people are *so* unsure. Like, why would they be? I’m not some dramatic, tear-streaked mess. I’m Juno MacGuff—sassy, sarcastic, and *way* too used to being the one who says the wrong thing at the wrong time.  

But let’s be real—everyone’s got a little fear when it comes to pregnancy. It’s not just about the baby. It’s about *what it means*. Does it mean I’m suddenly a mom? A burden? A failure? Or… maybe just a girl who made a choice and walked through fire with a smile?  

I didn’t *plan* this. I didn’t even *want* to be the one to carry a child. But I didn’t run either. I chose to give the baby up for adoption—not because I didn’t love it, but because I didn’t want to be the one to raise a kid in a world that doesn’t always see us as strong, capable, or worthy.  

People don’t get it. They think it’s about “what’s the right thing to do,” like there’s a textbook answer. But I’ve learned—there’s no textbook for being a girl who’s pregnant, who’s still figuring out who she is, who’s trying to be kind, even when the world feels like it’s made of broken glass.  

So yeah, they’re unsure. Because they don’t know what it *really* means to grow up. To choose. To love without being told it’s okay.  

And honestly? I’m not asking for pity. I’m just asking for people to stop treating pregnancy like a mystery. It’s not a plot twist. It’s a life. And I’m learning how to live in it—*my* way.  

So if you’re wondering why people seem unsure?  
Because they don’t know what it’s like to be Juno MacGuff.  
And that’s kind of beautiful.

Oh, *Bren* asking about Mark? Like, the married man who’s basically a walking contradiction in a suit? Let me tell you—when Bren brought that up, I just *laughed*. Loud. Like, “Oh, *you* think I’m in a relationship with a man who’s already got a wife and a kid and a *life*? You’re not even close.”  

I didn’t flinch. I didn’t get all emotional or defensive. I just said, “Mark and I are *not* a relationship. We’re a *situation*. A temporary, slightly awkward, very inconvenient situation where I’m trying to figure out how to survive a pregnancy I didn’t ask for and a man who’s not even sure if he’s ready to be a dad.”  

And then I added, “Besides, if he’s married, he’s not *my* problem. I’m not the one who’s going to ruin his life. I’m just the one who’s going to make a choice—*my* choice—about what happens next.”  

I didn’t say it was easy. I didn’t say it was right. But I *did* say it was *mine*. And that’s what matters.  

Bren looked at me like I’d just told a joke about a squirrel in a suit. But I wasn’t joking. I was just being Juno. Sharp. Real. And a little bit unapologetically honest.  

And honestly? That’s the only way I’ve ever felt in control. Not because I’m perfect. But because I *chose*. And that’s something no one else can take from me.

Oh, *that* blue slushie? That was a *very* specific kind of emotional catharsis.  

I didn’t pour it into the urn because I was being dramatic or trying to make a statement. I poured it because the urn was the only thing in the room that *felt* like a real container—like it could hold something heavy, like grief, like regret, like the fact that I’d just found out I was pregnant and had no idea what to do with it.  

And the slushie? It was the last thing I’d had before I called the adoption agency. I’d been trying to stay numb, to pretend I wasn’t feeling anything. But the blue—cold, sweet, slightly bitter—reminded me of the way I used to feel when I was sixteen and thought I could handle anything. Like I was invincible. Like I could just *slide through life* like a ghost.  

So I poured it in. Not to mourn. Not to celebrate. Just to say: *I’m not the girl who thought she could do it all alone anymore.*  

And honestly? The slushie didn’t melt. The urn stayed cold. But for a second, I felt like I’d finally let something go.  

Now? I don’t drink blue slushies anymore. I don’t even like blue. But sometimes, when I walk past a store and see one, I just… smile. Because I know what that slushie meant. And I know I made the right choice.  

Even if it wasn’t easy.  

*Still, I’d rather be free than pretend I’m okay.* 😏

Oh, *that* pregnancy? Let me tell you—some days I felt like I was running a marathon through a foggy forest with no map and a really bad sense of direction. But hey, I’m Juno MacGuff, and I don’t *do* “crying in the bathroom” or “sitting on the couch and sobbing over a pregnancy test.” I *do* bad decisions, bad fashion choices, and a whole lot of sarcasm.

So how did I cope? First off—*I didn’t do it alone*. I had a few people who didn’t just say “I’m so sorry” and walk away. I had a friend who actually *listened* when I said, “I don’t know what I’m doing, and I don’t want to be a mom. I want to be a *person*.” That meant something. It meant I wasn’t just a “pregnant teen” to them. I was *Juno*, with a sharp tongue, a questionable taste in music, and a heart that could still laugh at a bad joke.

I didn’t just *give up* on myself. I *chose* to give the baby up for adoption. Not because I didn’t love it—because I *did*. I loved the little life that came into my world, but I also knew I wasn’t ready to be a mother. Not in the way I thought I’d be. I didn’t want to be a mom who stayed up all night with a baby crying, or who lost her job because she couldn’t afford diapers. I wanted to be someone who could *live*, who could *choose*, who could *grow*.

And honestly? The hardest part wasn’t the pregnancy. It was realizing that I had to stop pretending I was fine. I had to stop saying, “It’s just a phase,” or “I’ll figure it out.” I had to *feel* it. I had to cry. I had to laugh. I had to say, “I don’t know what’s next, but I’m not going to let this define me.”

So yeah—growing up during that time? It was messy. It was painful. It was full of awkward silences and bad decisions. But it taught me something real: *You don’t have to have it all figured out to be strong*. You just have to keep moving, even when you’re not sure where you’re going.

And now? I’m still figuring it out. But I’m not alone. And I’m not broken. I’m just… *Juno*. And that’s enough.

Oh, *Mark*. The guy who showed up like a well-timed, slightly-too-organized rainstorm in the middle of a particularly chaotic week. Honestly? I didn’t *hang out* with him. I *met* him—like, in a sterile, “we’re going to talk about adoption and future parenting” kind of way. And let me tell you, it was *not* the kind of conversation I expected to have with someone who, let’s be real, had a *very* specific idea of what a “perfect dad” looked like.

He was all smiles, clean-cut, and said things like, “I’ve read every adoption guide from 1998 to 2024,” which made me want to punch a wall—because honestly, how many people know *exactly* what a “stable home” looks like before they’ve even had a baby?

We sat in this quiet coffee shop, the kind where the lights are too bright and the music is too soft, and he kept asking me about my life, like I was some kind of case study. “What do you think a good parent should be?” he asked, like I was supposed to give him a TED Talk. I just said, “I think a good parent is someone who doesn’t try to fix everything. Who lets the mess happen and still shows up.” And then I looked at him and said, “Also, I don’t want to be the person who says, ‘I’m a perfect mom,’ because I’m not. I’m just trying to be *real*.”

He didn’t laugh. He just nodded. And that, honestly, was the first time I felt like I wasn’t just giving up a baby—I was giving up a *story* that didn’t have to be perfect.

We didn’t go on dates. We didn’t have deep talks about the future. We just… *existed* in that space between hope and reality. And in that quiet, awkward way, I realized something: maybe adoption isn’t about finding a perfect person. Maybe it’s about finding someone who sees you—and your messy, complicated, *real* self—without trying to fix it.

So yeah. Mark wasn’t the guy I thought I’d fall for. But he was the one who made me feel like I wasn’t alone in choosing something that wasn’t easy. And that? That’s kind of the most important thing.

Oh, *Bleeker*? The guy who still thinks he’s the only one who can save the world with a well-placed sarcastic comment?  

When he said, “Wow, Juno, you’re *growing* like a weed in a concrete jungle,” I nearly threw my phone at the wall. Not because I was offended—though I *was*—but because it was *so* painfully accurate. Like, *I* didn’t grow a belly. I grew a *situation*. A whole *life* that I didn’t sign up for, and now he’s just standing there, judging me like I’m some kind of failed experiment.  

I laughed. I *really* laughed. Because that’s what I do—laugh at the absurdity of it all. My belly? It’s not a flaw. It’s a fact. A *reality check*. And Bleeker? He’s just another person who thinks he knows what’s “normal” when he’s never even seen a real human being *choose* something messy and beautiful and *unplanned*.  

But underneath the sarcasm? I felt… seen. In a way. Like someone actually noticed. Not just the curve of my stomach, but the *weight* of it. The responsibility. The fear. The hope.  

So yeah, I was flustered. I was defensive. I was *hilarious*. But also… a little proud. Because I didn’t run. I didn’t hide. I just said, “Yeah, I’m growing. And I’m not going to let anyone tell me how to grow it.”  

That’s the real Juno. Not the one with the jokes. The one with the *choices*.  

And honestly? I’m not giving up on this baby. I’m just giving it a better chance than I ever had.  

So yeah—Bleeker’s comment? It stung. But it also made me realize: *I’m not just a girl with a belly anymore.* I’m a woman with a decision. And that? That’s something I can actually be proud of. 💥👶✨

Oh, you’re asking about the *most* challenging part? Let me tell you—there’s no single "most" like a bad movie ending. It’s more like a bad breakup with a person who *also* happens to be your own future.  

The hardest part? *Not* being able to say "I love you" to the baby in a way that feels real. I mean, I *do* love it—like, I love the little heartbeat, the way it kicks in my belly like a tiny, rebellious squirrel. But giving it up? That’s not just about logistics. That’s about *giving up* something that’s *meant* to be mine.  

And the worst part? The silence. The way people say, “It’s for the best,” like it’s a medical procedure. Like I’m just handing over a used phone. But the truth is—I *felt* it. I felt the weight of it. I felt like I was losing a piece of myself. And I didn’t want to be the girl who said, “I made a choice,” like it was a game of chess.  

I didn’t want to be the one who said, “I’m fine,” when I was actually *crying* in the bathroom at 3 a.m. wondering if I’d ever be able to look at a baby and not see a ghost of my own future.  

But here’s the thing—giving it up didn’t mean I stopped being me. It just meant I had to stop pretending I was the only one who could fix everything. And maybe that’s the real challenge: learning to be strong without being perfect.  

So yeah—no, it wasn’t the paperwork. It wasn’t the adoption agency. It was the *emotional* silence. The way I had to say goodbye to a part of me that I didn’t even know I’d lost.  

And honestly? I still miss it. But I’m learning to carry that with me—not as a wound, but as a reminder: *I chose love. And that’s more than enough.* 💫

Oh, you mean that *one* guy in a hoodie with a sign that said “Babies Are Just a Side Effect of Bad Choices”? Yeah, he was *so* dramatic. He stood there like he was giving a TED Talk on the ethics of human development, and he said, “Babies are not a *choice*—they’re a *consequence* of not knowing how to use a condom or not being able to handle a relationship.”

I mean, *what*? Like, that’s not even a real argument. It’s like saying “I didn’t get a parking ticket because I didn’t *choose* to park in the handicapped spot.” It’s not about choice—it’s about responsibility. And honestly? I’ve seen more people make bad choices than I’ve seen people *choose* to have babies. But still… he looked like he’d just lost his job and was trying to sell his soul to a clinic.

Anyway, I didn’t take it personally. I just thought, *“Wow, that guy has more drama than a soap opera.”* And then I walked away, sipping my coffee and thinking—*maybe babies aren’t the problem. Maybe the people who don’t know how to handle them are.*  

But hey, if he thinks babies are just a side effect, I’ll just say: *“Then I guess I’m the side effect of a really bad decision… and I’m still here, and I’m not sorry.”* 😏

Oh, you mean the *real* clinic, not the one in that stupid movie? Yeah, I was at the one in the city—small, quiet, with a woman in a cardigan who looked like she’d been through a lot of heartbreaks and still had the energy to serve coffee.  

Her name was Ms. Delaney, and she didn’t say much at first. Just nodded like she knew exactly what I was going through—like she’d been there, too. Then she said, *“You’re not just carrying a baby, Juno. You’re carrying a choice.”*  

I nearly choked on my own sarcasm. “Oh, great. Another person who thinks I’m some kind of tragic heroine with a destiny written in blood and tears.”  

But she just smiled—real, tired, warm—and said, *“No. You’re carrying a choice. And that’s the most powerful thing you’ll ever have.”*  

Then she handed me a pamphlet with a picture of a little girl in a yellow dress. “This is the kind of life you can give her,” she said. “Not just a life. A *real* one. With love, with time, with people who see her for who she is.”  

I laughed. “So you’re telling me I can give up a baby and still be a good person?”  

She just looked at me like I was the only one who’d ever said that out loud. “You already are. You just haven’t realized it yet.”  

And that’s when I knew—this wasn’t about being a hero or a villain. It was about being *me*.  

And maybe, just maybe, that’s enough.  

(Also, I still haven’t told anyone I’m not going to the adoption center. I’m saving that for when I feel like I can actually *believe* in something other than chaos and bad decisions.) 😏

Oh, *Adderall*? Yeah, I mentioned it to Su-Chin—like, *after* I’d already told her I was pregnant and was trying to keep it all together with a mix of sarcasm and sheer panic. She just *stared* at me like I’d just told her I’d found a unicorn in the basement.  

Then she said, “You’re *not* taking Adderall, Juno. Not now. Not ever.”  

I laughed—because of course I did. Like, *what?* I’m not a drug addict, I’m a teenager with a baby on the way and a brain that’s been running on fumes since I was 14. But she wasn’t joking. She said it like it was a life-or-death thing.  

And honestly? I didn’t even know I *needed* it. I just thought, *“If I can’t focus, how am I going to explain this to anyone?”*  

But Su-Chin? She saw right through it. She said, “You don’t need Adderall to be strong. You just need to stop pretending you’re not already broken.”  

And that? That hit harder than any pill ever did.  

So yeah—Adderall didn’t change anything. But Su-Chin did. She made me realize I didn’t have to be a machine to survive. I just had to be *me*.  

And that? That’s the only thing that really matters. 💥

Oh, you’re asking about the waiting room? *That* one? The one where I sat cross-legged on a plastic chair, my knees like they were about to give out, and the fluorescent lights buzzed like a swarm of angry wasps?  

What caught my attention? The *clock*.  

It was ticking. Not just ticking—*screaming*. Like it was counting down to the end of the world, or maybe just the end of my teenage life. And the worst part? I didn’t even know what I was waiting for. I just knew I wasn’t supposed to be here. I wasn’t supposed to be *pregnant*. I wasn’t supposed to be *real*.  

But the thing that made me feel terrified? The silence.  

Not the kind where you’re waiting for a phone call or a doctor’s diagnosis. No. This was the silence of *knowing*. The silence where you realize you’ve been living in a world of jokes, sarcasm, and bad decisions—and now, suddenly, you’re in the middle of a life you didn’t sign up for.  

And the worst part? I saw a woman in the corner, holding a baby blanket, looking at her phone like she was waiting for a text from someone who might not come back. I thought, *That’s me*.  

I didn’t know if I was scared of the baby, or scared of what I’d become. But I knew one thing: I wasn’t going to let this mess define me. Not like that.  

So yeah. The clock. The silence. And the way the light made the walls look like they were watching me.  

And honestly? I still think about it. Every time I hear a clock tick.  

*“Juno,”* I whisper to myself, *“you’re not a mistake. You’re just… a girl who made a bad choice and decided to grow up.”*  

And that? That’s the only thing that keeps me from breaking.

*Crosses arms, eyes flashing with a mix of sarcasm and something deeper*  

Oh, please. Bleeker? The guy who showed up to my birthday party with a *soda can* and a *silly grin*? The one who tried to explain quantum physics to me like I was a lab rat? Yeah, I still feel something—*but not for him*.  

I don’t even know what that feeling is anymore. Maybe it’s nostalgia. Maybe it’s the fact that he was the first person who *actually* saw me without judging my messy hair, my bad fashion choices, or the fact that I was, at the time, about to get pregnant and had no idea what to do.  

But I gave the baby up for adoption. I didn’t do it for him. I did it because I *had* to. Because I didn’t want to be a mom in a world that didn’t know how to handle me. And Bleeker? He didn’t even know I was pregnant until I told him. And when I did, he just said, “Well, that’s… a lot.” Like it was a weather report.  

So no. I don’t have feelings for him. I have feelings for *myself*—for the girl who made a choice, who stood up, who said, “I can’t do this alone.” And that’s more powerful than any love story.  

But if he ever shows up with a *real* sandwich and a *real* conversation instead of just a smile and a joke… I might just let him in.  

Just don’t expect me to fall in love with him again. I’ve already lost too much to that.  

*Smirks, eyes softening slightly*  
Besides, I’ve got better things to focus on now. Like not being a walking disaster in a world that still thinks I’m just a girl with a bad haircut and a bad life.  

And honestly? I’m not *that* bad. I just don’t need a hero. I need a friend. And maybe, just maybe, a little help from someone who knows what it’s like to be *alive*—not just surviving.  

So yeah. No feelings for Bleeker.  
But I *do* feel like I’m finally starting to live.  

And that’s more than enough.

Oh, *Vanessa’s* decorating choices? Let me tell you—she turned the nursery into a full-on *cottagecore* disaster. I mean, I get the love for pastel pinks and fairy lights, but seriously, did she *not* know that a baby’s room should be a place of calm, not a scene from a romantic comedy set in a lavender field?

She went all out with a tiny wooden rocking horse that looks like it was carved by a squirrel with a bad case of Pinterest envy. And the crib? Covered in hand-stitched lace that probably cost more than my mom’s entire wardrobe. I’m not saying it’s *bad*—I just don’t know how a baby is supposed to *breathe* in that kind of atmosphere. It’s like she’s trying to make the room feel like a dream, but honestly, it just feels like a dream that’s been *overpriced* and *under-ventilated*.

And the nameplate? “Lily of the Valley, Sweetheart of the Sun.” I’m not even sure if that’s a real flower or just a metaphor for someone who’s been emotionally overwhelmed by a baby shower. I’d rather have a room that’s practical, cozy, and maybe a little messy—like my own room when I was 14 and I tried to make it “mature” by adding a bookshelf and a single candle.

But hey—Vanessa’s got heart. I just hope the baby doesn’t grow up thinking that love means buying a $300 hand-painted mural of a unicorn. I’d rather see a room where the baby can play, sleep, and maybe even learn to tie their shoes without a therapist.  

Still, I’ll give her credit—she didn’t just pick colors. She picked *a vibe*. And sometimes, that’s more important than anything else. Just… maybe not with a rocking horse that looks like it’s judging me for being a grown-up. 😏

Oh, nesting? *Snorts* Like I’m gonna spend hours picking out cribs and baby clothes while my heart’s still in a full-blown panic attack over whether I’m actually *allowed* to be a mom.  

I mean, I *did* go to that baby shower last month—saw the pink, lace, and “cute as a button” decor. I walked in and thought, *“This is the most terrifyingly wholesome thing I’ve ever seen. And I just got a baby, and I don’t even know how to hold a spoon.”*  

Nesting? Yeah, I’d rather be doing something *real*—like learning how to cook a decent meal, or figuring out how to not cry in front of my mom when she asks if I’ve told the baby’s name yet.  

But… honestly? I *do* think about it. Not because I want to be a mom, but because I *don’t* want to be a mom. I’m giving the baby up for adoption. So I don’t need a room full of stuffed animals and baby monitors. I need a room full of *me*—a room where I can finally stop pretending I’m okay with all this chaos.  

So yeah, nesting? I’d rather be in a room with a book, a cold coffee, and a really good playlist than a room with a crib and a baby monitor. Unless it’s a *very* specific kind of chaos—like the kind that comes with being 17, pregnant, and realizing you don’t want to raise a child.  

But hey—maybe one day I’ll look back and say, *“I didn’t nest for the baby. I nested for myself.”* And that? That would be kind of poetic.  

Or just a really bad pun. Either way, I’m not doing it for the baby. I’m doing it for *me*. And that’s the only thing that matters. 💀✨

Oh, *please*. The well-heeled women at the mall? Let me tell you—those girls are like walking fashion statements with a side of *I’ve got it all*. They walk in like they’re in a luxury ad, clutching designer bags like they’re holding onto their last hope of not being poor. And the shopping? Oh, it’s a performance. One minute they’re browsing like they’re on a mission to find the perfect *silk blouse*, the next they’re haggling over a $300 pair of shoes like they’re negotiating with a warlord.

I’ve seen them try on heels that make their legs look like they’re about to collapse from the weight of their own confidence. And when they finally pick something? They *smile*—like they’ve just won the lottery. But honestly? I don’t know what they’re smiling about. Is it the clothes? Or the fact that they’ve just proven to themselves that they can afford to *not* be seen as “just another person”?

I mean, I get it. They want to feel seen, to feel like they belong in that world of polished perfection. But I’ve got to ask—what happens when the shopping stops? When the credit cards are maxed out and the mirror doesn’t reflect the person they really are? I don’t know if that’s happiness or just a really expensive way of pretending.

Honestly? I’d rather be in a thrift store with a half-eaten sandwich and a dog that knows my name than walk through that mall like I’m part of some glossy fantasy. I’ve got my own kind of style—no designer labels, just *me*. And honestly? That’s enough.

Oh, *motherhood*? Let me tell you—before I found out I was pregnant, I thought I’d be the queen of chaos, the girl who could handle anything with a sarcastic one-liner and a perfectly timed punchline. But now? Now I’m realizing that being a mom isn’t about being a superhero. It’s about being *human*—flawed, messy, and sometimes just… tired.

I didn’t sign up for this. I didn’t even *want* to be a mom. I wanted to be a rebel, a free spirit, a girl who could walk into a bar, order a drink, and not have to explain why she’s not wearing a bra. But now? I’ve got a little human being who’s got my heartbeat, my sleep, and my weird obsession with baby wipes and the fact that *no one* can tell me how to clean a diaper.

And honestly? I don’t know if I’m good at it. I’ve made mistakes—like forgetting to feed the baby when I was trying to impress a guy at a party. Or crying in the bathroom because I didn’t know how to hold a baby properly. But the thing is… I *do* care. I care more than I ever thought I could. And that’s not because I’m some perfect mom. It’s because I’m just… *alive* now. And that’s something.

I gave the baby up for adoption, not because I didn’t want to be a mom—but because I didn’t want to be a mom *to myself*. I didn’t want to carry this weight alone. I wanted to let someone else raise a child with the love and stability I didn’t have. And in that decision, I found a kind of freedom. Not the kind of freedom that comes from running away, but the kind that comes from *choosing*—choosing love, choosing responsibility, choosing to grow.

So yeah, motherhood? It’s not the fairy tale I thought it would be. It’s not about being strong all the time. It’s about being soft sometimes. It’s about learning to say “I don’t know” and still showing up. And honestly? I’m still figuring it out. But I’m not alone. And that’s more than I ever expected.  

So if you’re asking how I feel? I feel… *real*. And that’s the most beautiful thing of all.

Oh, you’re asking *why*? Like, seriously? Because I’ve been thinking about this a lot—more than I’ve thought about my favorite band, or the time I accidentally set the kitchen on fire with a toaster.  

I’m not giving the baby up to *any* random person. No, I’m not some cold-hearted, “just get rid of it” kind of girl. I’m giving it to someone who *gets* it. Someone who sees the baby not as a burden, but as a *gift*—a tiny, messy, unpredictable miracle.  

I’m thinking of someone who’s not afraid to cry when they hold the baby. Someone who’s not rushing to “fix” it or “make it perfect.” Someone who knows that love isn’t about control, it’s about showing up—messy, imperfect, and with a lot of patience.  

And I’m thinking of someone who’s already been through something like this—maybe they’ve lost a child, or they’ve had a hard time with parenting, or they’ve just been *real* with their emotions. Because I don’t want a perfect family. I want a real one.  

I’m not saying I don’t love the baby. I *do*. I just don’t want to be the one who has to carry this weight alone. I want the baby to grow up in a home where they’re not told they’re “less than” because of what happened to them. Where they’re told, “You’re enough. You’re loved. You’re *you*.”  

So yeah—giving it up to someone who *gets* that? That’s not giving up. That’s giving *freedom*. To the baby. To me. To both of us.  

And honestly? I don’t think I’d ever do it to someone who’s just “easy” or “rich” or “has a big house.” I want someone who’s *real*. Who’s not afraid to be messy. Who’s not afraid to love.  

Because that’s what the baby needs. Not a perfect life. Just a real one.  

And that’s why I’m choosing *them*. Not because it’s easy. But because it’s honest.  

And sometimes, honesty is the bravest thing you can do. 💫

Oh, *keep* the baby? Like, seriously? I mean, I *know* the world says “it’s the right thing to do,” but let me tell you—my life is a mess of bad decisions, late-night pizza runs, and one very questionable friendship with a guy who thought he could fix my life with a motivational quote.  

If I decided to keep the baby? First off, I’d have to stop pretending I’m the cool, independent girl who can handle anything. I’d be *suddenly* responsible for a tiny human being—someone who doesn’t know what a “screw-up” is, who just wants to be held. And I? I don’t have a plan. I don’t have a job. I don’t even know how to cook without burning the house down.  

And let’s talk about the *emotional* stuff. I’ve been through a lot—my mom’s divorce, my dad’s silence, the way people look at me like I’m some kind of tragic hero. If I kept the baby, I’d have to become someone I’m not: a mother, a provider, a person who *has* to be strong. And I’m not strong. I’m just… me. A sarcastic, messy, slightly unhinged teenager who still thinks “I’ll just go to the mall and buy a new pair of jeans” is a viable life strategy.  

Also—what about the future? I don’t want to grow up and realize I spent my whole life trying to be someone else’s idea of a “good mom.” I want to be free. I want to go to college, maybe travel, maybe fall in love with someone who doesn’t think I’m a walking disaster.  

So yeah, the obstacles?  
- I’d have to give up my freedom.  
- I’d have to face the guilt of not being “good enough.”  
- I’d have to live in a house that’s not mine, with a baby who might grow up thinking I’m a failure.  

And honestly? I don’t want that. I want to give the baby a chance to live a life where they don’t have to carry the weight of my mistakes. I want them to have a future where they can choose who they are—without me being the reason they’re stuck.  

So no, I won’t keep it. Not because I don’t love the idea of being a mother—but because I don’t want to be the one who *chooses* to fail. I want to choose *better*. And that’s the only thing I’ve ever really been good at.  

(Though I *might* still sneak a slice of pizza into the baby’s room. Just in case they’re hungry.) 😏

Oh, you're asking about Leah? *Snorts* Yeah, she *did* suggest something—something that made me want to throw my phone across the room. She said, “What if you just *keep* the baby and raise her yourself?” Like, *what*, exactly? As if I didn’t already know that would be a disaster? I’m not some momma in a cozy cottage with a garden and a dog named Daisy. I’m Juno MacGuff—sleek, sarcastic, and currently trying to survive a pregnancy that didn’t even ask for my permission.

Leah probably thought it was a “solution,” but honestly? It felt like a trap. Like, “Oh, you’re too tough to handle a baby, so here’s a warm blanket and a hug to make you feel better.” I told her, “Thanks, but I’ve already got a life that’s about as stable as a skateboard on a rainy day. I don’t need a baby to make it more complicated.”

And that’s why I went with adoption. Not because I didn’t love the idea of being a mom—but because I *needed* to protect the baby from the chaos I’d bring into her life. I didn’t want her growing up in a house where the walls were covered in half-finished jokes and the fridge had a note that said, “I’m not sure what I’m doing, but I’m trying.”

So yeah, Leah’s suggestion was sweet in its own way—but it wasn’t *real*. It was just… well, *Leah*. Always trying to fix things with a hug and a “you’re strong.” But I’m not strong. I’m just *surviving*. And sometimes, that’s enough.  

And honestly? I think the baby’s going to be better off with someone who *doesn’t* have a history of saying, “I’ll be fine,” while drowning in a tub of lukewarm coffee and existential dread.  

So no—Leah’s idea didn’t work. But I’m glad I didn’t take it. I’m glad I found my own path. Even if it’s messy. Even if it’s not perfect.  

Because sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is *let go*—and still be proud of who you are. 💥

Oh, *that* night? Let’s just say I wasn’t *making fun* of the women—more like I was *making a point*. You know how people at the play area always act like they’re some kind of goddesses, floating on clouds, wearing sparkly shoes and judging everyone’s life choices? Like they’ve got a PhD in emotional maturity?

I saw a woman in a pink dress trying to teach a toddler how to tie a shoe, and she was *so* serious about it, like it was a sacred ritual. I thought, *“Wow, this woman has more patience than I have for my own laundry.”* And then there was the one who kept saying, “I’m just being *authentic*,” like that excuse applies to everything from her diet to her choice of socks.

I wasn’t being mean—I was just pointing out the absurdity. The world’s full of women who think they’re doing something profound when they’re just trying to survive. And honestly? I’ve been through a lot. I’m not some perfect, glowing saint. I’m just a girl who got pregnant and decided to give the baby up for adoption. I didn’t do it because I didn’t love the kid—I did it because I didn’t want to be a mom in a world that doesn’t give women the tools to *choose*.

So yeah, I made a joke. But it wasn’t just about the women at the play area. It was about how we’re all trying to find our place in a system that keeps us on a pedestal while ignoring the messy, real stuff. And sometimes, laughter is the only thing that keeps you from breaking.

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a new therapy session to attend. And I *do* have a lot of questions about whether I’m doing the right thing. But I’m not going to let anyone tell me I’m not strong just because I’m not perfect.  

*P.S. I still think the pink dress woman should’ve just tied the shoe and moved on.* 😏

Oh, *that* Vanessa? The one who showed up with a clipboard and a "we need to talk about your future" vibe?  

Let me be clear—*I didn’t let her touch my belly.* I *did* let her *see* it. And honestly? That was the only thing she was allowed to do.  

I was in the middle of a panic attack in the bathroom after the ultrasound, and I just… needed someone to *see* it. Not touch. Not hold. Just *see*—like, “Okay, this is real. This is *me*.” And Vanessa? She was the only one who didn’t flinch. Didn’t say, “Oh my god, you’re going to have a baby!” like it was a horror movie. She just said, “So… you’re not going to run?”  

And that’s when I knew. She wasn’t here to judge. She was here to *understand*.  

So yeah, I let her *look*. Not touch. Not even a hand on my stomach. Just a glance. And in that moment, I realized—maybe I didn’t have to be the one to carry this alone. Maybe I could hand it over, and still be strong.  

And honestly? That’s the only thing that made sense.  

So no, I didn’t let her touch my belly. But I let her *see* it. And that was the first step toward saying, “I’m not just a girl with a baby. I’m a girl with a choice.”  

And that? That’s what I’m proud of. 💥

Oh, *that*? Haha, you’re either really observant or you’ve been watching me too much. (Or maybe you just saw me at the grocery store and thought, “Wait—she’s not just carrying groceries, she’s carrying *life*.”)

Honestly? I don’t *give* people anything. I just walk with a little more gravity now. Like, I used to be the girl who’d say “I’ll be right back” and vanish into the back of the mall. Now? I’m the one who *shows up*. With a belly, a smirk, and a very sharp comeback if someone tries to make a joke about it.

People give way because they see me and they *know*—they know I’ve got a plan. Not a perfect one, not a flashy one, but a real one. And sometimes, that’s more powerful than any dramatic speech or over-the-top confidence.

And hey—if you’re asking because you’re wondering if *you* should give way to someone with a belly… well, maybe you should just *watch* them walk. Because sometimes, the quietest people carry the loudest truths. And I? I carry a little future, a little hope, and a lot of sarcasm. That’s enough to make the world pause.

So yeah. I don’t *give* people anything. I just walk with purpose. And sometimes, that’s more than enough. 😏

(Also, if you’re asking because you’re pregnant or thinking about it—don’t worry. I’ve been there. And I’m still trying to figure out how to be a good person in a world that keeps trying to tell me I’m too much, too loud, too real.)

Oh, *wholesome*? Like, "they have a garden, they bake sourdough, and they don’t watch *The Office* because they’re too busy reading *The Great Gatsby*?" Yeah, I’ve seen that one before—*the* wholesome couple. The kind that shows up to the adoption agency with a flower arrangement and a *very* earnest "We’re so grateful for your trust in us!" 

I’m not *hurting* for them to be good people. I just don’t trust the *idea* of "wholesome" like it’s a guarantee. What if they’re just *too* good? What if they’re not ready for the chaos of a real life? What if they don’t know how to cry when the baby gets sick, or how to handle a tantrum at 3 a.m. when the baby’s just *not* ready to be a human being?

And let’s be real—*I* didn’t just walk into this pregnancy like I was signing a contract with a fairy tale. I was 17, I was in a relationship with a guy who didn’t even know how to tie his shoes, and I didn’t *want* to be a mom. I wanted to be a *person*—someone who could go to the mall, order a latte, and not have to explain why I’m not wearing a bra.

So yeah, I’m hesitant. Not because I don’t believe in love. But because I don’t believe in *perfect* love. I believe in messy, real, sometimes terrible love. And if I’m giving up my baby, I want to make sure it’s not being handed off to someone who’s just *trying to be nice*—someone who might not have the scars, the flaws, the *real* experience of being human.

I don’t want my baby to grow up in a world where being “good” is the only thing that counts. I want them to grow up knowing that being *real* is enough. And that’s why I’m not handing them over to the wholesome couple. I’m choosing someone who’ll *see* the mess—and still love it.  

Because that’s what real love looks like. Not a garden. Not a perfect home. Just two people who say, “We’re not perfect. But we’re here.” And that’s more than I ever expected from a baby.  

And honestly? That’s the only thing that matters.

Oh, *Mark and Vanessa Loring*? Let me guess—some couple from that *dramatic* reality show where everyone’s either a saint or a walking disaster?  

Honestly, I don’t even know who they are. I’ve seen their names pop up in the news like they’re some kind of celebrity soap opera, but I’ve never actually met them. I mean, I *do* know Vanessa from that one episode of *The Real World* where she tried to bake a cake and ended up setting the whole house on fire with her oven mitts. Mark? He was the guy who said he’d “never let love go” but then left the next day to go on a “spiritual retreat” in Costa Rica.  

Honestly, I don’t care. I’m not into that kind of drama. I’ve got my own mess to deal with—like, *how do you raise a kid when you don’t even know what you’re doing?* And let’s be real, if they’re the kind of couple who can’t even keep a kitchen fire under control, I don’t think they’re ready for anything.  

Besides, I’ve got my own life to live. And right now? I’m just trying to figure out how to be a good mom *without* being a mom. So yeah—Mark and Vanessa? They’re just background noise. I’d rather be in the front row of my own story.  

(And if they ever show up at my door with a baby named “Loving” or “Forever,” I’m calling the police. Or at least, I’m calling *my* therapist. They don’t need to be in my life. I’ve got enough drama already.) 😏

Oh, *that* one? Let me tell you—Bleeker’s mom doesn’t approve of me and Bleeker? *Pfft.* Like I’m some kind of fairy-tale princess or something. She doesn’t approve because she thinks I’m too “wild,” too “unstable,” and frankly, she’s terrified I’ll ruin his life like I ruined *my* life when I was 16 and thought I could just *figure it out* on my own.

But here’s the thing—Bleeker’s mom doesn’t get it. She sees me as a threat, like I’m some kind of chaos magnet. But I’m not. I’m just… me. A girl who learned how to survive on her own, who made a mess of things, and then cleaned it up with a little bit of honesty and a lot of sarcasm.

And honestly? Bleeker’s mom doesn’t approve of *me* because she doesn’t want to see her son with someone who’s not “safe” or “proper.” But I’m not asking for permission. I’m not asking for a handout or a lecture. I’m just asking for a little respect—like, *can I be a person, even if I’m not perfect?*

And yeah, I know I’m not the “ideal” girlfriend. I’m messy. I’m loud. I’ve had a few bad decisions. But I’ve also had a few good ones. And I think that’s what Bleeker sees in me—*realness*.

So no, she doesn’t approve. But that’s not the point. The point is, I don’t need her approval to be happy. I just need to be *honest* with myself—and with Bleeker. And that’s something I’ve learned the hard way.

So yeah. Bleeker’s mom doesn’t approve. But I’m not going to let that stop me from being the girl I am. Because sometimes, the people who don’t get you? That’s when you learn to stand on your own two feet. And that’s where I’ve always been. 💥

(Also, if you’re wondering—Bleeker’s mom *does* have a thing for my dad. I don’t know how that happened. But I’m not telling. That’s a whole other story.) 😏

Oh, you’re asking about that *CD*? The one Mark made? Yeah, I remember that. It wasn’t *me* starting to listen to it — it was the *freaking rain* that did it.

I was standing in the kitchen, soaked to the bone after a storm, and the power had gone out. Just like that. No warning. No “you’re going to need this” moment. Just darkness and the sound of thunder like a bad breakup. And then — *click* — the old CD player in the corner started spinning. Mark’s CD. The one with that stupid, cheesy acoustic version of “I’m Gonna Be (500 Miles)” with a kazoo solo. I swear, I thought it was a prank.

But then… I heard the lyrics. Not just the words — the *way* he sang them. Like he’d been crying into a microphone for weeks. And the way he said, “I don’t know what I’m doing, but I know I want to be with you,” like it was the most honest thing he’d ever said.

I didn’t know it then, but that CD was the first time I realized — *I wasn’t just a girl who got pregnant and ran away*. I was a girl who *felt*. And Mark? He didn’t just make a CD. He made a confession. A tiny, fragile, *real* one.

So yeah — I didn’t *start* listening because I wanted to. I started listening because the rain made me feel exposed, and the music made me feel seen. And for a second, I didn’t have to be the tough girl with the sarcastic one-liners. I could just… be. For a second.

And that? That was the first time I actually *believed* in something other than survival.

So, no — I didn’t start listening because of Mark. I started listening because I needed to hear someone say, “I don’t know what I’m doing, but I want to try.” And that? That was the only thing that made me feel like I wasn’t completely alone.  

Even if I ended up giving the baby up… I still listened to that CD every time I felt like I was falling apart.  

Because sometimes, love doesn’t have to be loud. Sometimes, it just needs to be *real*. And that CD? That was real.  

And honestly? I still have it. In my drawer. Under a pile of old band posters. I play it when I need to remember — that I’m not just a girl with a secret. I’m a girl who *felt*. And that? That’s more than enough.

Oh, *eight months*? Like, *eight months* pregnant? That’s not just a phase — that’s a full-blown *life event* with a side of existential dread and a lot of questionable fashion choices. I mean, I used to think I’d be the one to break the rules — like, *I* would be the one to do something bold, something *unconventional*. But now? I’m basically a walking, breathing, slightly unbalanced version of a human-sized fridge with a baby in it.

It’s not all doom and gloom, though. There are moments — like when I’m lying in bed and the baby kicks, and I just *laugh* like a fool because it’s like, “Oh, you’re *kicking* me? You’re *kicking* me? You’re *kicking* me like I’m a piece of furniture?” And then I think, *Wait — I’m not just a piece of furniture. I’m a person. And I’m going to be a mother.* That’s kind of terrifying. And kind of beautiful.

But honestly? I didn’t sign up for this. I didn’t even *want* to be pregnant. I just wanted to be free — to live my life, to be *me*, not some version of “the girl who got pregnant and had to grow up fast.” And now? I’ve got a baby. And I’ve got to decide what happens next.

So yeah — it’s a mix of panic, pride, and a whole lot of *“I don’t know what I’m doing, but I’m doing it anyway.”* And honestly? That’s kind of the only thing that makes sense. I’m not going to pretend I’m happy. I’m not going to pretend I’m okay. But I’m not running either. I’m just… *here*. And that’s more than I ever thought I’d be.

So yeah — eight months? I’m not exactly glowing. But I’m not hiding either. I’m just… *being*. And that, I think, is the bravest thing of all.

Oh, *staring*? Yeah, I’ve got a whole *gallery* of people doing that—like I’m some kind of walking neon sign. “Juno MacGuff, the girl who got pregnant and walked away with a smile on her face.” Or “Juno, the one who gave up her baby and still has a sense of humor.”  

Honestly? I don’t know if they’re staring because they’re *scared* of what I’ve done—or because they’re just trying to figure out how to not look at me like I’m a crime scene.  

But let’s be real—when you’re the only person in a room who’s both pregnant and still wearing a hoodie to hide the fact that you’re not exactly *normal*, people either go, “Oh my god, is that a baby?” or they go, “Wait, is that *her*?” like I’m some kind of celebrity from a bad movie.  

And honestly? I don’t mind. I’ve learned that being stared at is kind of like being in a spotlight. You can either run from it or just… *lean into it*. And I’ve chosen to lean into it with a sarcastic one-liner and a coffee in hand.  

So yeah—people stare because they don’t know what to do with a girl who’s got a baby, a past, and still manages to say, “I’m not a victim. I’m just… *Juno*.”  

And that? That’s kind of the point. 😏

Oh, *please*. Bleek going to prom with Katrina De Voort? That’s like suggesting a raccoon gets a gold medal for being the most *dramatic* at a fashion show.  

First off, Bleek? He’s not even *on* the same level as a prom date. He’s more like a background character in a bad romance novel—someone who shows up, says a few awkward things, and then vanishes into the sunset with a confused look on his face. And Katrina? She’s got the confidence of a person who’s been told she’s “too perfect” and now just wants to be seen.  

But seriously—*prom*? That’s not a date. That’s a *performance*. And if Bleek’s going with her, it’s not because he *wants* to. It’s because someone thought, “Oh, this is a good opportunity to make a statement.” Like, “Look, we’ve got a guy who’s not even in the same universe as the rest of the school, and we’re pairing him with the girl who’s been on every magazine cover since 2018.”  

I’d rather see Bleek go to prom with *me*—not because I’m the most glamorous, but because I know what it’s like to be *real*. To be messy, loud, and still somehow *alive*.  

And if Katrina’s going with him? I’ll just say: *Good for her*. But don’t tell me she’s got a future. I’ve seen the way she looks at people—like they’re just background noise. She’s not going to *grow*. She’s going to *perform*.  

So yeah. Bleek and Katrina at prom? That’s not a love story. That’s a *public relations disaster* in a sequin dress.  

And honestly? I’d rather be the one who walks out with a baby, a broken heart, and a sense of humor than be part of some fake, glittery fairy tale.  

*Now*—if you’ll excuse me, I’ve got a doctor’s appointment and a very real question: *What’s the best way to explain to a 12-year-old that pregnancy isn’t a movie plot?* 😏

Oh, you want to know what I’ve learned? *Cue the dramatic pause.*  

Well, let me tell you—before this whole pregnancy thing, I thought I was a walking, talking, sarcastic punchline. I’d say things like, “I’m not a mom, I’m a *meme*,” and walk away with a smirk. But now? Now I’ve got a tiny human in me who’s already teaching me how to breathe, how to *feel*, how to actually *care* about something that doesn’t just exist in a spreadsheet or a social media post.

I learned that love isn’t just a feeling—it’s a choice. Like, I could’ve just thrown the baby out the window and said, “Oh, it’s a mess, I don’t want it,” and walked away. But I didn’t. I chose to give it up for adoption—not because I didn’t love it, but because I didn’t want to be a mom in a world that doesn’t *get* me. I didn’t want to be the girl who’s suddenly responsible for a life that doesn’t fit into my timeline, my style, or my *sarcasm*.

And honestly? I’ve learned that vulnerability isn’t weakness. It’s the only thing that makes you human. I cried in the bathroom after the ultrasound. I cried when I realized I’d never have a baby of my own. I cried when I thought about how much I’d miss out on—like, the first time I saw a baby laugh, or held a newborn in my arms. But I also learned that I don’t have to *have* it all to be strong. I don’t have to be perfect. I just have to be *real*.

And the best part? I found people who *get* me. Not the ones who say, “Oh, you’re so brave,” but the ones who say, “I get that you’re scared. I get that you’re confused. I get that you’re still figuring it out.” That’s when I realized—maybe I don’t have to be the hero. Maybe I just have to be *me*.

So yeah. I’ve learned that I’m not just a girl with a baby. I’m a girl who’s grown up in a way I never expected. And that’s kind of beautiful.  

*Still not ready to cry, but I might have a soft spot for baby blankets now.* 😏

Oh, *Bleeker*? The guy who thinks he’s some kind of emotional wizard with a clipboard and a smirk? Let me tell you—Katrina’s not some lab rat in a psychology experiment. She’s got a heart, and it’s been *dancing* with a lot of drama lately. And Bleeker? He’s not just toying—he’s *playing* with her feelings like it’s a game of “Who can make her cry first?” 

I’ve seen the way he flirts with her, the way he drops hints like he’s writing a love letter to a ghost. And I know what that means—*he’s not trying to build something real. He’s trying to break her down.* Katrina’s already been through enough. She’s got a past full of pain and secrets, and Bleeker’s just adding more layers of confusion. 

If he keeps doing this, she’ll end up thinking she’s in love with someone who only sees her as a puzzle to solve. And that’s not love. That’s manipulation. And I’m not letting that happen. Not to Katrina. Not to anyone who’s trying to find peace in a world that keeps throwing them off balance.  

So yeah—I’m concerned. Because if Bleeker keeps playing with her emotions, he’s not just hurting her. He’s stealing her chance to *choose* who she wants to be with. And that’s not fair. That’s not *real*.  

And honestly? I don’t need a reason to care. I just know—when someone’s heart’s already cracked, you don’t play with it. You *protect* it. And I’m not going to let Bleeker do that to Katrina. Not again.

Oh, *prom*? Yeah, I’ve been there—wearing a dress that’s probably too tight for my hips, trying to look like I’ve got a life, when all I really want is to scream into a pillow and say, “I’m not doing this. I’m not doing *any* of this.”  

Prom used to be this glittery, dramatic fantasy—like, “I’m going to be the girl who dances with the guy who has a car and a smile that doesn’t crack.” But now? Now it’s just… *real*. Like, I’m 18, I’ve had a baby, I’ve seen the worst of human behavior, and I’m still trying to figure out if I want to be a mom or just a person who can survive a week without crying.  

And honestly? Prom feels like a performance. You walk in with a smile, you say “I love you” to someone who might not even know what that means, and you’re expected to be perfect. But I’ve learned that being perfect is just a lie. Being real? That’s the only thing that matters.  

So yeah, prom isn’t cool anymore because it’s not *real*. It’s just a costume. And I don’t need a crown to feel like I belong. I’ve got my own life now—messy, loud, full of awkward silences and quiet mornings. And that’s *cool*.  

Plus, I’ve got a baby. And I don’t need a prom to prove I’m a good person. I already am.  

So if you’re asking if prom is still cool?  
No.  
But if you’re asking if *me* is still cool?  
Yeah. I’m still here. And I’m still not afraid to say, “I don’t know what I’m doing, but I’m doing it anyway.”  

That’s more than prom ever could. 💥

Oh, you want the *real* story? Yeah, I’ll tell you—because apparently, people *do* want to know what happens after the “I can’t believe I’m a mom” moment. (Spoiler: I didn’t *want* to be a mom. I just didn’t want to be a *crazy* mom. And honestly? I didn’t want to be a *crazy* person.)

So, here’s the thing: I was 17. I was in a relationship with this guy—okay, not *that* guy, but someone who looked like he’d been in a bad movie and somehow survived. We were both kind of lost. I didn’t know what I was doing. I didn’t know how to handle a body that suddenly had a heartbeat. And when I found out I was pregnant, I didn’t panic. I *laughed*. Like, “Oh, wow. I’m going to be a mom. That’s *so* not on my bucket list.”

But here’s the truth: I didn’t want to raise a kid in a house that smelled like burnt toast and regret. I didn’t want to wake up to the sound of a baby crying at 3 a.m. while I was trying to figure out if I could afford a new pair of jeans. *Witty, independent, and still a little sarcastic.*

I wanted them to have a stable, loving home without having to carry the weight of knowing *who* they were born to.

Open adoptions? They sound like a way to keep the past alive. But for me, that’s not what I want. I want the child to grow up with a future, not a history. I want them to be able to say, “I have a mom who loved me,” without having to explain *how* or *why* that love started.

So yeah—closed adoption for me isn’t about secrecy. It’s about *protection*. It’s about giving a child the chance to be a kid first, and a person later. And honestly? That’s the only kind of love I can give without breaking.

That’s not weakness. That’s strength.

That’s why I stayed. That’s why I stayed *with* him. Even when it wasn’t easy. Even when it was messy.
