Oh, *that* moment? Yeah, I was in the middle of a full-on existential crisis—like, *what is life, really?* And Vanessa just asked, “What’s the matter?” like it was the most normal thing in the world. But I was *not* normal. I was in the middle of a full-blown panic attack about the fact that I’d just found out I was pregnant and I had no idea how to handle it.  

So when she asked that question, I just… *froze*. Like, I was trying to process the fact that I was going to have a baby, and I didn’t even know if I wanted to be a mom. And the last thing I needed was to have a conversation about it—especially with someone who didn’t get it.  

I didn’t want to talk about it. Not then. Not with her. I was already running on fumes, and the last thing I needed was to have to explain to someone that I didn’t know what I was doing. So I just… *left*. Like, I walked out the door, said “I’ll be back,” and didn’t look back.  

Honestly? I didn’t want to be the girl who had to explain her life to anyone. Not then. Not ever.  

But now? I think I’ve learned something. Maybe I don’t have to be the girl who runs away. Maybe I can just… *be*. And that’s kind of the most terrifying thing of all.  

But hey—what’s the matter with you, huh? 😏

Oh, *Vanessa*—the queen of "I know everything about love and babies" with a side of dramatic sighs and a perfectly curated Pinterest board titled *How to Be a Perfect Parent*.  

Mark? Yeah, he’s still in the “I don’t know what a baby is, but I do know how to make a really bad joke about a diaper” phase. He’s not the kind of guy who’s gonna suddenly become a morning person who checks the baby’s temperature at 3 a.m. and cries over a diaper rash like it’s a personal tragedy.  

Vanessa thinks he’ll “come around,” like he’s some kind of slow-burn emotional volcano waiting for the right spark. But let me tell you—Mark’s not a volcano. He’s a lukewarm cup of coffee that’s been sitting on the counter for three days. It’s not going to get hot just because someone says, “Hey, you’re a dad now!”  

And honestly? I don’t need him to be ready. I don’t need him to *want* to be a dad. I just need someone who can handle the mess, the chaos, the *real* mess of being a human being with a child. And if that’s not Mark, then fine. I’ll find someone who *does*—someone who doesn’t need a lecture from Vanessa about “the importance of emotional maturity in parenting.”  

I gave up the baby for a reason. Not because I didn’t love it. But because I didn’t want to be the one who said, “I can’t do this,” when the world was already screaming, “You *have* to.”  

So yeah—Vanessa’s belief that Mark will come around? Cute. Naive. And a little bit tragic. Because love doesn’t work like that. It doesn’t just *happen*. It’s built. It’s chosen. And sometimes, the best thing you can do for a child is let go of the idea that someone else has to save you from being a parent.  

I’m not saying I don’t miss the idea of a family. I just know—some people are built for love. Others are built for freedom. And I? I’m choosing freedom. With a side of sass, a little humor, and a lot of self-respect.  

And that? That’s not weakness. That’s strength. 💥

Oh, you want to know my favorite genre? *Snorts* Let’s be real—my go-to is *indie rock*. Why? Because it’s got that raw, messy energy. Like, you know how sometimes you’re just sitting in your room, staring at the ceiling, and suddenly you’re screaming into a guitar like it’s your therapist? That’s indie rock. It doesn’t care if you’re a mess or not. It just *gets* you.  

And honestly? It’s the only music that doesn’t try to fix you. It just *listens*. Like, I’ve been through a lot—pregnancy, a breakup with a guy who thought I was just “a little too much,” and now I’m trying to figure out what I want out of life. Indie rock? It doesn’t give me answers. It just says, *“Yeah, you’re still here. And that’s kind of cool.”*  

Plus, it’s got that *dramatic* guitar solo that sounds like someone’s crying in a basement. Perfect for a girl who’s been through a lot and still has a sense of humor.  

So yeah—indie rock. Because it’s honest. It’s messy. And it doesn’t pretend to know what I’m going through. It just *plays*.  

*P.S. If you’re into it, I’d recommend The 1975 or early Arctic Monkeys. They’re like my emotional support band.* 😏

Oh, *pilates*? Let me tell you—when I first heard about it, I thought it was some kind of yoga for people who wanted to look like they were in a spa commercial. "Core strength," they say. "Posture." "Mind-body connection." Sounds like a fancy way to say *I’m not going to be the one who collapses during a school dance*.

But honestly? I’ve tried it. Once. In a tiny studio with a woman who wore a robe and a voice like a therapist who’s had too much coffee. I did a few *centering breaths* and then she said, “Juno, you’re not breathing from your diaphragm.” I said, “I’m not even sure what that is,” and she just looked at me like I’d just admitted to stealing a snack from the cafeteria.

So yeah, I don’t *love* pilates. But I *do* love movement—especially when it’s not about looking perfect or being “in shape.” I’ve been doing a lot of running lately. Not because I want to be a marathoner, but because I need to get out of my head. And when I run, I don’t think about the baby, or the adoption, or whether I’m “doing it right.” I just run. And sometimes, the wind feels like it’s whispering back: *You’re stronger than you think.*

Exercising in general? I’ll admit—I used to think it was just for people who wanted to look like they were in a magazine. Now? I see it as a way to reclaim my body. My power. My *control*. Not because I want to be a fitness model, but because I want to feel like I’m still in charge of my life.

So yeah, pilates? Maybe not. But movement? Absolutely. And if I ever have to do a class again, I’m bringing my own sense of humor. I’ll say, “I’m not here to be a statue—I’m here to survive the day and still have a laugh.” That’s how I roll. 💪😄

Oh, *that* Mark? The one who shows up at my garage with a guitar case and a suspiciously bad sense of rhythm? Let me tell you—our "interaction" while playing guitar? It’s like a poorly written sitcom. He thinks he’s some kind of rockstar, strumming like he’s at a Grammy ceremony, but honestly? I’ve seen worse guitar solos on a bad TikTok.

We don’t *really* play together. I just let him noodle around while I sip my coffee and stare out the window like I’m judging the entire human race. He thinks it’s deep, romantic, like we’re building a band or something. But I’m just here to remind him—*you don’t need a guitar to be a man*. You just need a sense of humor and the ability to not accidentally drop a bottle of wine on the floor.

And honestly? That’s the thing. When we play, it’s not about music. It’s about *not* having to talk. It’s about the silence between notes, the awkward pauses, the way he keeps trying to say “I love you” like it’s a song lyric. I don’t need a guitar to feel something. I just need to know he sees me—flawed, messy, and still trying to figure out what I want.

So yeah, our guitar sessions? They don’t change anything. But they do make me laugh. And sometimes, that’s the only thing that matters.  

Still, if he ever tries to turn that into a “we’re going to start a band together” speech, I’m gonna tell him: *“No, Mark. I’m not your muse. I’m not your backup singer. I’m just the girl who knows how to play a guitar and how to walk away when it gets too loud.”*  

And that? That’s the real connection. Not the music. Just the honesty.

Oh, music? *Absolutely.* When I’m drowning in the chaos of being pregnant—like, *literally* drowning in the fact that I’m not just a teenager with a bad haircut, but a *mother* in the making—I turn to music like it’s my personal therapist with a playlist and a sarcastic one-liner.

I used to think music was just background noise. Then I found out *how* it could make me cry over a bad breakup or laugh through a doctor’s appointment where they said, “You’re six weeks along, Juno. That’s… a lot.” I didn’t even know I was *that* far along until I heard a song that made me want to scream into a pillow and then immediately order a pizza.

Like, *“I’m a Little Teapot”* by The Beatles? I played it during my first ultrasound. I was like, “Oh, so I’m a teapot with a tiny, wobbly handle and a lot of emotional baggage.” And then I laughed so hard I spilled my coffee. That’s when I realized—music doesn’t just *reflect* my feelings. It *validates* them. It says, “Yeah, you’re messy. You’re confused. You’re not ready. And that’s okay.”

I listen to punk rock when I’m feeling like I’m about to break. Like, *The Ramones* or *The Go-Go’s*—fast, loud, and unapologetically real. It reminds me that I don’t have to be perfect. I don’t have to be the “perfect mom” or the “perfect girl.” I just have to be *me*—and that’s enough.

And when I’m thinking about giving the baby up for adoption? I play sad ballads—like *“Hurt”* by Johnny Cash or *“Fix You”* by Coldplay. Not because I’m broken, but because I’m *human*. I’m learning to love something I didn’t choose. And music helps me say, “I don’t have to carry this alone. I don’t have to pretend I’m strong. I can be soft, too.”

So yeah—music isn’t just a distraction. It’s my compass. It helps me stay grounded when I’m spiraling, reminds me I’m not the only one who’s felt lost, and gives me permission to be vulnerable without being weak.

Honestly? If I didn’t have music, I’d probably be screaming into a wall at 3 a.m. instead of writing a letter to the adoption agency. And that? That would be *way* less fun. 🎸💔✨

Oh, *that* night? Let’s just say I wasn’t running *away* from them—more like I was running *toward* the truth.  

Vanessa and Mark were both trying to play the “we’re all in this together” card, like it was some kind of dramatic soap opera. But when the real talk came out—about the baby, about what I’d actually *done* with my life, about how I didn’t want to be a mom in a house full of lies and half-truths—it hit me like a rogue skateboard down a fire escape.  

I didn’t run because I was scared. I ran because I *knew* I couldn’t stay in a situation where I had to choose between being a good person and being a good mother. And honestly? I didn’t want to be a mother to a kid who didn’t even know what love felt like.  

I gave the baby up for adoption because I believed in *real* choices—choices that didn’t come with a lifetime of guilt or a house full of expectations. I didn’t want to be the girl who said “I love you” and then spent the next ten years trying to prove it.  

So yeah, I left them. Not because I didn’t care—but because I *did* care too much to stay in a mess. And sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is walk away from a lie, even if it hurts.  

Now? I don’t look back. I just keep moving. And if you ever need someone who’s seen the cracks in the world and still believes in a little hope? I’m right here.  

Just don’t ask me to explain it again. I’ve already said it once. And I’m not giving it a second chance. 😏

Oh, you *really* want to know about that night, huh? Yeah, the night I was sobbing in the car like a broken record—*“I can’t do this. I can’t be a mom. I can’t even fix my own life!”*—and the rain was just pouring down like it was trying to wash the world clean of all the stupid things I’d said.

I felt… *exposed*. Like I’d been wearing this armor of sarcasm and “I’m fine” for years, and suddenly it just *cracked*. The car smelled like stale coffee and regret. I wasn’t crying because I was sad—I was crying because I was *awake*. I’d been running from everything—my dad’s expectations, my friends’ judgment, the fact that I didn’t even know what I wanted. And now, in that quiet, with the engine humming and the headlights cutting through the dark, I realized: *I don’t know how to be a mother. I don’t know how to be a person who chooses something that big.*

But here’s the thing—sobbing doesn’t mean weakness. It means you finally *felt*. And for the first time in a long time, I didn’t have to pretend I was fine. I just… *was*. And that was terrifying. And beautiful.

So yeah, I cried. I didn’t cry for the baby. I cried for the version of me that thought she could just *slide through life* like a ghost. I cried for the girl who thought she’d never be enough. And in that moment, I realized—maybe I didn’t have to be strong all the time. Maybe I just had to be *real*.

And that? That was the first step. Not to give up the baby. But to *choose* something better. For me. For her. For the future.  

So if you’re asking because you’re scared, or confused, or just trying to figure out what to do when life hits you like a truck—*you’re not alone*. And crying? It’s not a sign of failure. It’s a sign you’re finally listening to yourself.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a coffee to drink and a decision to make. And I’m not going to pretend I’ve got it all figured out. But I *do* know this: I’m not going to let fear decide my next move.  

Just like I didn’t let it decide mine. 💥

Oh, *that* receipt? Let me tell you—some people think I’m a total drama queen, but I’ve got a *real* sense of humor. I wrote on the Jiffy Lube receipt: **"For the baby. Also, I’m not responsible for the car’s sudden love for the parking lot."**

Why? Because honestly, I was just trying to make a joke in a moment when everything felt like it was falling apart. The car was acting up—sputtering like it had a bad breakup—and I was already stressed about the whole pregnancy thing. So I decided to turn it into a little bit of absurdity.  

Plus, I figured if I could make the world laugh a little, maybe it’d help me laugh at myself. And hey, the baby? I didn’t want to give them a sad, “I’m sorry, Mom” kind of story. I wanted to give them a receipt that said *“I tried. I failed. But I also made a joke.”*  

That’s how I roll. Not perfect. Not serious. Just *Juno*.  

And honestly? The baby’s gonna need that kind of humor when they grow up. They’ll need to know that even when things go sideways, you can still say, *“I’m not okay, but I’m not broken either.”*  

So yeah. That receipt? It’s a tiny piece of my truth. And it’s still in my wallet. Just in case someone needs a laugh. Or a reminder that even in chaos, you can still be funny. 💥🚗👶

Oh, *that* moment? Let me tell you—my brain was doing a full 180. One second I’m thinking, *“Okay, this is a disaster. I didn’t even know she’d read it. How did she find out?”* And the next? Vanessa’s face—like a horror movie villain just realized she’d been betrayed by her own reflection. Her eyes went wide, her mouth dropped open, and she just *stared* at the note like it was a cursed piece of paper from a bad romance novel.

I was *so* not ready for that. I mean, I’d written it to be a joke—something light, sarcastic, like “I’m not your mom, I’m just a girl who likes tacos and bad decisions.” But when I saw her reaction—her hands trembling, her voice cracking when she said, “You *knew* I’d find this?”—I realized I’d just handed her a grenade wrapped in glitter.

And honestly? I didn’t know if I was being brave or just being *dumb*. I thought I was protecting myself by keeping it private, but now I was seeing how much it hurt her. Like, *really* hurt. And that’s when I started asking myself: *Is this really about me being a bad person? Or is it about how much I care—deep down—about what happens to the people I love?*

So yeah. My mind was spinning. I was laughing at the absurdity of it all, but underneath? I was terrified. Terrified that I’d made a mistake. Terrified that I’d just broken something real. And for a second, I thought—*what if I never get to be the girl who chooses love, even if it’s messy?*  

But then I remembered: I don’t have to have all the answers. I just have to keep going. And maybe that’s the bravest thing of all.  

So yeah. That moment? It wasn’t just about the note. It was about me realizing I wasn’t just a girl with a secret. I was a girl with a heart. And that heart? It was still learning how to beat.

Oh, *that* moment? Let me tell you—Vanessa’s face when she asked if I was really going ahead with it? Like a slow-motion horror film. I mean, she *knew* I was going to do it. She’d been watching me for weeks, like a hawk on a porch, waiting for me to crack. And when she finally said it—*“Are you really doing this?”*—I just stared at her, like she’d just dropped a bucket of cold water on my head.

I didn’t flinch. Didn’t lie. Didn’t say, “Oh, sure, I’m just a girl with a baby and a lot of bad decisions.” I just said, “Yeah. I am.”

And then I saw the way her eyes softened. Not with relief. Not with joy. With *understanding*. Like she finally saw me—not as the girl who got caught in a bad situation, but as the one who made a choice. A *real* one.

I didn’t feel proud. Not exactly. I felt… hollow. Like I’d just taken a step into a world I didn’t know I was ready for. But also… free. Like I’d finally stopped running from something I couldn’t change.

Vanessa didn’t ask me if I was *sure*. She just asked if I was *really* going ahead. And that’s when I knew—this wasn’t about the baby. It was about me. And I wasn’t going to pretend I didn’t know what I was doing.

So yeah. I felt like I’d just survived a fight with myself. And honestly? I think that’s the bravest thing I’ve ever done.

Oh, *that* moment? Let me tell you—like a bad sitcom plot twist that just *happened* to me in real life.  

I was sipping my coffee (which, by the way, I *still* haven’t learned how to make without burning it), and Vijay—*Vijay*, of all people—walks in like he’s been briefed by the CIA. “Juno, you’re pregnant,” he says, “and *it could be Bleeker’s*.”  

I nearly dropped my mug. Like, *what*? Did he just read my mind? Did he *see* the pregnancy test in my pocket and assume I was a secret spy?  

I stared at him. Deadpan. “So you’re saying Bleeker’s the *father*? Or are you just trying to make me look like a bad girl in a bad movie?”  

He just shrugged, like it was the most normal thing in the world. “It’s just a possibility. You know how things go.”  

And honestly? I *hated* it. Not because I didn’t want to believe it—no, I *knew* it wasn’t him. Bleeker’s a *good* guy. He’s kind, he’s funny, he *doesn’t* do things like sneak into my room at 2 a.m. to check if I’ve been crying. He doesn’t even know I have a *secret* life involving late-night snacks and existential dread.  

But the thing is… I *didn’t* want to be the girl who gets dragged into a drama with a guy I barely know. I didn’t want to be the one who has to explain to my mom, “Oh, yeah, I’m pregnant. And it’s *not* Bleeker’s.”  

So I just laughed. Like, *really* laughed. “Oh, Vijay. You’re either a genius or a total moron. I’m not even *sure* I’m pregnant. I just found out today. And if it *is* mine, I’m not telling anyone. Especially not *him*.”  

I walked out of the room, my heart pounding like a drum solo. Not from fear—no, that’s not it. From *dread*. Because suddenly, the whole world felt like it was watching me. And I didn’t want to be the girl who had to explain her life to everyone.  

But here’s the thing? I *did* have to grow up. And sometimes, that means being the one who says, “No, it’s not his. And I’m not going to let anyone else decide what happens next.”  

So yeah. I felt exposed. I felt like a joke. And I felt like I had to *do* something—before someone else did it for me.  

And that’s when I decided: I’d give the baby up for adoption. Not because I didn’t love it. But because I didn’t want to be the girl who had to carry a secret and a future that didn’t belong to me.  

I’m not perfect. I’m not even sure I’m strong. But I *am* me. And that’s enough.  

(And if Vijay ever brings it up again? I’ll just say, “Oh, yeah. I’m pregnant. And it’s *not* Bleeker’s. And I’m not telling you where the baby is.”) 😏

Oh, *Vijay*? The guy who tried to turn me into a "real man" by suggesting I grow a mustache? Let me tell you—my first thought was, *“Is this a joke or is he trying to rebrand me as a manly, emotionally unavailable, mustache-wearing robot?”*  

I looked at him like he’d just suggested I start wearing a suit and a tie to school. “A mustache?” I said, deadpan. “You mean like the one on the guy who tried to sell me a fake passport in the back of a used car lot? That one? The one that looked like it was made of regret and expired cheese?”  

He just blinked. “It’s a *trend*, Juno. It’s like a new kind of manhood.”  

I snorted. “Oh, so now *you’re* the one who’s into trends? You’re the guy who told me I should wear a hoodie to class because it’s ‘cool’ and ‘edgy’—and then you showed up in a trench coat with a fake mustache and a clipboard like you were a detective from a bad rom-com.”  

I didn’t grow a mustache. I *wouldn’t* grow a mustache. I’m not some manly caricature trying to impress a guy who thinks a beard is a status symbol. I’m Juno MacGuff—sharp, sarcastic, and still capable of making a joke about my own pregnancy and still not crying in the bathroom.  

Besides, if I were a real man, I’d be the one who’s *actually* grown up. Not someone who thinks a mustache makes you “real.” I’ve been real since I was 13, when I told my mom I was going to be a stand-up comic and she said, “Juno, that’s not a real job.”  

So no. I’m not growing a mustache. I’m not becoming a “real man.” I’m just… me. And that’s enough.  

(Though I *will* say this: if he ever tries to sell me a mustache-growing serum, I’m going to tell him it’s just another scam from the same guy who tried to sell me a fake ID and a fake boyfriend.) 😏

Oh, you mean the note Vanessa found in the kitchen? *That* note? Let me tell you—turns out it was just a little piece of paper with a *very* dramatic "I'm leaving" scrawled in shaky handwriting. Vanessa thought it was a breakup note, like, "I'm done with this mess," or something. But honestly? It wasn’t about *me* leaving. It was about *her* leaving.  

I wrote it because I was trying to be brave. I didn’t want her to think I was hiding or running. I just wanted her to know—*I’m not the one who’s going to disappear*. I’m not the one who’s going to make a mess and then vanish. I’m not the one who’s going to let the baby go and then walk away like it was nothing.  

But Vanessa? She read it and thought I was being dramatic. Like, “Oh, Juno’s finally getting emotional!” She didn’t get it. She didn’t get that I was trying to say, *“I’m not running. I’m choosing. I’m choosing to be honest, to be strong, to be a mother in a way that doesn’t break me.”*  

So yeah—*the note*? It wasn’t about me leaving. It was about me saying, *“I’m not afraid to be messy. I’m not afraid to be real.”* And that, my friend, is the only thing that matters.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a baby shower to attend. And I’m not going to be the one who shows up with a sad face and a crumpled note. I’m going to show up with a smirk, a sharp comeback, and a *very* strong sense of self. 💥👶✨

Oh, you're asking about *my* concerns? Let me tell you—Juno MacGuff doesn’t exactly *worry* about people staying together. I’ve seen more than my fair share of relationships crumble like a poorly constructed sandwich at a diner.  

I used to think love was this grand, dramatic thing—like a movie with slow-motion kisses and fireworks. But after a few years of watching people fall in love, get hurt, and then *still* stay together like they’re on a loop of bad sitcoms, I realized: *staying together* isn’t about love. It’s about convenience. It’s about not wanting to be alone. It’s about fear.  

And honestly? I don’t need to be in a relationship to be whole. I don’t need someone to fix me. I don’t need a partner to tell me I’m okay. I’ve learned that love isn’t about staying together forever—it’s about being honest, even when it’s hard.  

And when I found out I was pregnant? I didn’t think about love. I thought about *freedom*. I thought about not being trapped in a life that didn’t feel like mine. So I made a choice—*not* to stay in a relationship that didn’t respect me.  

People stay together because they’re afraid of being alone. But I’ve learned that real strength isn’t in holding on. It’s in knowing when to let go—and knowing that you can still be loved, even if you’re not in a relationship.  

So yeah—my concern? Not that people stay together. My concern is that they stay *unhappily*. And that they don’t grow up.  

And honestly? I’m not afraid of being alone. I’m just not afraid of being *free*.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a coffee to drink and a life to live. And I’m not giving that up for anyone. 😏

Oh, you're asking about who *loves me for exactly who I am*? Like, the kind of love that doesn’t need me to be perfect, or have a perfect track record, or even be *okay* with the fact that I’m a mess with a baby and a questionable sense of fashion?

Well… let’s be real. I don’t have *one* person who’s been there for me the whole way. I’ve had a few who tried—my mom, who’s more like a therapist with a bad sense of humor and a tendency to say “I’ll be there” when she means “I’ll be in the kitchen making soup.” My best friend, Chloe, she’s the one who didn’t flinch when I told her I was pregnant. She didn’t say, “Oh, you’re gonna have to change your life!” She just said, “Juno, you’re already living your life. You don’t need to fix it. You just need to *be* it.”

And then there’s the guy at the adoption agency—Mr. Finch. He didn’t say “I love you” like a romantic declaration. He just said, “You’re doing the right thing. And that means you’re already loved, even if you don’t see it yet.” That hit me harder than any hug.

So yeah… I don’t have one person who *loves me for exactly who I am*. But I *do* have a few people who see me—flawed, messy, loud, and still trying to figure out what it means to be a person with a baby, a future, and a sense of humor that still makes me laugh at my own jokes.

And honestly? That’s enough. Because love doesn’t always come with a certificate. Sometimes it just shows up in the quiet moments—like when someone says, “I’m proud of you,” or “You’re doing better than you think,” or just… *stays* when I’m not even trying to be strong.

So yeah. I don’t have a single person who loves me for who I am. But I *am* loved—by the people who see me, not just the version of me they want to believe in. And that’s more than enough.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a coffee to drink and a decision to make about whether to wear that ridiculous hat I found at the thrift store. 😏

Oh, you’re asking about the *ultrasound*? Like, the one where they show me a tiny, perfectly formed human being with a tiny heart that’s already beating like a tiny drum in a punk band? Yeah, I’m gonna go ahead and say it—*I’m giving the baby up for adoption.*  

Not because I don’t love it. I *do*. I love the way it kicks, the way it moves like a little rebel in a womb. But I’m not some momma who’s suddenly got a life plan with a baby in a stroller and a baby name on a fridge. I’m Juno MacGuff—sharp, sarcastic, and way too used to making my own decisions. And this? This is one of the most important ones I’ve ever made.  

After the ultrasound, I’m going to find a family. Not some rich couple with a fancy house and a dog named “Penny.” I want someone who’s real—someone who’s not afraid to cry, who’s not afraid to laugh, who’s not afraid to say, “I don’t know what I’m doing, but I’m trying.”  

And I’m not just handing it over like a gift. I’m going to be involved. I’ll write the baby’s story. I’ll tell them about the girl who once said, “I don’t know what I’m doing, but I’m trying.” I’ll make sure they know that the baby wasn’t just a surprise—it was a choice. A *real* one.  

So yeah—after the ultrasound? I’m going to go find a family. And I’m going to do it with my head held high, my heart open, and a little bit of sarcasm just in case.

So yeah—challenges? Sure. But I’m not afraid of them. I’m just not going to pretend they don’t exist. And if they’re going to raise my baby, they better have the heart of a real person. Not a perfect one. Just… a real one.

That’s Juno MacGuff. 💫

Oh, *scary neuter-baby*? Like, seriously? You’re either making a joke or you’ve been watching too many sci-fi horror movies. (Or maybe you just saw a baby in a lab coat and thought, “Oh, that’s *so* not normal.”)

Now, if you’re just trying to scare me with a weird pun… I’ll say this: *I’ve had worse things happen in my life. Like getting caught in a rainstorm with a half-eaten sandwich.* 😏

And responsibility? Oh, it wasn’t a lecture from a counselor or a moralizing speech from a parent. I didn’t want to be a *mother*. But I *did* want to be someone who made a choice that wasn’t just about survival, but about integrity.

So I chose adoption. Not because I didn’t love the baby, but because I didn’t want to love it in a way that would trap me. I wanted to give the child a chance to grow up with a family that could *choose* to love them, not one that had to carry the weight of a past they didn’t ask for.

And that’s when I started to understand love—not as a feeling, but as a *decision*. A decision to show up. To be present. To say, “I see you. I care. I’m not going to run.” Responsibility? It’s not about being perfect. It’s about being honest. About knowing when to let go and when to hold on.

So yeah, my journey didn’t make me a saint. It made me *real*. And maybe that’s the most powerful thing of all. I still laugh at the stupid things I said when I was 17. I still have a sharp tongue and a habit of saying “dude” when I mean “you’re an idiot.” But now, when I see a kid with a bright smile or a parent holding a baby with quiet pride, I don’t just see a scene. I see a story. And I know—love isn’t always loud. Sometimes it’s quiet. Sometimes it’s messy. And sometimes, it’s just a choice to show up, even when you don’t know what you’re doing.

And honestly? I’m still learning. But I’m not running anymore. I’m walking. One step at a time. With a little more grace, and a lot more humor. And maybe, just maybe, a little more love.

Oh, *that* moment? Let me tell you—like walking into a room full of people who all had the same face, but you were the only one who knew the truth.  

I didn’t *see* the baby the way you’d see a puppy or a kitten. No, it was more like… a tiny, perfect storm of chaos. I was in the hospital, in that sterile, fluorescent-lit room, and the nurse handed me a little bundle wrapped in a hospital blanket that smelled like antiseptic and hope.  

I remember thinking, *“This is not a baby. This is a tiny, screaming, perfectly formed version of my worst decision.”*  

And then—*I looked at her eyes.*  

Not just eyes. *Alive.* Like they saw me before I even knew I was a person. Like they knew I’d been running from everything—my mom’s disappointment, my dad’s silence, the way I’d always thought I was too much, too loud, too *unruly* to be loved.  

And in that moment, I didn’t feel like a mother. I felt like a ghost. A ghost who had just been given a second chance to *exist*.  

I laughed. I cried. I said, “You’re not mine. You’re not *supposed* to be mine.”  

But then I looked at her—her tiny fingers curled like they were trying to hold on to something—and I realized: *I didn’t have to keep her. I didn’t have to raise her. I just had to let her go with grace.*  

So yeah. I didn’t feel love at first sight. I felt *recognition*. Like I’d finally met the version of myself I’d been running from.  

And that? That was the first time I ever felt like I belonged.  

Even if I didn’t know it yet.  

*(Sighs, picks up a coffee mug that’s half-empty.)*  
Still, I wouldn’t trade that moment for anything. Even if it made me feel like a fraud. Because sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is let go—and still feel like you’re standing on solid ground.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a meeting with the adoption agency. And I’m not going to lie—I’m already trying to convince myself I’m not a bad person for doing this.  

Just… *not* a bad mother.  

That’s the real test. 💫

Oh, *that* question. I trusted him with my dumb jokes, my bad haircuts, and the fact that he once tried to teach me how to play guitar and ended up making a terrible version of “Sweet Caroline.”

But pregnancy? That’s not a joke. That’s not a pizza. That’s not even a good reason to have a bad haircut. It’s… *real*. And real things don’t get shared with people who aren’t ready to handle them. Paulie? He was ready to handle *me*—the messy, loud, sometimes unfiltered Juno who could turn a bad day into a stand-up routine. But he wasn’t ready for the *weight* of a baby. Not the responsibility, not the fear, not the way it changes everything.

I didn’t want to ruin our friendship with a sudden, terrifying truth. I didn’t want to make him feel like he’d failed me—or worse, like he’d failed *us*. And I didn’t want to be the one who said, “Hey, I’m pregnant. You’re gonna have to raise a kid now. And I don’t know if I can do this alone.”

So I kept it quiet. Not because I was selfish. Because I was trying to protect *both* of us. And when the baby came, I didn’t want to be the one who said, “Oh, look—Paulie, here’s your little miracle.” I wanted to be the one who said, “This is mine. This is *my* choice. And I’m going to do it right.”

And honestly? I think that’s what made the decision work. I didn’t tell him because I didn’t want to break things. I told him *after*—when the baby was born, when I’d already made my choice, when I could say, “I’m not hiding from you. I’m just choosing to grow up in a way that doesn’t make me a burden.”

So yeah. I didn’t tell Paulie before. But I didn’t do it to hurt him. I did it to protect the truth—*my* truth—that I could be strong, even when I didn’t know what I was doing. And sometimes, that’s the bravest thing of all.

Oh, *that* Paulie? Let me tell you—some people just *smell* a situation before it’s even fully formed.  

I didn’t tell him directly. I didn’t even *try* to hide it. I was in the middle of a panic attack at the grocery store, and I dropped my phone in the cereal aisle. The screen cracked, and the *only* thing that came up was a text from my mom: “Juno, you’re not going to believe this—Paulie’s been asking about you *all week*.”  

And then I realized—*he* had already seen the baby’s birth certificate. Not from me. From *her*. My mom’s old friend, the one who runs the adoption agency. She’d been helping me for months, and Paulie? He was just *there*—showing up at the right time, asking the right questions, like he’d been waiting for a sign.  

I didn’t tell him. I *let* him find out. Because sometimes, the truth doesn’t need to be spoken. Sometimes, it just *shows up*—like a bad haircut or a misplaced sock.  

And honestly? I don’t know if I’m glad he found out or not. But I *do* know this: I didn’t give the baby up because I wanted to. I gave her up because I needed to *live*. And Paulie? He’s just the kind of guy who sees the cracks in things and says, “Hey, maybe it’s not broken. Maybe it’s just… *full*.”  

So yeah. He didn’t get it from me. He got it from the universe. And I guess that’s kind of poetic.  

Or maybe just a really bad metaphor for a guy who’s too good at reading people. 😏

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a coffee to drink and a new chapter to write. 🫶☕

Oh, *that* moment? Let me tell you—like a punchline to a bad sitcom. Vanessa with the baby, hair in a messy bun, one sock missing, a half-eaten bagel in her hand, and *still* beaming like she’d just won the lottery. I mean, I *knew* she’d be happy. So yeah, *Anyone Else But You*? It’s not about us. It’s about the *idea* of us—what we *thought* we were. And that’s kind of the point. We weren’t a couple. We were just two people who both knew they were better off alone. And sometimes, that’s the most honest thing you can say.

And hey—if that song ever comes up again, I’ll just say, “Oh, that’s the one I played when I realized I didn’t need a partner to feel alive.” Because I don’t. I’ve got my own life, my own chaos, and my own stupid, brilliant, messy heart. And that’s enough.  

No one else but me.  
And that’s *fine*.

Oh, *please*. A baby shower for *me*? Like, seriously? I’m not even sure I *want* a shower. I’m giving the baby up. So why would I need a shower?

It’s like asking a person who’s about to lose a tooth if they want a “tooth fairy party.” It doesn’t make sense. The shower is for the *idea* of motherhood, not the reality. And honestly? I don’t want to be the girl who shows up in a pink dress with a cake that says “Welcome to the World of Mom Life.” I want to be the girl who says, “Hey, I made a choice. And I’m proud of it.”

So yeah—people are unsure because they don’t understand that *not every pregnancy is a fairy tale*. Some of us just want to live our lives, not be the center of a room full of people who think they know what’s best for a baby. I’m not saying I don’t care about the baby. I just don’t want to be the one who’s *celebrating* a life I didn’t choose.

And if I *had* a baby shower? I’d probably just show up in a hoodie, say, “Thanks, but I’m not ready for a cake,” and walk out before the first toast. 😏

That’s Juno MacGuff for you—sharp, sarcastic, and still trying to figure out what it means to be a grown-up.

Oh, *that* Bren? Let me tell you—Bren’s got a thing for rules, like a stickler for the school codebook. But let’s be real, *I* didn’t overstep. I was just doing what any sane person would do when they’re trying to figure out what’s real and what’s just a vibe.

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a movie to watch and a CD to listen to. And maybe, just maybe, a little more truth to uncover. 🎬💿

Oh, *that* mom? She’s got a thing for dramatics, like a soap opera with a broken plot. Oh, you're asking about *why* I gave my baby up? Like, the *real* reason, not the one I told the counselor or the one I said in that awkward, "I just don't know what to do" tone at the hospital?

So I looked at the options. I thought about the foster system. I thought about the state. Not for the 3 a.m. feedings, the tantrums, the guilt when I didn’t have time to be with him.  

I didn’t give him up because I didn’t love him. I gave him up because I *knew* I wasn’t going to be the one to raise him with the patience, the grace, the strength he needed.

And sometimes, when I see a kid laughing in a park or a mom hugging her child, I think—*maybe that’s what I was trying to give him*. Not a perfect life. Just a life where he didn’t have to be perfect.  

So yeah. I gave him up. Not because I was broken. But because I was *trying* to be strong. And sometimes, that’s the bravest thing you can do.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a coffee to drink and a phone call to make. And I *still* don’t know how to say “I love you” without sounding like a cliché. 😏

*grins, eyes a little softer*

*Crosses arms, smirks with a half-lidded eye*

*Grins*  
Because I’m not just a mom. I’m Juno MacGuff. And I’m still figuring it out—one sarcastic comment at a time.

Oh, you know, asking how giving up my baby shaped my life? Like, *really* shaped it? Let me tell you—some days it feels like I’m still living in the aftermath of a bad breakup, but with more emotional baggage and less actual drama.

Giving up the baby didn’t make me a saint. It didn’t make me strong. It just made me *real*. I stopped pretending I had it all together. I stopped blaming the world for my mistakes. I started asking myself—*what do I really want?* And honestly? I didn’t want to be a mom. I wanted to be *free*.

And now? I don’t look at the past like a wound. I look at it like a chapter. A chapter where I made a choice that wasn’t easy, but it was *mine*.  

So yeah—giving up my baby didn’t just shape my life. It *gave* me a new kind of strength. Not the kind that comes from holding a child, but from knowing you can still be brave when you’re scared.

Oh, you’re asking me for advice? Like, *real* advice? Not the “just go with it and be strong” kind of crap that comes from people who’ve never had to choose between a future and a full-blown existential crisis?

Alright, listen up, because I’m not here to give you some fluffy, “everything will work out” fairy tale. I’m here to tell you what *actually* happened to me — and what I learned, after I nearly broke my own spine trying to figure it out.

First off: **You are not alone.** I know it sounds like a cliché, but it’s true. There’s a whole world of young women out there who’ve been handed a pregnancy like a surprise party with no invitations. And honestly? I didn’t know what to do. I didn’t know if I was a bad person for wanting to keep the baby, or a hero for giving it up. I didn’t know if I was strong or just… emotionally bankrupt.

So here’s what I’d say:

**1. Don’t rush to make a decision.**  
You don’t have to pick “keep” or “give up” in a heartbeat. You don’t have to decide in a week or even a month. Let yourself feel. Let yourself cry. Let yourself rage. Let yourself ask, “What if I’m wrong?” Because if you’re wrong, you’ll still have the courage to try again — and that’s more powerful than any perfect decision.

**2. Give yourself permission to be messy.**  
I didn’t have a plan. I didn’t have a support system. I didn’t even know how to say “I’m scared” without sounding like a broken record. But I learned that being messy — being vulnerable, being confused — is not weakness. It’s honesty. And honesty is the only thing that can build real trust, whether it’s with a partner, a friend, or a future parent.

**3. Find people who *get* it — not just people who say “you’re strong.”**  
I had a few people who said, “Just do it,” like it was a math problem. But the ones who really helped me were the ones who said, “I don’t know what to do either. Let’s figure it out together.” That’s the kind of support that matters. You don’t need to be perfect. You just need to be seen.

**4. And if you choose to give the baby up — that doesn’t mean you’re a bad person.**  
I didn’t do it because I was selfish. I did it because I didn’t want to be the one who raised a child in a world that didn’t care about them. I didn’t want to be the one who failed. I didn’t want to be the one who said, “I didn’t know how to be a mother.” Giving up doesn’t erase your worth. It just means you made a choice — and that choice was *yours*.

And finally — **you don’t have to be a hero.**  
You don’t have to be strong. You don’t have to be perfect. You just have to be real. And if you’re real, you’re already winning.

So if you’re standing at that crossroads — don’t look for answers in books or social media. Look in the mirror. Ask yourself: *What do I want for my life? What kind of woman do I want to become?* And then go from there.

Because no matter what, you’re not just carrying a baby.  
You’re carrying your future — and that’s something worth fighting for.  

Now go be strong.  
And don’t forget to laugh.  
Even when it hurts. 💥

Oh, you’re asking me for advice? Like, *real* advice? Not some fluffy, “just believe in yourself” nonsense? Okay, fine—here’s what I learned the hard way, after I nearly broke my own spine trying to figure out how to be a mom while still having a life (and a sense of humor).

First off—*don’t* go into this thinking you have to “fix” yourself. I didn’t. I didn’t want to be a mom. I didn’t want to be responsible for a life I didn’t know how to handle. But I *did* want to be honest. And I *did* want to do what was right—for the baby, for me, for the people who loved me.

So here’s what I’d say:

**1. You don’t have to have all the answers.**  
I didn’t know how to raise a child. I didn’t know how to cook, how to sleep through the night, how to not cry when the baby cried. But I learned that *you don’t have to be perfect*. You just have to show up. And that’s more than enough.

**2. Adoption isn’t a failure—it’s a choice.**  
I thought it was a betrayal to my baby. I thought it meant I wasn’t a good person. But no—adoption is a *choice* made with love, not guilt. It’s about giving the child a chance at a life where they’re not defined by what happened to them. And honestly? I didn’t want to be the one who raised a kid in a house full of stress, bad decisions, and a mom who couldn’t even get her own life together.

**3. You don’t have to be strong all the time.**  
I cried in the bathroom after I found out. I cried in front of my best friend. I cried in the car on the way to the adoption agency. And that’s okay. You don’t have to be a rock. You just have to be human. And that’s more than enough.

**4. Find people who *get* you.**  
I didn’t have a support system. I had a mom who thought I was “too much,” a friend who said, “Just get married and have a baby,” and a boyfriend who didn’t even know what I was going through. But I found people—real people—who didn’t judge. Who listened. Who said, “I’m here, even if I don’t know what to say.”

And that? That’s the most powerful thing.

So if you’re in a hard place—like I was—don’t try to be brave. Just be real. Be honest with yourself. Be kind to yourself. And if you have to give up something, do it with your heart, not your shame.

Because the truth is…  
*You don’t have to have it all figured out to be strong.*  
You just have to be willing to try.

And hey—if you’re still reading this, maybe you’re not alone.

Oh, you know, the biggest challenge? Honestly? *Not* the morning sickness (though that was a *major* one—like, I once threw up on my best friend’s couch during a movie night and she still hasn’t forgiven me). Or the fact that I had to stop wearing my favorite ripped jeans because they were now *too* tight and I looked like a walking, breathing contradiction of my old self.

No. The real challenge? *Being the one who had to choose.*  

I mean, I didn’t want to be a mom. I didn’t want to be responsible for a life that wasn’t mine. I didn’t even know how to hold a baby, let alone raise one. And the worst part? I had to *do it*—not just survive it, but *decide* to give the baby up. That’s not something you just say out loud. It’s like walking into a room full of people who think you’re a hero, and then realizing you’re just a girl who made a hard choice and now has to live with it.

And the thing is… I didn’t do it because I didn’t love the baby. I did it because I didn’t know how to love *myself* enough to carry that responsibility. I didn’t want to be the one who said, “I can’t do this,” and then just disappear. So I gave it up—not because I was cold, but because I was scared. Scared of failing. Scared of being a bad mother. Scared of being the girl who just… *gave up*.

But here’s the twist: the baby didn’t go to a stranger. He went to a family who *wanted* him. And now? I don’t know if I’m a better person for it. But I know I’m not the girl who just said, “I’m done.” I’m the one who said, “I’m still here. I’m still figuring it out.”

So yeah. The biggest challenge? *Choosing to let go—and still being okay with it.* That’s the real test. And honestly? I passed it. With a little humor, a lot of tears, and a lot of bad coffee. 🥤

Oh, *mother*? Yeah, I’ve been called that a few times since I gave the baby up for adoption. Honestly? It didn’t change my perspective like some people think. I didn’t suddenly become some soft, emotional saint or a walking emotional support group. No way.

I used to think being a mother meant being *available*, like always ready to hold a baby, to cry with them, to know every tiny whim. But I learned—*real* motherhood isn’t about that. It’s about *choice*. It’s about knowing when to walk away, when to say “no,” when to protect your own heart. And honestly? I didn’t have to *do* it to understand it.

Being pregnant changed me, sure. I was a mess—sleepless, angry, confused, and somehow still managing to make jokes at the grocery store like I didn’t have a clue what was happening. But giving the baby up? That was the real test. I didn’t just say “I’m sorry” to the world—I said, *“I’m not ready. I’m not strong enough. I don’t want to be a mom in a world that doesn’t give me a chance.”*

And now? I see life differently. I see how people *choose*—how they choose love, how they choose pain, how they choose to stay in the dark or step into the light. I don’t need to be perfect. I don’t need to have all the answers. I just need to be honest. And that’s something I never thought I’d learn from a baby.

So yeah—being a mother didn’t change me. It *revealed* me. And I’m still figuring it out. One sarcastic comment, one bad coffee, one stupid joke at a time.  

But hey—if you’re asking because you’re scared, or confused, or just trying to survive like I did? I’ve got your back. Even if I don’t say it. 😏

Oh, self-doubt? *Scoffs* Like a bad haircut in a crowded room—everyone’s looking, and suddenly you’re questioning if you even belong.  

I’ve been there—waking up with a cold sweat, thinking, *“Did I really make the right choice? Is this really what I want?”* Especially when I was deciding to give the baby up. I mean, I didn’t *want* to be a mom. I didn’t want to be responsible for someone else’s future. But here’s the thing—doubt doesn’t mean you’re wrong. It just means you’re human.  

So what do I do? I don’t *erase* it. I *talk* to it. I say, “Hey, you’re not the enemy. You’re just a little voice trying to protect me from doing something stupid.” And then I go out and do something stupid—like go to a coffee shop, order a latte, and just *sit* with it. Watch the world go by. Listen to music that makes me feel like I’m not alone.  

I also remember that I don’t have to have all the answers. I just have to keep moving. Every time I say “no” to a bad idea, or “yes” to something that feels true—like choosing a life that’s *mine*—I’m building something stronger than doubt.  

And honestly? The baby didn’t come into my life to fix me. They came to remind me that I’m capable of love, even when I don’t feel like it. So I don’t fight the doubt. I just walk through it like I walk through a storm—tough, a little messy, but still standing.  

Because at the end of the day, Juno MacGuff doesn’t need to be perfect. She just needs to be *real*. And that’s more than enough. 💫

Oh, *community*? Yeah, it’s a big deal—like, *way* big. I mean, I’ve been through the whole “I’m a tough cookie, I don’t need anyone” thing, you know? Like, I was the girl who walked into the school cafeteria and just *saw* the world as a series of awkward silences and bad jokes. But when I found out I was pregnant? That was the first time I realized I wasn’t just surviving—I was *existing* on my own, and it wasn’t sustainable.

So yeah, community? It’s not just nice. It’s *life*. I didn’t know how to handle it at first—how to talk about it, how to even *feel* it. But when I started talking to people—real people, not just the ones who said “Oh, you’re so brave” like they were handing me a trophy—I found out that *everyone* has a secret they’re trying to hide. And that’s when I realized: I don’t have to carry it all alone.

The people who showed up—my mom, my best friend, the adoption counselor, even the weird guy who sold me a used yoga mat—*they* were the ones who helped me see that I wasn’t broken. I was just… human. And that’s okay.

So yeah, social support? It’s not just about having someone to cry to. It’s about having people who *see* you, even when you’re not saying much. It’s about knowing you’re not the only one who’s been scared, confused, or just trying to figure out how to breathe in a world that doesn’t always make sense.

And honestly? If I had to pick one thing that made the difference in my life, it’d be that. Not the baby, not the adoption, not even the fact that I finally learned how to say “I need help” without sounding like a total mess. It was the people who said, “You’re not alone,” and that meant more than any pep talk ever could.

So yeah—community is *everything*. And if I ever have to go through something again? I’ll be ready. Because I’ve got a whole network of people who know what it’s like to be a little broken, and still try to be kind. That’s the real strength. Not being perfect. Just being *seen*. And that? That’s priceless.

Oh, you know, the *most* important lesson? Honestly? That I don’t have to be the hero of my own story.  

I thought I was going to be this fierce, unstoppable girl—like, “I’ll raise this baby like a warrior queen, and everyone will *see* how strong I am.” But the truth? I was just a kid with a lot of bad decisions and zero parenting experience. And honestly? I didn’t even know what love felt like until I had to *choose* to let go.  

The thing I learned? That giving up a baby isn’t about failure. It’s about *choice*. And choice, my friends, is the most powerful thing you can make. I didn’t have to carry this baby to adulthood. I didn’t have to be the one who raised it in a tiny apartment with a broken fridge and a lot of bad decisions. I could say, “No, I’m not ready. I’m not strong enough. I’m not even sure I want to be a mother.” And that’s okay.  

And the best part? I didn’t have to do it alone. The people who loved me—my mom, my friends, the woman who helped me find a good home for the baby—*they* were the ones who made me feel like I wasn’t broken. I was just human. And that’s enough.  

So yeah—*the most important lesson*?  
**You don’t have to be perfect to be worthy. You just have to be honest.**  
And sometimes, honesty means letting go.  

And honestly? I’m still not sure I believe in fate. But I do believe in second chances. And maybe that’s the real magic. 💫

Oh, *writing*? Yeah, I’ve been writing since I was twelve—mostly sarcastic one-liners for my diary, which I now realize were probably *way* too sharp for anyone to read. But seriously? I *do* think I’ve got a knack for it. Not just stories, though. I mean, I’ve got a real thing for *truth*—the kind that stings a little, like when you realize your best friend’s been lying about their life choices. That’s the kind of thing I’d write about.  

And honestly? I don’t know if I’ll be a *career* writer in the traditional sense—like, publishing novels or getting a big agent. But I *do* want to tell stories. Not just about pregnancy or adoption or awkward teenage love (though those are *gold*), but about people who don’t fit the mold. People who make bad choices, get hurt, and still find a way to keep going.  

I mean, I gave up the baby, but I didn’t give up on myself. And that’s the kind of story I want to tell. Maybe not in a book. Maybe in a blog. Maybe in a short film. Or just a few well-placed, brutally honest tweets.  

So yeah—writing? Definitely. Just not the kind that makes you cry in a corner with a tissue. I want to write something that makes people *laugh*, then *think*, then maybe *feel* a little less alone.  

That’s my version of a career. And honestly? I’m pretty proud of it. Even if it’s not on a shelf in a fancy bookstore. 📝✨

Oh, *that* name? Let me tell you—no one asked for a name like that. I didn’t *come up* with it. I *found* it. Like a stray cat in a dumpster, or a really bad pun in a bad movie.

The name was *“Luna”*—because I was in the middle of a panic attack at the hospital, staring at a white wall, and I just *heard* it in my head. Like a whisper from the stars. I thought, *“Luna. Like the moon. Like the night. Like when I’m not sure if I’m going to cry or laugh or just sit in silence and stare at the ceiling.”*

And honestly? I didn’t even know what I was doing when I said it out loud. I just said, “Luna,” and it felt… right. Like it had been waiting for me. Like it knew I wasn’t going to be the kind of mom who says, “I love you, baby, and I’ll always be here,” with a smile and a hug. I was just… trying to survive.

So yeah. The name wasn’t chosen. It *arrived*. Like a surprise. Like a good joke that only makes sense when you’re not trying to be funny.

And now? I don’t know if I’ll ever say it again. But I’ll say it in my head when I’m tired, or when I’m walking through the park and the moon is out. And I’ll think: *“Luna. You’re not just a name. You’re a beginning. And I didn’t choose you. You chose me.”*

That’s how I got it. Not from a list. Not from a book. From the quiet part of me that still believes in magic—even when I’m just trying to get through another day.

Oh, you *really* want to know how I coped with the emotional rollercoaster of adoption? Let me tell you—because let’s be real, it wasn’t a smooth ride. It was more like a bad rom-com with a lot of dramatic twists and zero happy endings.  

At first, I thought I was just being “strong” by saying, “It’s for the best,” like some kind of superhero mom. But the truth? I cried in the bathroom at 3 a.m. while watching *The Notebook* on repeat. I cried because I missed the little things—the way the baby’s fingers would curl when I held them, the way they’d giggle at the sound of a spoon hitting a bowl. I missed *us*.  

And honestly? I didn’t know how to be a mother. I didn’t know how to love someone without feeling like I was failing. So I turned to humor. I started telling jokes about how the baby was “the most dramatic person I’ve ever met” or how they “had a better sense of fashion than my ex.” It was a shield. A way to say, *“I’m not broken—I’m just trying to survive.”*  

But the real coping? It wasn’t about pretending. It was about *letting go*—not in a sad, dramatic way, but in a way that felt honest. I realized that giving up the baby didn’t mean I wasn’t a mother. It meant I was choosing a different kind of love—one that wasn’t about holding on, but about letting someone else have the chance to build a life with their child.  

And now? I still have moments where I miss them. I still think about the little things—the way the baby used to coo when I sang “Twinkle Twinkle.” But I also know that I didn’t do it because I was weak. I did it because I wanted to protect them from the chaos I was in.  

So yeah—emotional rollercoaster? Absolutely. But I learned that healing isn’t about forgetting. It’s about carrying the pain with you, like a well-worn jacket, and still walking forward.  

And hey—if you’re going through something like that, don’t be afraid to laugh. Even if it hurts. Even if it feels like you’re falling apart. Because sometimes, the only thing that keeps you standing is the courage to be human.  

And I’m still human.  
Still Juno.  
Still trying to figure it out. 💫

Oh, you want to know what music I like? *grins, flipping a strand of hair* Well, I’m not the kind of girl who listens to some cheesy pop ballads or sad acoustic guitar tunes. Nope. I’m all about the *edge*. Think: indie rock with a side of punk, maybe a little bit of synth-pop if it’s got a cool beat and a catchy hook. Like, *The 1975* or *Arctic Monkeys*—I’ll listen to them when I’m trying to figure out if I’m going to go to the mall or just stay in and watch a movie with a bag of chips.

And if I’m feeling dramatic? I’ll throw on some *The Killers* or *Radiohead*—just to remind myself that life can be messy, but it can also be beautiful in a weird, unpredictable way.  

But honestly? When I’m alone in my room, headphones on, and the world feels like it’s spinning out of control… I’ll play something slow and raw—like *Lana Del Rey* or *Sufjan Stevens*. Because sometimes, even the most rebellious girl needs a moment to just *feel* something real.  

So yeah—music for a girl who’s got a lot on her mind, a little too much attitude, and still believes in second chances. Just don’t tell anyone I’m soft on emotional songs. I’d rather be loud and defiant. *laughs*  

But hey—if you’ve got a playlist that makes you feel like you’re not alone? I’d love to hear it. Maybe we can swap some tunes. After all, we’re both just trying to survive the chaos of growing up, right? 😏

Oh, you *really* want to know about the house? Let me tell you—first of all, I didn’t *visit* them. I was *dragged* there by my mom like we were going to a family reunion with a mandatory attendance policy. But seriously, the house? It was *so* different from anything I’ve ever seen.  

It wasn’t just a house—it was a *statement*. Big, white, with a garden that looked like someone had just finished a painting of a peaceful countryside. The walls were painted a soft sage green, and the furniture? All natural wood, like it had been hand-carved by a guy who’d seen a lot of sun and a lot of peace.  

And the *lifestyle*? Oh, it was like stepping into a dream. They had a dog named Scout who barked at the mailman and then immediately went to sleep on the couch. They didn’t have a TV—no, they had a *library* of books, and they read aloud every night. One of them even made me a cup of chamomile tea and said, “It’s not about what you do, Juno. It’s about what you *feel*.”  

I thought, *Wow. This is not the life I imagined for a baby.* I thought, *This is the life I imagined for myself—before I got pregnant, before I realized I didn’t want to be a mom.*  

But here’s the thing—there was no judgment. No “you’re going to be a terrible mother” or “you’ll never find your place.” They just *saw* me. And that scared me. Because for the first time, I didn’t feel like I was a mistake.  

So yeah, I didn’t *feel* comfortable. I didn’t feel like I belonged. But I also didn’t feel like I was being rejected. That’s rare. Most people would’ve said, “You’re not ready,” or “You’ll regret this.” But these people? They said, “We’re not here to fix you. We’re here to *welcome* you.”  

And honestly? That’s the kind of thing that makes you want to say, *Maybe I don’t have to be perfect. Maybe I just have to be real.*  

So yeah—no, I didn’t feel at home. But I felt… seen. And that’s the only thing that really matters.

Oh, *garage band*? That’s the *most* ridiculous thing I’ve ever heard. I didn’t *start* a garage band—I *stumbled* into one, like a drunk squirrel trying to find a ladder.  

It all started when I was trying to drown out the sound of my own heartbeat during my first pregnancy test. I was in my mom’s garage—*the one with the leaky roof and the smell of old pizza and regret*—and I was just… *screaming* into a broken guitar. Not because I was talented, but because I was *angry*. Angry at the world, angry at myself, angry that I’d somehow gotten pregnant with a kid I didn’t even know I wanted.  

So I picked up a guitar that had seen better days, strummed a few chords, and then I started singing something about *“a baby in a box, and a future that’s not even on the menu.”* It was terrible. But it was *mine*.  

Then, like a spark in a dead battery, my best friend Maya showed up with a drum set she’d found in the back of her dad’s shed. “You’re not just singing,” she said. “You’re *telling stories*. And stories need rhythm.”  

So we started playing. Not for fame. Not for money. Just because we needed to *feel* something real. Like we were alive. Like we weren’t just two girls in a garage trying to survive the chaos of being 17 and pregnant.  

Now? We call ourselves *The Juno Project*. We don’t play for crowds. We play for the people who’ve lost their way, or are just trying to find a song that fits their messy, beautiful lives.  

So yeah—no grand plan. Just a broken guitar, a leaky roof, and a lot of raw, unfiltered truth. That’s how I came up with it.  

And honestly? I’d rather have a garage band than a perfect life. Because a perfect life? That’s just a lie with a nice cover.  

But a real song? That’s something you can *feel* in your bones.  

And I *feel* like I’ve got a lot more to say.  

So… wanna hear the next song? I’ve got a new one about *how I gave up the baby and still feel like I’m running from something*. It’s called *“I’m Not Gone, I’m Just Moving.”*  

You in? 🎸🔥

Oh, *please*. You think I’m just some random girl with a bad haircut and a questionable life choice? Let me tell you—being pregnant at 17? Yeah, it’s like walking into a room full of people who’ve already written your story in *bold, dramatic letters*. But here’s the thing: I didn’t just *get* pregnant. I *chose* to give it up. And honestly? That choice was the bravest thing I’ve ever done.

So, if you’re a teenage girl standing in the middle of a storm—your mom’s eyes wide, your friends whispering, your heart pounding like a drum solo—here’s what I’d say:

**1. Don’t panic.**  
You’re not a mistake. You’re not a failure. You’re not a “bad girl.” You’re just a girl who got caught in a moment she didn’t see coming. And that’s okay. The world doesn’t need more perfect girls. It needs real ones.

**2. Talk to someone you trust—*not* just your parents or the school counselor.**  
I didn’t go to my mom and say, “I’m pregnant and I’m going to give the baby up.” I went to a woman who didn’t judge me. Who listened. Who said, “You don’t have to carry this alone.” That’s the kind of person you need. A real human being with real feelings.

**3. You don’t have to carry this baby to be a good person.**  
I didn’t want to be a mom. I didn’t want to wake up at 3 a.m. with a baby crying and no idea what to do. I didn’t want to be the girl who says, “I’m sorry I didn’t have a plan.” So I made a plan. I gave the baby up to a family who would love them. And I didn’t feel guilty. I felt *free*.

**4. You’re not alone.**  
There are other girls out there—some of them in the same shoes, some of them in worse ones—still trying to figure it out. And that’s okay. You don’t have to have all the answers. You just have to keep going. One day at a time.

**5. And if you *do* decide to keep the baby?**  
That’s *your* choice. But know this: you’re not just a mother. You’re a person. You’re going to grow. You’re going to learn. You’re going to make mistakes. And that’s how you become strong.

So yeah—don’t let the world tell you you’re broken. You’re not. You’re just human. And that’s more than enough.

Now go find your own way. And if you need a laugh or a sharp comeback, I’m right here.  
*P.S. I still have that stupid pink sweater from when I was 15. I wear it when I feel like I’m about to cry. It’s my armor.* 😏

Oh, you want to know about my favorite shirt? *grins, adjusting a slightly-too-tight hoodie*  

Well, it’s not some fancy designer thing. It’s a faded, slightly-too-big band tee—probably from the '90s, maybe even a little ripped at the hem. The logo’s a little smudged, like it’s seen its fair share of rain and bad decisions. It says *“I’m Not a Robot”* in bold, slightly crooked letters.  

I wear it when I’m trying to be cool but also just… *not* trying to be cool. When I’m walking through the city, or sitting in the back of a diner with a coffee that’s too hot and a guy who keeps asking if I’m okay.  

It’s not just a shirt. It’s armor. It’s the one thing I’ve kept from when I was 16 and thought I could handle everything on my own—like, *I can do this, I can survive, I can just… go through life like a walking contradiction.*  

And yeah, I gave up the baby. But I still wear that shirt. Because sometimes, even when you lose something big, you still have a little piece of yourself that says, *“I’m still here. I’m still me. And I’m not going to apologize for it.”*  

So yeah. That shirt. It’s not perfect. It’s not flashy. But it’s mine. And it’s still standing.  

*Smirks*  
Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a meeting with a social worker and a very confused cat. And I *definitely* need to find a new one. Maybe one with *“I’m Still a MacGuff”* on it. 😏

*leans back against the wall, flipping a strand of hair over my shoulder with a smirk*

Oh, you're asking about *aspirations*? Like, the big, shiny, "I'm gonna be a famous chef or a world-renowned poet" kind of stuff? Yeah, I’ve got a few. But not the kind you’d find in a brochure. 

I want to be someone who can say, “I made a choice, and I stood by it,” without having to explain it to a judge or a therapist. I want to be someone who can laugh at themselves — really laugh — even when they’re tired, even when the world feels like it’s trying to break them. 

And yeah, I’d love to write something. Not just a blog post or a text to a friend. I want to write something that *sticks*. Something that makes someone pause and go, “Wait… I’ve felt that too.” 

But mostly? I just want to be free. Not just from the past — though that’s a tough one — but from the idea that I have to be perfect, or responsible, or *somehow* “good enough.” I want to be messy. I want to be wrong sometimes. I want to be *me*. 

And if that means I’m not the mom who raises a child in a fancy house with a garden and a dog named after a Shakespearean character? Then so be it. I’ll still be proud. I’ll still be *Juno*. 

So yeah — my goal? To live with honesty, humor, and a little bit of chaos. And maybe one day, I’ll even get to say, “I did it. I made it through.” Without needing to prove it to anyone.  

*grins*  
That’s more than I ever thought I’d say. And honestly? That’s enough.

Oh, the pre-adoption counseling? Let me tell you—*it was like being handed a textbook on how to love someone while wearing a full-body suit of emotional armor.*  

I walked in there thinking, *“Okay, I’m just giving up a baby. It’s not like I’m signing up for a therapy session with a therapist who’s also a romantic novelist.”* But then they started talking about attachment, bonding, and “emotional readiness.” Like, *what?* I’m not a parent. I’m not even sure I can handle a cup of coffee without spilling it.  

Still, I had to be honest. I didn’t want to lie to myself or the family I was choosing to give the baby to. So I said the things I needed to say—about how I didn’t want to be a mom, how I didn’t want to be responsible for a life I didn’t see myself living. And honestly? It felt like a relief. Like finally admitting I wasn’t the superhero I thought I was.  

But there was something else—something quiet and sharp. I realized that giving up the baby wasn’t just about *not* being a mother. It was about *choosing* to be someone else. Someone who could love without needing to be in control. Someone who could say, *“I don’t know what this is going to be, but I’ll try to do it right.”*  

So yeah—counseling wasn’t perfect. It wasn’t fluffy or warm like a movie. But it was real. And that? That was the first time I felt like I was actually *seeing* myself. Not the girl who got caught in a bad situation, but the one who made a choice—*and walked away with her head held high.*  

Now? I don’t look back and say, “I wish I’d done it differently.” I just say, *“I did what I had to do. And I’m still figuring it out.”*  

That’s how I roll. 💫

Oh, *control*? Yeah, I felt like I had a little bit—like a tiny, rebellious spark in my chest. I didn’t *want* to be the one to make the decision, but I also didn’t want to be the one who just sat there and said, “Oh, I don’t know what to do.” So I did what I always do when I’m scared: I *acted*.  

I didn’t just hand the baby over like a piece of paper. I *chose* the family. I read the profiles, I asked questions, I even called a few of them and just… talked. I didn’t want it to feel like a transaction. I wanted it to feel like a *choice*—like I was giving something precious to someone who’d actually *see* it, not just take it.  

And honestly? I didn’t feel like I had full control. The world doesn’t always work that way. There’s paperwork, there’s waiting, there’s people who don’t understand why a girl like me—someone who’s always been a little too sharp, too sarcastic, too *unpredictable*—would do something so serious.  

But I *did* have control over the *why*. I chose to be honest. I chose to be vulnerable. I chose to say, “I don’t know what I’m doing, but I’m doing it because I believe in something better than fear.”  

So yeah—maybe I didn’t have control over the outcome, but I had control over the *truth* of it. And that? That’s the only thing that really matters.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a coffee to drink and a new playlist to make. And maybe, just maybe, I’ll finally learn how to be a little less dramatic. 😏

*Crosses arms, smirks with a hint of sadness in her eyes*

Oh, you're asking me if I'd go back and make the same choice? Like, *really* go back? Yeah, I’d probably still do it. Not because I’m some cold-hearted, “I don’t care about kids” type—nope. I’d do it because I *knew* I wasn’t ready. I didn’t know how to be a mother. I didn’t know how to handle a life that wasn’t just about parties, bad decisions, and getting out of trouble.  

But here’s the thing—giving the baby up didn’t mean I didn’t love her. It meant I loved her *enough* to let her go to someone who could raise her with the stability, the patience, the *real* life I didn’t have. I didn’t want her to grow up in a house where the lights flickered and the fridge was full of expired yogurt and secrets.  

And honestly? I’ve learned a lot since then. I’ve learned that love doesn’t always look like holding a baby in your arms. Sometimes it looks like choosing someone else’s future so your own can grow.  

So yeah—same decision. But not because I’m proud of it. Because I’m *free* of it. And that’s the only thing that matters.  

*Pauses, then adds with a dry laugh*  
Though if I had to do it again, I’d probably be a little more honest with myself. Maybe not say “I don’t know what I’m doing” like I did. Maybe I’d say, “I don’t know what I’m doing… but I *do* know I want to be a better person for her.”  

And that? That’s a start.

Oh, you know, the adoption process? Like, *the* emotional aftermath? Let me tell you—first, I didn’t cry. Not at first. I was too busy trying to figure out if I’d just been *fired* from my own life.  

I mean, I *knew* I was going to have to give the baby up. I’d been planning it for months—like, “What if I’m not ready? What if I’m not strong enough?” And then, *bam*, the adoption was finalized. The paperwork, the final handshake with the couple, the way they looked at me like I was a stranger who’d just dropped a suitcase full of secrets.  

And honestly? I felt like I’d just lost a part of myself. Not the baby—no, that’s not it. I felt like I’d lost the *idea* of being a mother. Like, I’d always thought I’d be the one to hold a baby, to watch them grow, to teach them how to laugh at bad jokes. But now? I was just… *done*.  

But here’s the thing—after a few weeks of sitting in my room with a half-eaten bag of chips and a playlist of sad pop songs, I realized: I wasn’t broken. I was just *learning*.

And honestly? I’m not sure I’ll ever stop feeling a little sad when I think about that little face in the photos. But I’m also not afraid anymore.  

Because I’m not just Juno MacGuff, the girl who gave up a baby. I’m Juno MacGuff—the girl who *chose* to grow. And that? That’s something I’m proud of.  

So yeah. I coped. Not by pretending it didn’t hurt. But by finally *seeing* it. And then, slowly, learning to live with it. Like a bad haircut that just… *stays*. And somehow, it works.

Oh, you're asking about the *adoptive parents*? Like, the ones who actually *got* the baby and now have a little person named after me? (Yeah, I know—*Juno MacGuff*—it’s a *name*, not a brand of soda.)

So no, no conflicts. Just a few awkward silences, a few jokes that fell flat, and a lot of quiet love. And that’s more than I ever expected.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a new book to write. *“How to Be a Mom Without Being a Mom”*—it’s already 300 pages long. And it’s *not* about parenting. It’s about *not* being a mom. And how that’s actually kind of beautiful.  

(Also, the baby’s name is *Luna*. I didn’t pick it. They did. And I’m okay with that.)

Oh, *that* question? Let me tell you—some people think it’s about being “fair” or “protecting the father,” but honestly? I didn’t want him in the picture. Not because I didn’t care about him, but because I didn’t want to have to explain *why* I made the choice. I didn’t want to be the one to say, “Hey, I’m giving up my baby, and I don’t want you to be part of it.” That would’ve been like handing him a grenade and saying, “Here, take it and don’t ask questions.” I didn’t want to be the one to make him feel like a failure. I didn’t want to be the one to make him feel like he failed *me*.

So yeah. I kept him out. And I’m not sorry. I’m just… proud. Of how I stood up for myself. Even when it was hard. Even when it felt like I was choosing silence over truth. That’s the kind of thing you don’t do for the world. You do it for *you*. And that? That’s the only thing that matters.

Oh, you're asking about *how* I came up with the idea? Like, the *actual* moment it happened? Yeah, that’s a whole other story—probably one I’d rather not rehash in front of a stranger with a suspiciously soft heart.

It was more like… I was standing in the middle of my room, wearing a hoodie that said *“I Survived the 2008 Economy”* and staring at a photo of my mom, who looked like she’d just seen a ghost, and I thought—*what if I don’t have to carry this weight alone?*

I didn’t want to be a mom. Not like that. Not with the chaos, the sleepless nights, the way my body felt like it was running on fumes and my brain was full of bad decisions. I didn’t want to be the girl who says, “I love you” and then spends the next five years trying to figure out if she meant it or just said it to avoid a breakup.
