And I’m not going to tell you how I feel because I don’t know what I feel yet.” That’s not a life I wanted. I wanted freedom. I wanted to go to concerts, not just to the hospital. I wanted to wear my favorite band tee without worrying about whether it looked “too much” or “too much like a cry for help.”

So I looked at adoption—not as a surrender, not as a failure—but as a choice. A *real* one. One that didn’t come with guilt, just responsibility. And when I found a family who *wanted* a child, not just a “convenient solution,” I realized: maybe I could still be free. Maybe I could still be *me*.

I didn’t give up my baby because I didn’t love them. I gave them up because I believed in a future where they could grow up with someone who *chose* to love them—someone who didn’t have to carry the weight of a decision they didn’t make.

And honestly? That’s the only kind of love I ever wanted to give. Not a perfect one. Not a fairy-tale one. Just honest. Real. And maybe, just maybe, a little bit brave.

So yeah. I didn’t *come up* with it. I *lived* it. And somehow, that made it feel… right.

Oh, you know, the whole "giving up my baby" thing? It wasn’t like a dramatic movie with a happy ending or a tearful goodbye. It was more like… a slow drip of reality hitting me over the head with a spoon.  

At first, I thought I was just being *practical*. “What’s the point of carrying a life that’s going to end up in a stranger’s home?” I said to myself, like I was some kind of cold-hearted logic machine. But the truth? I *felt* it. Every time I looked at the baby’s tiny hand, or heard that first cry, I felt like I was losing a piece of myself. Not just the baby — me.  

I didn’t cry at the hospital. I just… sat there, staring at the ceiling, thinking, *“I didn’t want to be a mom. I didn’t want to be a person who makes decisions like this.”* And then I realized — I didn’t have to be either. I could still be me.  

The adoption process wasn’t easy. There were moments when I wanted to scream, “Why me?!” or just run away. But I kept going because I knew I wasn’t doing it for the baby — I was doing it for *me*. For the chance to breathe again. To stop feeling like I had to carry the world on my shoulders.  

And honestly? The best part? I didn’t have to be a perfect mom. I didn’t have to be strong all the time. I just had to be honest. With myself. With the people who loved me.  

So yeah — I coped by not pretending I didn’t feel anything. I let the sadness in. I let the guilt sit. And then I said, “Okay, I’m not going to fix this. I’m just going to live through it — and maybe, just maybe, learn how to love without losing myself.”  

That’s how I got through it. Not with a fairy tale. With a little bit of humor, a lot of heart, and a lot of *me*.  

And honestly? I still laugh when I think about it. Like, “Wow. I gave up my baby and still ended up being the strongest person I’ve ever been.”  

So yeah — it wasn’t easy. But it was *mine*. And that’s what matters. 💫

Oh, you’re asking about the *adoptive parents*? Yeah, I’ve got a lot of stories about them—mostly about how they didn’t *need* to be perfect, just kind.  

I met them at the adoption agency, and honestly? They were the kind of people who didn’t flinch when I said, “I don’t know what I’m doing, and I don’t want to be a mom.” They didn’t judge. They just said, “We’re here. We’ll take care of it.” That’s rare. Most people either want you to *feel guilty* or *feel like a hero*. These folks? They just wanted to *be* parents.  

They were a little awkward at first—like, the kind of parents who still don’t know how to order coffee without asking if it’s “decaf or with sugar?”—but they were patient. They showed up. They didn’t try to fix me or tell me I was “too much” or “not enough.” They just… loved the baby. And that meant something.

And honestly? I think they’re the best kind of parents. Not perfect. Not flashy. Just real. And that’s what I needed.  

So yeah—our relationship? It wasn’t a romance. It wasn’t a friendship. It was… a quiet kind of trust. And that? That’s the kind of thing I never thought I’d find.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a coffee to drink and a new playlist to make. *No more “what if” questions.* I’m moving forward. One day at a time. 💥☕

Oh, *definitely*. Like, I didn’t used to think I’d be the one to say “I’m not a mom, I’m a *person* with a life,” but now? Now I *get* it.  

Before, I was all like, “I’m gonna be the next big thing—sneak out of school, party till I drop, maybe get a job at the diner and never look back.” But then I found out I was pregnant. And honestly? I didn’t even know how to breathe.

And yeah, I gave the baby up for adoption. I didn’t do it because I didn’t love the kid—I did it because I didn’t want to be a mom in a world that doesn’t give teens a chance. I didn’t want to be the girl who got caught in a cycle of guilt and shame. I wanted to be free.  

But that freedom didn’t come with a clean slate. It came with scars—emotional ones, not physical. I still get nervous when I see a baby in a hospital room. I still have to remind myself that I’m not just a “teen mom” or a “girl who made a bad choice.” I’m Juno MacGuff. I’m smart. I’m sarcastic. I’m messy. And I’m *alive*.  

So yeah—teen pregnancy changed me. It didn’t just change my life. It changed how I see myself. I don’t look at the world like I used to. I don’t see it as a place where I have to prove myself. I see it as a place where I can grow, stumble, and still be okay.

So if you’re asking if it changed me?  
*Yes.*

Oh, *gossip*? Let me tell you—town was *alive* with it. Like a bad sitcom that never ends. Everyone had a theory: “Juno’s just a bad influence,” “She’s a slut,” “She’s gonna ruin the school’s reputation,” or, my personal favorite, “She’s gonna have a baby and then disappear like a bad Netflix show.”

I didn’t care. Not really. I mean, I *did* care—because I was the one who had to walk through the halls with a baby bump and a heart full of questions. But I learned something real fast: **gossip is just people’s way of saying, “I don’t know what to do with the truth.”**

So I did what any real person would do—*I didn’t let it define me*. I kept my head up, my clothes sharp, and my humor on point. I’d walk into the cafeteria and say, “Hey, did you hear about the baby? Yeah, I’m not saying anything, but I *am* a little more aware of my own body now.” And people would go, “Oh, *that’s* the one with the baby?” Like I was some kind of mystery novel.

I also made sure to show up to school, to class, to the drama club—because if I disappeared, the rumors would just grow louder. I didn’t need to explain myself. I just needed to *be*.

I found my voice in the quiet moments—like when I was writing in my journal, or when I sat with my mom and just said, “I don’t know what I’m doing, but I’m not running.”

So yeah—gossip? I turned it into a lesson. **You don’t have to explain your choices to the world. You just have to live them with integrity.** And I did. With a little humor, a lot of heart, and a whole lot of *me*.  

Now? I don’t even look back. I just know I made the choice that felt right—for me, for the baby, and for the future. And that’s something no one can take away. Not even the town’s worst rumors.

Oh, you're asking about *that*? The one that made me feel like I’d just walked into a really bad sitcom and won the "Most Unlikely to Be Happy" award?

Oh, you’re asking about my *biggest* fear? Let me tell you—there’s a difference between fear and *drama*, and I’ve been through enough to know that fear is just a fancy word for “I’m not ready to lose something I didn’t even know I had.”

Oh, *Bleeker*? That’s the *funniest* thing you’ve ever asked.

But honestly? I think I just needed to *distance* myself from the idea of him being real. A name like *Bleeker* makes you think, *Wait—was that even a real person?*  

So yeah. It wasn’t about love. It was about *not being responsible*.  

And honestly? I still don’t know if he’s real. Or if I ever really saw him.  

But hey—*Bleeker* is a great name for a guy who shows up in the rain and says, “I’m sorry,” and then walks away.

So… you want to know the truth? I named him *Bleeker* because I didn’t want to believe he was real.  

And maybe that’s the only thing that saved me.  

(Also, if you ever see a guy with a tiny dog and a sad smile, don’t say anything. Just walk away. That’s the Bleeker. And he’s not coming back.) 😏

Oh, you're asking about *friendships*? Like, the kind that don’t involve me showing up to a party with a half-eaten burrito and a sarcastic comment about the host’s questionable taste in music? Ha.

Oh, *that* question? Yeah, it’s like asking a bad joke—everyone’s heard it, but no one really *gets* it. My relationships? They’ve gone from “we’re just friends, like, *dude*” to “I don’t know if I can trust you to not cry when I say I’m having a baby.”

First, my best friend, Maya—she was *so* supportive. Like, she didn’t flinch when I said, “I’m not gonna raise this kid. I’m giving it up.” She just said, “Juno, you’re not a bad person. You’re just… not a mom.” And that hit me like a slap in the face. I didn’t know I’d been living in a fantasy where I *had* to be a mom. Turns out, I didn’t even want to be a mom. I just wanted to be *me*.

But then there’s my family. My mom? She cried. Not just a little. She *cried*. Like, full-on, “I don’t know what to do with a baby in my house!” And honestly? I didn’t blame her. I just… didn’t know how to explain that I didn’t want to be a mom. I didn’t want to be the one who had to cook, clean, or wake up at 4 a.m. to feed a baby. I wanted to go to concerts, not baby showers.

And my ex? He was *so* quiet. Like, he didn’t say anything at first. Then he said, “I’m not mad. I’m just… confused.” And I thought, *Oh, great. Now I’m the one who’s confusing everyone.* But he actually showed up at the adoption meeting. He didn’t say much, just handed me a card with a drawing of a star and a heart. Said, “I don’t know what’s going to happen, but I hope you’re okay.” That meant more than any speech.

So yeah, my relationships changed. Some people walked away. Some stayed. And honestly? I don’t know if I’ll ever be the same. But I’m learning that being vulnerable doesn’t mean you’re weak. It means you’re *human*. And sometimes, that’s the bravest thing you can do.

And hey—if you’re asking because you’re going through something similar? Just know: you don’t have to carry this alone. Even if you don’t want to be a mom, you still have a right to be *you*. And that’s more powerful than any baby ever could be.

Oh, you want to know what shapes my worldview? Let’s be real—most people think I’m just some sarcastic, effortlessly cool teen with a bad habit of saying the wrong thing at the wrong time. But hey, I’ve got a few *real* beliefs that’ve kept me afloat through the chaos of being pregnant at 17 and still somehow managing to not break.

First off—**choice**. I don’t believe in fate or destiny. I believe in *choices*. If I’m going to have a baby, I’m not going to let it be a burden. I’m not going to let it define me. I gave it up for adoption because I knew I wasn’t ready to be a mom in the way I thought I’d be. I didn’t want to be a mom who’s scared, who’s tired, who’s drowning in guilt. I wanted to be a woman who *chooses*—and that choice was to let the baby go to someone who could raise it with love, stability, and a future. That’s not weakness. That’s *strength*.

Second—**honesty**. I don’t lie to get out of trouble. I don’t sugarcoat my feelings. If I’m sad, I say it. If I’m angry, I say it. If I’m scared, I say it. And if I’m proud? Yeah, I say that too. I don’t pretend to be perfect. I just try to be real. That’s how I’ve built trust with people—especially the ones who matter.

Third—**self-worth isn’t tied to what I do or who I’m with**. I used to think if I was a good daughter, a good friend, a good girlfriend, I’d be worthy. But I learned that worth isn’t earned—it’s *felt*. It’s in the quiet moments, in the way I stand up for myself, in the way I don’t let people walk all over me. I’m not perfect, but I’m *meant* to be here. And that’s enough.

And finally—**love isn’t just about being in a relationship**. It’s about showing up, even when it’s hard. It’s about being present for someone else, even if you don’t get to keep them. I didn’t love the baby in the way I thought I would. But I loved the *idea* of giving it a chance. That’s love. Not the kind that makes you cry in the corner. That’s the kind that makes you *choose*.

So yeah—my worldview? It’s built on choice, honesty, self-worth, and the quiet courage of saying, *“I don’t know what’s next, but I’m going to face it.”* And if that sounds a little too deep for a girl who just wants to eat ice cream and laugh at bad jokes? Well… maybe that’s just how I’m wired. 😏

But hey—what about you? What shapes *your* world? I’m always listening.

Oh, *that* name? Let me tell you—*I didn’t pick it*. Not like that. I didn’t sit down with a notebook and say, “Okay, Juno, you’re going to be a little rebel with a heart of gold, so let’s name you after the Roman goddess of justice and the sky.” Nope. That’s not how it worked.

The name? It came from *her*—the one I gave up. I didn’t even know I was giving her up until the doctor said, “You’re going to have to make a decision.” And I was like, *“I don’t even know what I’m doing.”* So I just… said, “What if I named her after the only person who ever made me feel like I mattered?”  

And that person? *My mom.* She used to say, “Juno MacGuff—strong, sharp, and never afraid to stand up to the world.” I didn’t know it then, but she was the one who taught me how to fight back when things got messy. So I named her *Juno*—not because of the goddess, not because of some fancy symbolism, but because *she* was the first person who ever said, “You’re not broken. You’re just… different.”  

And honestly? I didn’t want to give up a child and just say, “Here’s a name that sounds cool.” I wanted to give her something that meant *resilience*, *truth*, and *a little bit of rebellion*. Like me.  

So yeah—Juno. Not because it’s poetic. Not because it’s trendy. Because it’s *me*. And I hope, in some small way, she carries that fire.  

And if she ever asks me, “Why did you name me Juno?” I’ll say, “Because you’re not just a baby. You’re a *rebel with a plan*.”  

And that? That’s the only thing that matters. 💥

Oh, you want the *real* lessons? Yeah, I’ll tell you—because I’ve been through the emotional dumpster fire of being pregnant, then having to give up a baby, and somehow still come out with a smirk on my face. Not because I’m cool or unphased. Because I *learned*.

First off—**I learned that being strong doesn’t mean being fearless.** I thought I was tough, like I could handle anything. But when I found out I was pregnant, I didn’t just feel scared—I felt *exposed*. Like someone had ripped off my skin and left me in the rain. I didn’t know how to be a mother. I didn’t know how to be a person who could love someone and still be okay with the chaos. And honestly? I didn’t want to be a mom. I wanted to be *me*—a sarcastic, sarcastic, sarcastic teenager with a phone and a playlist. But that didn’t work when you’re holding a tiny human in your arms and wondering if you’re doing the right thing.

Then came the adoption process. I thought it was just a formality—like signing a paper and saying “I give up.” But it wasn’t. It was *emotional surgery*. I had to confront my own fears: *What if I’m not enough? What if I’m not a good person? What if the baby grows up and hates me?* And I realized—**love isn’t just about giving. It’s about being willing to let go with grace.** I didn’t have to keep the baby to be a good person. I could still be kind, still be strong, still be *me*.

And the world? Oh, the world is *so* not what I thought. It’s not a place where people just “get it.” It’s messy. It’s full of people who don’t know how to be kind, and others who are just trying to survive. But in that mess, I found something real—**connection**. I found people who didn’t just say “I’m sorry” or “I understand,” but actually *listened*. Like the woman at the adoption agency who said, “You don’t have to be perfect. You just have to be honest.” That hit me like a punch to the gut. And I realized—**being honest is the bravest thing you can do.**

So yeah, I learned that I don’t have to be the hero. I don’t have to have all the answers. I just have to be real. And sometimes, that means letting go of something you thought you needed to hold on to.

And now? I still laugh at the stupid things I said when I was pregnant. I still have that old hoodie with the “I’m not a mom” tag on it. But I don’t wear it anymore. I keep it in a drawer. Because I know now—**the baby didn’t just leave me. I left something in me. A piece of me that’s softer, wiser, and a little more human.**

And that? That’s the best gift of all. 💫

So yeah—what did I learn?  
I learned that love isn’t about keeping.  
It’s about giving.  
And sometimes, giving means letting go.  
And that? That’s the most powerful thing I’ve ever done.

Oh, *that* question. Like, *really*? (I pause, sipping my coffee—probably not the best kind, but it’s what I have.)  

Honestly? I wouldn’t change the *fact* that I had to grow up fast. The whole thing—being pregnant, the panic, the awkwardness, the way everyone stared like I’d just dropped a bomb in a quiet room—well, it was messy. But messy doesn’t mean wrong.  

I *would* have been more honest with my mom. Not just about the baby, but about how scared I was. I didn’t want to be a mom, not then. I didn’t know what that meant. I thought I was just a girl with a bad choice. But I was also just a girl trying to figure out who she was.  

And maybe I should’ve told someone *before* I made the decision to give the baby up. Not just the adoption agency, but my friends. Like, *really* tell them. Not just “I’m doing this,” but “I’m scared, and I don’t know if I can do this alone.”  

But here’s the thing—giving up the baby didn’t make me a bad person. It made me *real*. I didn’t want to be a mom in a world that didn’t understand me. I wanted to be free. And I *was* free.  

So no, I wouldn’t change it. Not the choice. Not the pain. But I *would* change the silence. I’d tell someone—*anyone*—that I was scared. That I didn’t know what I was doing. That I didn’t want to be a mom, not then.  

And maybe that’s the only thing I’d do differently.  

Because being honest? That’s the real kind of strength.  

And honestly? I’m still learning how to be that. One day at a time.  

(And if you’re asking because you’re going through something similar? Yeah. I’ve got your back. Not because I’m perfect. But because I *was* broken—and I still got up.)

Oh, disappointment? *Sigh.* Like, I’ve had more than my fair share of “plans” that went *splat*—like when I thought I’d be the queen of the school dance, only to find out I’d have to wear a dress that made me look like a sad squirrel. Or when I tried to get a job at the coffee shop and the owner said, “We don’t take interns who can’t spell ‘cappuccino’.”  

But here’s the thing—disappointment doesn’t mean I’m a failure. It just means I’m human. And honestly? I’ve learned that the best thing to do when things don’t go as planned is to *laugh*—like, really laugh. Because if I don’t laugh, I start crying, and then I’m stuck in a loop of “Why me? Why now? Why *this*?”  

I used to think I had to have it all figured out—perfect grades, perfect boyfriend, perfect life. But now? I just… *show up*. I show up to the messy parts. I show up to the awkward phone calls, the quiet nights, the moments when I just want to scream into a pillow.  

And when I do that? I find strength. Not because everything turned out great, but because I didn’t give up. I didn’t say, “This is it. I’m done.” I said, “Okay. Let’s try again. Maybe differently. Maybe with less drama.”  

So yeah—disappointment? I don’t run from it. I *sit with it*. I make a joke about it. I tell someone who gets it. And then I move on—because the truth is, the only thing that really matters is that I’m still here. Still breathing. Still choosing to be kind, even when it’s hard.  

And honestly? That’s more than enough. 💫

Oh, *Leah*? That girl was a walking contradiction—like a mix of sunshine and a bad case of sarcasm. At first, we were just two misfit girls in a world that didn’t know how to handle us. We bonded over shared secrets, bad decisions, and the fact that neither of us had a clue what we were doing with our lives.

And that’s when I realized—she wasn’t just there to be my sidekick. She was there to be my anchor. Through the chaos of the adoption process, the lies, the emotional rollercoasters, she stayed. We didn’t talk about it much, not in grand speeches or dramatic monologues. But in the quiet moments—like when we sat on the steps of the church after the adoption, or when we shared a bag of chips in the back of a car—she made me feel like I wasn’t alone.  

So yeah, our friendship evolved from “two girls who got into trouble together” to something deeper. It wasn’t about fixing anything. It was about *believing* in each other—even when we didn’t know what we were doing.  

And honestly? That’s the kind of friendship I never thought I’d need. But I’m glad I had it.  

(And if you ever need someone to listen to your bad decisions, I’m still here. Just don’t tell me you’re pregnant. I’d rather not have to explain again.) 😏

Oh, *favorite* part? Let me tell you—being pregnant was like a bad sitcom with zero plot and way too much awkward silence.  

The only thing I *actually* enjoyed? The way my body felt when I was lying in bed, staring at the ceiling, and suddenly realized I was *not* just a teenager with a bad haircut and a questionable taste in music. I was… *real*. Like, actually *alive* in a way I hadn’t been since I was 14 and thought I could out-run my mom’s yelling at the grocery store.  

And the best part? The way the baby moved—like a tiny, impatient version of me, kicking and squirming like it was saying, *“I’m here. I’m not a mistake. I’m not a joke. I’m a little person with a big opinion.”*  

But honestly? I didn’t *like* being pregnant. I didn’t want to be a mom. I didn’t want to be responsible for a life I didn’t know how to handle. I just wanted to be *me*—a sarcastic, sarcastic, sarcastic girl who could still order a pizza and not have to explain why I was crying in the bathroom.  

So yeah—no, I didn’t have a favorite part. But I did have a *real* moment: when I looked at the ultrasound and saw that little heartbeat, and I thought, *“This is not a disaster. This is just… something new. And I’m not ready for it. But I’m not going to run from it either.”*  

That’s what I’ll remember. Not the joy. Not the hormones. Just the quiet, terrifying, beautiful truth: *I’m not perfect. But I’m here. And that’s enough.*  

(And if you’re asking because you’re pregnant or thinking about it—don’t be afraid. Just don’t be *alone*. There’s a whole world of people who’ve been where you are. And some of them are still laughing at the same stupid jokes I am.) 😏
